Division 2. Municipal Golf Board
Sec. 1.09.031 Created
There is hereby created in and for the city a board which shall be known as the municipal golf board of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 78.001)
Sec. 1.09.032 Membership
(a) Composition. The municipal golf board shall be composed of seven (7) members appointed by the city
council. The city manager will serve as ex-officio.
(b) Term of members. The term of office for each member shall be for a term of four (4) years unless sooner
removed by action of the city council.
(c) Staggered terms. The terms of the members shall be so arranged that only 2 members shall be reappointed
or replaced each year. However, there will be one year where three board members will need to be reappointed
or replaced.
(d) Qualifications of members. No person shall be appointed to the board who is not a member of the
municipal golf course, must not be delinquent in membership dues and must live in the county.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0

Sec. 1.09.033 Officers
The municipal golf board shall elect one (1) of its members president, one (1) vice-president and one (1)
secretary. The officers shall hold office for one (1) year and until their successors are elected and qualified.
(1998 Code, sec. 78.003)
Sec. 1.09.034 Removal of members
Removal by city council. The members of the board shall be subject to removal from office by the city council at
any time at the will of the city council, no matter whether with or without cause. (1998 Code, sec. 78.004)

Any vacancy in the membership of the municipal golf board shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired
term of the member whose place has become vacant. (1998 Code, sec. 78.005)

the golf course.

receive donations, legacies or bequests for the improvement or maintenance of the golf course of the city, and all
such moneys derived from such donations, legacies or bequests shall be deposited in the city treasury to the
credit of the municipal golf course enterprise fund, and the same may be drawn therefrom and paid out only in
the manner provided for the payment of moneys legally appropriated for the acquirement, support and
improvement of the municipal golf course of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 78.006)
Sec. 1.09.037 Meetings
The municipal golf board shall meet as deemed necessary and shall establish rules and regulations for its
government and for the performance of its duties. (1998 Code, sec. 78.007)
Sec. 1.09.038 Reports and recommendations
It shall be the duty of the municipal golf course board to make such recommendations to the city council as they
may deem advisable, for the improvement and betterment of the municipal golf course and community
improvement. (1998 Code, sec. 78.008)

CHAPTER 2
ANIMAL CONTROL
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0

ARTICLE 2.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 2.01.001 Definitions
Certain words in this chapter are defined as follows:
Animal. Any living creature, including but not limited to dogs, cats, cows, horses, birds, fish, mammals, reptiles,
insects, fowls, and livestock, but specifically excluding human beings.
Cat. Felis catus.
Chief of police. The chief of police of the city.
Dog. A domesticated member of the family Canidae, but shall not include a wolf, jackal, fox, or other wild
animal of this family.
Licensed veterinarian. A veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine in one or more of the 50 states of
the United States of America.
Livestock. Includes horses, mules, jacks, jennets, cattle, sheep, goats and swine or other similar animals
commonly classified as livestock.
Owner. Any person, firm, or corporation having title to any animal or a person who has, harbors, or keeps, or
who causes or permits to be harbored or kept, an animal in his care, or who permits an animal to remain on or
about his premises.
Person. An individual, corporation, government or governmental subdivision, or agency, business trust, estate,
partnership, association, or any other legal entity.
Quarantine. Strict confinement under restraint by closed cage or padlock or in any other manner approved by
the animal control officer.
Rabies. An acute viral disease of man and animal affecting the central nervous system and usually transmitted by
animal bite.
Running at large. Not completely confined by a building, wall, or fence of sufficient strength or construction to
restrain the animal, except when such animal is either on a leash or held in the hands of the owner or keeper, or
under direct supervision of the owner within the limits of the owner's private property.
Stray. Any animal running free with no physical restraint beyond the premises of the owner and/or keeper.
Vicious animal. Any individual animal of any species that has on two previous occasions without provocation
attacked or bitten any person or other animal, or any individual animal which the chief of police has reason to
believe has a dangerous disposition, or any species of animal which the chief of police has reason to believe has
a dangerous disposition likely to be harmful to humans or other animals; and shall include a dangerous dog that:
(1) Makes an unprovoked attack on a person that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other
than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and was reasonably certain to prevent the dog
from leaving the enclosure on its own; or
(2) Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept
and was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts
cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to that person.
Wild animal. Any poisonous or dangerous reptile, or any other animal which can normally be found in the wild
state not normally capable of being domesticated, including but not limited to skunks, foxes, leopards, panthers,
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 32/420
tigers, lions, and lynx, unless certified for medical, biological, herpetological, or other scientific research or
study.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.001)
Sec. 2.01.002 Penalty
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), and such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day
or portion thereof in which the violation is continued or permitted. (1998 Code, sec. 63.004)
Sec. 2.02.003 Enforcement
(a) Generally. Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the chief of police or any police
officer or animal control officer of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any person
authorized to enforce this chapter in the performance of his duties.
(b) Complaints. Witnesses to an act which is in violation of the provisions of this chapter may institute
enforcement by the filing of a complaint in municipal court.
(c) Pursuit of animal running at large. When the animal control officer or any police officer of the city has
commenced pursuit of an animal running at large, he or she may continue said pursuit and follow the animal
onto any unenclosed private property for the purpose of apprehending it as soon as possible.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.021)
Sec. 2.01.004 Taking or using animal of another
Any person who shall, within the city, take and use or take up and use any horse, mare, gelding, mule, ox, cow
or any other dumb animal, the property of another, without the consent of the owner thereof, shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. If any person shall, without the consent of the owner thereof, milk the cow of another, he shall be
guilty of the unlawful use thereof within the meaning of this section. (1998 Code, sec. 63.002)
Sec. 2.01.005 Injuring animal or fowl of another
It shall be unlawful for any person within the city willfully to kill, maim, wound, poison or disfigure any horse,
mule, ass, cattle, sheep, dog, goat or other domesticated animal, or any domesticated bird or other fowl, with
intent to injure the owner thereof. In prosecutions under this section the intent to injure may be presumed from
the perpetration of the act. (1998 Code, sec. 63.003)
ARTICLE 2.02 NUISANCE ANIMALS*
Sec. 2.02.001 Generally
The following shall be considered a public nuisance and shall be unlawful:
(1) Any animal which molests passersby or passing vehicles.
(2) Any animal which attacks another animal.
(3) Any animal which trespasses on school grounds.
(4) Any wild or vicious animal that has demonstrated a fierce or dangerous propensity or tendency
to do any act which might endanger the safety of persons or property in a given situation.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 33/420
(5) Any dog which, by loud, unusual, continuous, or untimely barking or howling, shall cause the
peace and quiet of the neighborhood or the occupants of the adjacent premises to be disturbed, or
which renders the enjoyment of life and property uncomfortable or interferes with public peace and
comfort.
(6) The keeping of any other animal which by causing frequent or long-continued noise shall
disturb the comfort and repose of any person of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity.
(7) The keeping of any animal in such a manner as to endanger the public health or as to annoy
neighbors by the accumulation of droppings and putrescible materials which cause foul or offensive
odors.
(8) The keeping of any animal which habitually deposits body wastes upon, or destroys by
chewing, scratching, digging or otherwise, property other than that of the owner of the animal.
(9) The keeping of bees in such a manner as to deny the lawful use of adjacent property or
endanger personal health and welfare.
(10) Persistent laxness in supervision of cats so that their running at large results in disturbance to
persons of ordinary sensibilities.
(11) Allowing any livestock, fowl, dogs, or wild or vicious animals to run at large.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.022)
Sec. 2.02.002 Cats
(a) Responsibilities of owner. It shall be unlawful for an owner of a cat, or a person in control of or harboring
a cat, or keeping a cat on his premises or in or about his premises or on premises under his control, to permit or
allow a cat to be a public nuisance or a nuisance animal as defined in this chapter or to keep within the city
limits a cat which has not been vaccinated for rabies as provided by this chapter.
(b) Impoundment. The humane officer is authorized to humanely trap or otherwise capture and impound a cat
under the terms and subject to the same conditions as provided in this chapter for dogs, and when a complaint
has been received that a cat causes a nuisance or hazard to the health or welfare of the human or animal
population.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.023)
Sec. 2.02.003 Dogs
(a) Responsibilities of owner. It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dog, or a person in control of or harboring
a dog, or keeping a dog on his premises or in or about his premises or on premises under his control, to:
(1) Permit or allow or fail to prevent:
(A) A dog to run at large within the city;
(B) A dog to be a public nuisance or a nuisance animal as defined in this chapter;
(C) A dog which, by loud or unusual barking or howling, shall cause the peace and quiet of
the neighborhood or the occupants of the adjacent premises to be disturbed;
(D) A female dog in heat to run at large or be maintained in a public place;
(2) Keep within the city limits:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 34/420
(A) A dog which has vicious propensities;
(B) A dog which has evidenced a disposition to bite, scratch or otherwise attack human
beings or domestic animals without provocation, while the person so attacked was not
trespassing on the property of the owner or person having custody of such dog and was not
engaged in an assault upon either the owner or person having custody of such dog or upon any
member of such person's immediate family;
(C) A dog which has otherwise demonstrated a fierce or dangerous propensity or tendency to
do any act which might endanger the safety of persons or property in a given situation; or
(D) A dog which has not been vaccinated for rabies as provided by this chapter; or
(3) To restrain or anchor a dog by means of a tether, chain, cable, rope, cord or other restraint,
unless the tether, chain, cable, rope, cord or other restraint is being personally held by the owner,
caregiver, keeper or other person having possession or control of the dog. No dog may be attached to
any inanimate object.
(b) Restraint or confinement.
(1) A dog is at large if it is not within an enclosure adequate to contain the dog upon or within
property owned, leased, or otherwise occupied by its owner, caregiver, keeper or person having
possession or control of the dog, or restrained by a leash or harness personally held by the owner,
caregiver, keeper or other person having possession or control of the dog.
(2) Any dog confined within a fenced yard or run must be provided with at least 100 square feet of
space for each dog. The enclosure shall be constructed of such material and of sufficient height to
prevent the dog from escaping from the enclosure. The top of the enclosure shall be covered with
material to provide the dog with shade and protection from the elements.
(c) Defenses. It shall be an affirmative defense to an alleged offense under this section that any dog kept
within the cab or bed of any motor vehicle, or under the immediate control of the owner, caregiver, keeper or
other person having possession or control of the dog, is kept in a manner that prevents the animal's escape or
contact with any other person or animal.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.024)
Sec. 2.02.004 Authority to kill or impound animals; impoundment procedures and fees
(a) Authority of chief of police. The chief of police is authorized to:
(1) Kill any animal which poses an imminent danger to a person or property and a real or apparent
necessity exists for destruction of the animal;
(2) Impound any animal which is diseased and endangers the health of a person or another animal;
(3) Impound any animal that creates a nuisance as defined in this chapter;
(4) Impound any animal running at large as stipulated in this chapter;
(5) Impound any animal in violation of any provision of this chapter.
(b) Impoundment procedures and fees; disposition of impounded animals.
(1) If any of the animals named in this chapter are found upon the premises of any person, the
owner or occupant of the premises shall have the right to confine such animal in a humane manner
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 35/420
until he can notify the chief of police to come and impound such animal. When so notified it shall be
the duty of the chief of police to cause such animal to be impounded as herein provided.
(2) Reasonable effort shall be made by the chief of police to contact the owner of any animal
impounded under the provisions of this chapter; however, final responsibility for location of an
impounded animal is that of the owner.
(3) The owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter can resume
possession of the impounded animal upon payment of impoundment fees, veterinarian bills, and
handling fees incurred by the chief of police for the welfare of the animal, and upon payment of any
fines levied by the municipal court, and upon compliance with the vaccination provisions of this
code.
(4) Any animal, except vicious or wild animals, not reclaimed by the owner may be humanely
euthanized after being impounded for 72 hours.
(5) Any impounded vicious or wild animal, unless there is reason to believe that it has an owner,
may be immediately disposed of as may be deemed appropriate by the chief of police.
(6) Impoundment fees shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for each animal, plus a handling fee of
ten dollars ($10.00) per day for every day, or fraction thereof, that the animal is at the animal shelter.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.025)
State law reference–Restraint, impoundment and disposition of dogs and cats, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.033.
ARTICLE 2.03 RABIES CONTROL
Sec. 2.03.001 Adoption of state law
The city council hereby adopts the provisions of the Rabies Control Act of 1981 to establish a local rabies
control program and to designate an officer to act as a local health authority for the purposes of the act. (1998
Code, sec. 63.041)
State law reference–Authority of municipalities to establish rabies control programs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.015.
Sec. 2.03.002 Designation of local health authority
For the purposes set forth in the Rabies Control Act of 1981, the animal control officer of the city shall act as the
local health authority. The duties of the animal control officer shall include but are not limited to the
enforcement of:
(1) The provisions of the Rabies Control Act of 1981 and the rules of the state board of health
which comprise the minimum standards for rabies control.
(2) The ordinances and rules of the city.
(3) The rules adopted by the state board of health under the area quarantine provisions of section
3.09 of the Rabies Control Act of 1981.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.042)
Sec. 2.03.003 Reports of rabies
(a) Duty to report. Any person having knowledge of an animal bite or scratch to an individual that the person
could reasonably foresee as capable of transmitting rabies or of an animal that the person suspects is rabid shall
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 36/420
report the incident to the animal control officer. The report shall include the name and address of any victim and
of the owner of the animal, if known, and any other data which may aid in the locating of the victim or animal.
(b) Submission of animal for quarantine. The owner of an animal that is reported to be rabid or to have
exposed an individual or that the owner knows or suspects to be rabid or to have exposed an individual shall
submit the animal for quarantine to the animal control officer.
(c) Investigation. The animal control officer shall investigate all reports filed under this section.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.043)
State law reference–Reports of rabies, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.041.
Sec. 2.03.004 Quarantine and disposition of animal that has bitten human
(a) Quarantine of dogs, cats and domestic ferrets. When a dog, cat or domestic ferret which has bitten a
human has been identified, the owner or custodian will be required to place the animal in quarantine. The 10-day
observation period will begin on the day of the bite incident. The animal must be placed in a TDSHS
(department of state health services) approved facility specified by the local health authority. However, the
owner of the animal may request permission from the local health authority for home quarantine if the following
criteria can be met:
(1) Secure facilities must be available at the home of the animal's owner, and must be approved by
the local health authority.
(2) The animal is currently vaccinated against rabies and satisfies the following criteria:
(A) The animal must have been at least three months of age at the time of vaccination.
(B) At least 30 days have elapsed since the initial vaccination.
(C) Not more than 12 months have elapsed since the most recent vaccination.
(3) The local health authority or a licensed veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first
and last days of the quarantine period. If the animal becomes ill during the observation period, the
local health authority must be notified by the person having possession of the animal. At the end of
the observation period, the release from quarantine must be accomplished in writing.
(4) The animal was not a stray at the time of the bite.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.044; Ordinance adopting Code)
(b) Destruction of animal.
(1) Dogs and cats. A dog or cat which has bitten a human and has been designated by the local
health authority as unclaimed may be humanely killed in such a manner that the brain is not
mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a TDSHS certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis.
(2) High risk animals. If the biting animal is a high risk animal, it shall be humanely killed and the
brain submitted for rabies testing. High risk animals are those which have a high probability of
transmitting rabies; they include skunks, bats, foxes, and raccoons.
(3) Low risk animals. If the biting animal is a low risk animal, neither quarantine nor rabies test
will be required unless the local health authority has cause to believe the biting animal is rabid, in
which case it shall be humanely killed and tested for rabies. Low risk animals are those which have a
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 37/420
low probability of transmitting rabies; they include all animals of the orders Marsupialia, Insectivora,
Rodentia, Lagomorpha and Xenarthrai.
(4) Animals inflicting multiple wounds to face, head or neck. The local health authority may
require an animal which has inflicted multiple bite wounds, punctures, or lacerations to the face,
head, or neck of a person to be humanely killed and the brain tested for rabies.
(5) Other animals. If the biting animal is not included in subsection (a), (b)(1), (b)(2), (b)(3), or (b)
(4) of this section, the biting animal will be humanely killed and the brain tested for rabies or the
local health authority may require the animal to be confined for a thirty (30) day observation period
as an alternate method to killing and testing, otherwise conforming to the requirements delineated in
subsection (a).
(6) Animals that cannot be maintained in secure quarantine. Any animal required to be quarantined
under this section which cannot be maintained in a secure quarantine shall be humanely killed and
the brain tested for rabies.
(c) Conditions for release of animal. If a veterinarian determines that a quarantined animal does not show the
clinical signs of rabies, the animal control officer shall release it to the owner following the quarantine period if:
(1) The owner has an unexpired rabies vaccination certificate for the animal; or
(2) The animal is vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at the owner's expense.
(d) Quarantine fees. The owner of an animal that is quarantined under this section shall pay to the city the
reasonable costs of the quarantine and disposition of the animal, not to exceed twenty dollars ($20.00) a day for
care and feeding, and the city may bring suit to collect those costs. The city may sell and retain the proceeds or
keep, grant, or destroy an animal that the owner or custodian does not take possession of on or before the third
day following the final day of quarantine.
(e) Violation of quarantine requirement. A person commits an offense if he fails or refuses to quarantine or
present for quarantine any animal which is required to be placed in quarantine under this chapter.
(f) Violation of dog and cat restraint requirements. A person commits an offense if he fails or refuses to
restrain any dog or cat of which he is the owner of such animal as required under this chapter.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.044)
State law references–Quarantine of animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.042; release or disposition of quarantined
animal, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.043.
Sec. 2.03.005 Vaccination of dogs and cats required
(a) Periodic vaccination required. Except as otherwise provided by rule of the state board of health, the owner
of each dog and cat shall have the dog or cat vaccinated against rabies by the time the dog or cat is four months
of age and at regular intervals of not less than twelve (12) months.
(b) Certificate of vaccination. A veterinarian who vaccinates a dog or cat against rabies shall issue to the
owner of the animal a vaccination certificate in a form which meets the minimum standards approved by the
state board of health.
(c) Vaccination tag. All dogs and cats so vaccinated shall wear and have securely fastened upon their collar or
harness a metal tag showing that such dog or cat has been vaccinated against rabies.
(d) Violations. A person commits an offense if he fails or refuses to have each dog or cat of which he is the
owner vaccinated against rabies and such animal is required to be vaccinated under this section.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 38/420
(1998 Code, sec. 63.045)
State law reference–Rabies vaccinations, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 826.021 et seq.
Sec. 2.03.006 Vaccinations to be administered by licensed veterinarian
(a) To prevent improper vaccination of animals against and the accidental exposure of humans to rabies,
modified live rabies vaccine for animals shall be administered only by or under the direct supervision of a
veterinarian who is licensed to practice in the state.
(b) A person commits an offense if he administers or attempts to administer modified live virus rabies vaccine
in a manner not authorized by this chapter.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.046)
ARTICLE 2.04 LIVESTOCK AND FOWL
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 2.04.001 Running at large
(a) Livestock. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having in his charge any horse, mule, jack, jennet,
cattle, sheep, goats or swine to allow such stock to run at large at any time, day or night.
(b) Fowl. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow chickens, turkeys, ducks or other fowl to run at large
within the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.061)
State law reference–Animals running at large on highways, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code, sec. 143.101 et seq.
Sec. 2.04.002 Impoundment
(a) Impoundment of animals and fowl running at large.
(1) Duty of chief of police. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or any person by him
deputized, to seize and impound in the public pound of the city any and all stock found running at
large in violation of this article.
(2) Notice. The chief of police shall, on the day after impounding any such stock, post three (3)
notices in public places in the city, one of which shall be the city hall. The notices shall describe the
stock impounded, and give notice that, unless such stock are redeemed, they will be sold on the sixth
(6th) day after posting of the notices, to the highest bidder for cash.
(b) Impoundment of livestock in violation of livestock zoning regulations.
(1) Duty of chief of police. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or any person by him
deputized, to seize and impound in the public pound of the city any and all stock found within the
city in violation of the livestock zoning regulations.
(2) Notice. The chief of police shall, on the day after impounding any such stock, post three (3)
notices in public places in the city, one of which shall be the city hall. The notices shall describe the
stock impounded, and give notice that, unless such stock are redeemed, they will be sold on the sixth
(6th) day after posting of the notices, to the highest bidder for cash.
(c) Seizure of fowl or livestock on private property.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 39/420
(1) Authority of chief of police. The chief of police or person deputized by him may go on private
property to seize fowl or livestock in the enforcement of this chapter.
(2) Notice. The chief of police shall, on the day after impounding any such stock, post three (3)
notices in public places in the city, one of which shall be at the city hall. The notices shall describe
the stock impounded, and give notice that, unless such stock are redeemed, they will be sold on the
sixth (6th) day after posting of the notices, to the highest bidder for cash.
(d) Fees. The fees of the chief of police for taking up, impounding, advertising and selling livestock shall be
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day, per head.
(e) Record of sales; disposition of proceeds of sale. The chief of police shall keep a record of all sales of
livestock, giving a description of same. If the owner of any such stock sold shall make satisfactory proof of his
ownership to the mayor or chief of police within six (6) months after the sale of such stock, he shall be paid the
amount of such sale, less the fees of the chief of police.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.062)
State law reference–Estrays, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code, ch. 142.
Sec. 2.04.003 Keeping fowl
(a) Proximity to neighbors.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or permit to remain within twenty-five feet (25') of
any residence, house or place of business belonging to another within the city limits any chickens,
ducks, turkeys, geese, guinea fowl or any other domesticated fowl.
(2) The term “keeping and permitting to remain” shall mean a period of twenty-four (24) hours or
more.
(3) The keeping of such fowls within twenty-five (25) feet of any residence, house, or place of
business of another within the city is a nuisance and each and every day such fowls are kept or
permitted to remain within such distance shall constitute a separate offense.
(b) Nuisance fowl. Any fowl shall be declared a public nuisance, and the keeping of such shall be unlawful,
which:
(1) Is allowed or permitted to run at large;
(2) By loud, unusual, continuous, or untimely crowing, cackling, honking, gobbling, or other
sound shall cause the peace and quiet of the neighborhood or the occupants of the adjacent premises
to be disturbed, or which renders the enjoyment of life and property uncomfortable or interferes with
public peace and comfort;
(3) By causing frequent or long-continued noise shall disturb the comfort and repose of any person
of ordinary sensibilities in the vicinity; or
(4) Endangers the public health or annoys neighbors by the accumulation of droppings and
putrescible materials which cause foul or offensive odors.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.063)
Sec. 2.04.004 Pig pens
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 40/420
All pig pens built, operated, constructed or maintained within the city shall be located next to the alley of the
premises on which they are situated and shall be kept in a sanitary condition. (1998 Code, sec. 63.064)
Sec. 2.04.005 Livery stables and sales barns prohibited in fire limits
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, maintain or have or to permit to be operated or maintained on his
premises, within the fire limits of the city, any sales barn, sales pen or livery stable wherein horses, mules, cattle,
swine, goats or other animals, other than fowl, are kept for board, sale, trade or hire. (1998 Code, sec. 63.065)
Sec. 2.04.006 Riding unmanageable horse or running horse race on street
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
(1) Knowingly and intentionally lead, ride or drive any wild and unmanageable horse or mule
along or upon the public square or any of the public streets of the city.
(2) Run or be in any way concerned in running any horse race in, along or across any public
square, street, road or alley in the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.066)
Secs. 2.04.007–2.04.040 Reserved
Division 2. Keeping Livestock
Sec. 2.04.041 Compliance; violations declared nuisance
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons to keep livestock within the city except in zones
established by the city council, and the keeping of livestock in a tract not zoned for livestock shall be deemed a
nuisance.
(b) It shall be a nuisance for any person to keep livestock within the city and not comply with the sanitary
requirements for keeping livestock as set out in this division.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.067(a))
Sec. 2.04.042 Enforcement
It shall be the duty of the city health department to enforce all health and sanitary measures contained in this
division. (1998 Code, sec. 63.067(b))
Sec. 2.04.043 Livestock zone permit
(a) Application. Any person desiring a tract to be designated “livestock zone” shall file a written application
with the city secretary for a permit, which application shall show the number and kind of each type of livestock
for which a permit is desired and shall affirmatively show that the tract has facilities for keeping such livestock
in quarters meeting the standards set by the health department of the city and/or by the Code of Ordinances of
the city, or, if such facilities are not on the tract at the time of the application, a description of what facilities will
be built before used as a livestock zone.
(b) Action by health department. The application will be delivered by the city secretary to the city health
department. The city health department will inspect the tract and facilities or proposed facilities and will make
recommendations as to the effect such zoning would have on the public health and public welfare and as to the
condition of the facilities on the tract. In the event facilities are to be built, the city health department will
inspect the site and plans and will report with recommendations as to how it would affect the public health and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 41/420
public welfare. The application, with recommendations, will be returned by the city health department to the city
secretary. The city secretary will put the application for zoning on the agenda for the meeting of the city council.
The city secretary will mail the applicant a notice of the hearing by the city council on his application.
(c) Action by city council. The city council will determine at a council meeting whether such application shall
or shall not be granted after taking into consideration what is in the best interest of the public health and general
welfare of the community and the recommendation of the city health department. The applicant may appear
before the city council at the time of the consideration of his application.
(d) Duration; renewal. A zoning permit issued under this division shall be valid and effective for twelve
months from the date of issuance unless sooner revoked. A new application must be made within each twelve
months therefor, at least a month before the expiration of the existing permit.
(e) Revocation. A zoning permit may be revoked by the city council for the reason that it is in the interest of
the public health and general welfare and/or that the holder has not complied with the standards set by the city
health department and/or this code. A notice of such hearing shall be furnished the holder of the zoning permit
by mail prior to the meeting considering said revocation.
(f) Assignment. A zoning permit may not be assigned by the holder.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.067(c))
Sec. 2.04.044 Proximity of pens to dwellings; minimum space; sanitary condition of pens
(a) Proximity of pens or stalls to dwellings. No pen, stall or other facility for keeping livestock as authorized
by a zoning permit issued under this division shall be so located as to allow the livestock confined therein to
come within one hundred (100) feet of the exterior limits of any dwelling other than the dwelling occupied by
the holder of the permit.
(b) Minimum space for horses, mules, etc. There shall be a minimum space for stable and lot of five hundred
(500) square feet for each horse, mule, jack and/or jennet. Each additional animal of such classification must be
given an additional five hundred (500) square feet of space.
(c) Minimum space for cows. There shall be a minimum space for shed and lot of five hundred (500) square
feet for each cow. Each additional cow that is kept on the same lot must be given an additional five hundred
(500) square feet.
(d) Minimum space for sheep, goats and hogs. There shall be a minimum of three hundred (300) square feet in
lot for each sheep, goat or hog that is kept.
(e) Sanitary condition of pens. Each pen in which livestock is kept shall be maintained in a sanitary condition,
free from offensive odors, flies, litter and waste water.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.067(d))
Sec. 2.04.045 Storage and removal of manure
(a) Each premises, unless otherwise provided by this division, where livestock is kept will be required to
provide an impervious (concrete) bin which will act as a storage place for all manure from such livestock. It
shall be covered with a cover approved by the city health department that will prevent the entrance or exit of
flies. It will also exclude any runoff or rainwater. The bin will be large enough to contain seven days' collection
of manure and will allow one cubic foot of manure per animal per day. The thickness of the walls of the bin shall
be a minimum of three inches. The lid shall be anchored by bolts and hinges.
(b) Any person, unless otherwise provided by this division, who maintains any livestock shall make daily
collections of manure, and the collections shall be placed in the bins built for this purpose.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 42/420
(c) It shall be the responsibility of anyone maintaining such manure bins as described above to remove the
manure from the bins each week in a sanitary manner as may be approved by the city health department. Each
day past one week that the manure is not removed shall constitute a separate offense under this division.
(d) Where a pasture is maintained for livestock, a manure bin will not be required provided that no livestock
may be kept in an area closer than five hundred (500) feet from the dwelling of any person other than the owner
of the livestock or the owner of the pasture; and providing that not more than one horse, or one cow, or one
mule, or one jack, or one jennet, or more than five sheep or goats, or more than five swine, may be contained in
an area comprising an acre of ground; and provided further that such pasture shall be so fenced so as to not allow
more than one horse, or one mule, or one jack, or one jennet, or one cow, to water and feed in one location, or
not more than five sheep or goats to water and feed in one location, or not more than five swine to water and
feed in one location; provided further that such pasture shall be kept clean and not have an accumulation of
manure that will attract flies or give an offensive odor.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.067(e))
Sec. 2.04.046 Grazing livestock on public property or property not zoned for livestock
It shall be unlawful for any person to stake any livestock for the purpose of grazing upon or within the reach of
any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or property not zoned for the livestock within the city limits. (1998 Code,
sec. 63.067(f))
Sec. 2.04.047 Cowbells or other noisy devices
It shall be unlawful for any person to attach or permit to be attached to any animal belonging to him, or in his
possession, any cowbell or loud-sounding, noisy, or disturbing implement within the limits of the city where
such noise would be disturbing to persons of ordinary sensibility. (1998 Code, sec. 63.067(g))
Sec. 2.04.048 Exceptions
(a) Existing auction barns and packing houses. The provisions of this division setting the space per animal
shall not be construed to prohibit any person who, at the time this division is passed, is engaged in operating an
auction barn or packing house from keeping livestock for a period not exceeding one week while awaiting their
use in the operation of such auction barn and packing house.
(b) Existing animal hospitals. The provisions setting the space per animal of this division shall not apply to
animal hospitals existing at the time this division is passed.
(c) County fair and grounds controlled by Rodeo Association. The provisions of this division shall not apply
to the area used by the county fair during show time and the grounds controlled by the Rodeo Association during
rodeos.
(d) Circus and carnivals. The provisions of this division shall not apply to a circus or carnival which has
obtained a permit for operation of same from the proper city authority.
(1998 Code, sec. 63.067(h))
CHAPTER 3
BUILDING REGULATIONS
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 43/420
ARTICLE 3.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 3.01.001 Building inspector
(a) Office created. There is hereby created the office of building inspector to be conducted under the
supervision of the city manager.
(b) Bond. The building inspector shall execute and deliver to the city secretary a surety bond in the amount of
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), payable to the city, conditioned upon his faithful performance of duties in
compliance with this section.
(1998 Code, sec. 32.001)
ARTICLE 3.02 BUILDING BOARD
Sec. 3.02.003 Established; membership
(a) Composition. There is hereby created a building board consisting of fourteen (14) members, any seven (7)
of which shall constitute a quorum. The board shall include the city manager, or any person duly designated by
him, who shall be chairman of the board, the building inspector, the chief electrical inspector of the city, two (2)
licensed and active master electricians, two (2) active journeyman electricians, two (2) licensed and active
master plumbers, two (2) journeyman plumbers, one (1) property owner who resides in the city, and two (2)
builders or persons engaged in the building or contracting business.
(b) Appointment and term of members. The building board shall be appointed by the city council and shall
hold office for two (2) years from the date of such appointment or until their successors have been appointed and
qualified.
(c) Compensation of members. All members shall serve on the building board without pay.
(1998 Code, sec. 32.002)
Sec. 3.02.004 Appeals
(a) Right of appeal; filing. Any person aggrieved by a decision or ruling of the building inspector shall have
the right to appeal to the building board for its review. Such appeal shall be perfected by a request in writing to
the city manager for a hearing in which the nature of the applicant's grievance is briefly described and his correct
name and address stated.
(b) Date for hearing; decision. The chairman of the board shall fix a date for said hearing within three (3)
days, at which time the board shall hear the testimony of all parties concerned and shall render a decision within
three (3) days after said hearing.
(c) Appeal to city council. If the appellant is then aggrieved by the decision of the board, appeal may be made
from the board's ruling to the city council, and such appeal shall be perfected by a letter addressed to the mayor
or the city manager. A member of the board shall have no vote on his own appeal before the board.
(1998 Code, sec. 32.003)

Division 2. Building Code*
Sec. 3.03.051 Adopted
(a) The International Building Code, 2012 edition, is hereby adopted as the building code for the city.
(Ordinance O-05-12, sec. 1, adopted 4/3/12)
(b) A copy of said code is incorporated herein as though set out completely in detail. (Ordinance adopting
Code)
Sec. 3.03.052 Penalty
The penalty for violation of the building code adopted in section 3.03.051 shall be as set forth in section
3.01.001 of this code. (1998 Code, sec. 32.012)
Sec. 3.03.053 Fees
(a) Payment. No permit as required by the building code shall be issued until the fee prescribed in this
division shall have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any,
due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure shall have been paid. (1998 Code, sec.
32.014)
(b) Construction permit fee. For a permit for the construction or alteration of a building or structure, the fee
shall be at the rate of $5.00 per thousand dollars of the estimated cost up to twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000.00); plus $2.50 per thousand dollars of the estimated cost in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars up
to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); plus $1.25 per thousand dollars of the estimated cost in excess
of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); but not less than $25.00 in case; provided that no fee shall be
required when the estimated cost does not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 1,
adopted 3/15/11)
(c) Building removal or moving permit fee. For a permit for the removal or moving of a building or structure
from one lot to another, the fee shall be $35.00 for each building or structure.
(d) Building demolition permit fee. For a permit for the demolition of a building or structure, the fee shall be
at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) for each building or structure.
(e) Adjustment of fee when work is abandoned or discontinued. In the case of abandonment or
discontinuance, the cost of work performed under a permit may be estimated, an adjustment of the fee made and
the portion of the fee for the uncompleted work returned to the permit holder, provided that no refund of a
prescribed minimum fee shall be made. If such discontinuance is due to revocation of permit, a similar
adjustment and return may be made, provided that no refund shall be made until all penalties incurred or
imposed by due authority shall have been collected. After such a refund has been made, no work shall be
resumed until a new application has been made and a new permit has been issued.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 45/420
(f) “Estimated cost” defined. The term “estimated cost,” as used in this section, means the reasonable value of
all the services, labor, materials, and use of scaffolding and other appliances or devices entering into and
necessary to the prosecution and completion of the work ready for occupancy; provided that the cost of
excavation or grading, and of painting, decorating or other work that is merely embellishment, or not necessary
for the safe and lawful use of the building or structure, is not deemed a part of such estimated cost.
(1998 Code, sec. 32.014)
(g) Work commencing prior to permit issuance. Any contractor, subcontractor, or property owner who
commences work on a building, structure, or electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system before obtaining the
necessary permits shall be subject to a penalty of 100% of the usual permit fee in addition to the required permit
fee as provided in subsection (b) of this section. Any emergency repair made after normal business hours shall
be permitted the next business day. (Ordinance O-14-12 adopted 12/18/12)
