ARTICLE 4.02 AMUSEMENT CENTERS†
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.02.001 Definitions
Billiards. Any game played on a table with balls and cue sticks where the balls are struck by the sticks and the
balls strike against one another.
Business establishment. Any business, club, or other organization operated for profit or nonprofit in or upon
which there is located any coin-operated amusement device as defined herein.
Class A amusement center. A business establishment in which at least four coin-operated amusement devices or
at least one billiard table is operated.
Class B amusement center. A business establishment with three or less coin-operated amusement devices.
Coin-operated amusement device. A machine or device operated by insertion of a coin, token or similar object,
for the purpose of amusement or skill. The term does not include musical devices or machines designed
exclusively for children.
Licensee. The person in whose name a license to operate an amusement center has been issued, as well as
individual(s) listed as applicant(s) on the application for an amusement center license.
Operator. A person who manages or controls an amusement center.
Person. An individual, partnership, company, corporation, firm, organization, institution or similar entity.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.001)
Sec. 4.02.002 Amusement devices and billiard tables not in licensed amusement center declared
nuisance
Every coin-operated amusement device and billiard table subject to the provisions of this article and not within a
licensed amusement center is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and may be seized and destroyed by the
chief of police and his agents, as provided by law for the seizure and destruction of common nuisances. (1998
Code, sec. 41.002)
Sec. 4.02.003 Appeals
With respect to class A amusement centers and class B amusement centers, any person who is denied a license
or whose license has been suspended or revoked pursuant to the provisions hereof shall have the right to appeal
the decision to the city council. Such appeal must be filed not later than ten (10) days from the date the license
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 108/420
application is denied or the license is suspended or revoked. No appeal shall be allowed after such ten (10) day
period. The city council shall hear the appeal at the first regular meeting after the appeal is filed and the decision
of the city council shall be final. (1998 Code, sec. 41.003)
Sec. 4.02.004 Due date for payment of license fees
The fees assessed pursuant to this article are annual fees and become due and payable on January 2nd of each
year. (1998 Code, sec. 41.004)
Secs. 4.02.005–4.02.030 Reserved
Division 2. Class A Amusement Centers
Part I. In General
Sec. 4.02.031 Hours of operation
(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) or (c) of this section, no licensee or his operator may operate the
amusement center between the hours of 12:01 a.m. to 9:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, and between the hours
of 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., Saturday and Sunday.
(b) If an amusement center is within five hundred feet (500') of a district restricted to residential use under the
zoning ordinance of the city, no licensee or his operator may operate the amusement center except between the
hours of 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., Sunday through Thursday, and between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00
midnight, Friday and Saturday. A variance to this subsection may be granted by the chief of police and must be
so noted upon the license. The variance may be withdrawn at any time for cause.
(c) If an amusement center is within five hundred feet (500') of a public or private elementary or secondary
school, no licensee or his operator may operate the amusement center between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00
p.m. during the fall or spring term when students are required to attend school in the school district in which the
center is located.
(d) For purposes of this article, measurements shall be made in a straight line without regard to intervening
structures or objects, from the nearest entry door in the portion of the building used as an amusement center to
the nearest point of a district restricted to residential use or nearest entry door of a school.
(e) If an amusement center's hours are restricted only by subsection (a) of this section, a licensee may obtain a
temporary permit to operate continuously. The chief of police shall issue a temporary permit for no longer than
thirty (30) days and only once a year.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.013)
Sec. 4.02.032 Responsibilities of licensee; prohibited activities
(a) A licensee or his operator may not permit any of the following activities within the amusement center:
(1) Violation of any possession, sale, or delivery provision of the Texas Controlled Substances Act;
(2) Violation of any provision of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code;
(3) Prostitution;
(4) Gambling; or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 109/420
(5) Entry of a person younger than 17 years between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. during
the fall or spring term when students are required to attend school in the school district in which the
center is located.
(b) A licensee or his operator may not permit any of the following activities on the premises of the amusement
center:
(1) Violation of section 42.01 of the Penal Code;
(2) Throwing or depositing litter in or upon the sidewalk or adjacent streets or properties; or
(3) Any of the activities listed in subsections (a)(1) through (4) above.
(c) In subsection (b) of this section, “premises” means an area, other than the interior of an amusement center,
to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and which is under the control of an owner or
operator of an amusement center, such as a parking facility or private sidewalk.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.014)
Sec. 4.02.033 Inspection
Representatives of the health department, fire department, police department, and building inspector may inspect
the premises of an amusement center for the purpose of insuring compliance with the law at any time it is open
for business. (1998 Code, sec. 41.015)
Secs. 4.02.034–4.02.060 Reserved
Part II. License
Sec. 4.02.061 Required
(a) An application for a license must be made on a form provided by the city. The applicant must be qualified
according to the provisions of this article and his premises must be inspected and found to be in compliance with
the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state regarding public establishments, by the health department,
fire department and building inspector.
(b) If a person who wishes to operate an amusement center is an individual he must sign the application for a
license as applicant. If a person who wishes to operate an amusement center is other than an individual, each
individual who has a twenty percent (20%) or greater interest in the business must sign the application for a
license as applicant. Each applicant must meet the requirements of section 4.02.063 and each applicant shall be
considered a licensee if a license is granted.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.005)
Sec. 4.02.062 Application
(a) An applicant for a license shall file with the chief of police a written application on a form provided for
that purpose, which shall be signed by the applicant, who shall be the owner of the amusement center. Should an
applicant maintain an amusement center at more than one location, a separate application must be filed for each
location. The following information is required in the application:
(1) Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant including the trade name by which the
applicant does business and the street address of the amusement center, and, if incorporated, the name
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 110/420
registered with the secretary of state;
(2) Name, address, and telephone number of the operator of the amusement center and proof that
the operator is at least eighteen (18) years of age;
(3) Whether the applicant, operator, and, if applicable, any corporate officer of the applicant,
within the preceding five (5) years, has been convicted of a felony or of an offense involving drugs,
gambling, prostitution, obscenity, or unlawfully carrying a weapon;
(4) The occupation of the applicant, operator, and, if applicable, all corporate officers of the
applicant for the preceding five (5) years;
(5) Whether a previous license of the applicant, or, if applicable, corporate officer of the applicant,
has been revoked within two (2) years of filing of the application;
(6) A statement that all the facts contained in the application are true.
(b) The chief of police may require additional information of any applicant for a license to clarify items on the
application.
(c) No applicant may maintain an amusement center in violation of the comprehensive zoning ordinance of
the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.006)
Sec. 4.02.063 Issuance
(a) The chief of police shall approve the issuance of a license to an applicant within thirty (30) days after
receipt of an application unless he finds one or more of the following to be true:
(1) An applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age.
(2) An applicant or an applicant's spouse is not of good moral character, and his reputation for
being peaceable and law-abiding in the community where he resides or does business is bad.
(3) An applicant or an applicant's spouse is overdue in his payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines,
or penalties or any other obligation assessed against him or imposed upon him.
(4) An applicant uses alcoholic beverages to excess.
(5) An applicant is physically or mentally incapacitated to an extent that he cannot operate an
amusement center.
(6) An applicant has failed to answer or has falsely answered a question or request for information
on the application form provided.
(7) An applicant or an applicant's spouse has been convicted of a violation of a provision of this
article within two years immediately preceding the filing of the application. The fact that a conviction
is being appealed shall have no effect.
(8) An applicant is residing with a person who has been denied a license by the city to operate an
amusement center within the preceding 12 months, or residing with a person whose license to operate
an amusement center has been revoked within the preceding 12 months, or residing with a person
who does not meet the qualifications of this section.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 111/420
(9) An applicant's premises have not been approved by the health department, the fire department,
or the building inspector.
(10) The license fee required by this article has not been paid.
(11) An applicant or an applicant's spouse has been convicted of:
(A) A felony; or
(B) A misdemeanor involving an offense of:
(i) Prostitution;
(ii) Promotion of prostitution;
(iii) Public lewdness;
(iv) Gambling;
(v) Violation of the Texas Controlled Substances and Dangerous Drugs Act, or the
Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code; or
(vi) Unlawfully carrying a weapon;
and five (5) years have not elapsed since the termination of any sentence, parole, or
probation. The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect.
(12) An applicant has been employed in an amusement center managerial capacity within the
preceding 12 months and has demonstrated that he is unable to operate or manage amusement center
premises in a peaceful and law-abiding manner.
(b) When the conditions of this division have been complied with, an amusement center license shall be issued
by the city secretary and approved by the chief of police.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.007)
Sec. 4.02.064 Fee
The annual fee for a class A amusement center license is $100.00. The fee for issuing a replacement license for
one lost, destroyed, or mutilated is $2.00. The fees assessed hereunder are payable to the city secretary upon
approval of the license by the chief of police. No refund of fees will be made. New licenses issued after the first
day of October may be for a term not to exceed fifteen (15) months for a fee of $125.00. (1998 Code, sec.
41.008)
Sec. 4.02.065 Display; replacement; transfer
(a) Each license issued pursuant to this division must be posted and kept in a conspicuous place in an
amusement center and must state the number of coin-operated amusement devices and billiard tables for which
the license was issued.
(b) A replacement license may be issued for one lost, destroyed, or mutilated, upon application to the chief of
police and upon payment of the prescribed fee.
(c) An amusement center license is not assignable or transferable.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 112/420
(d) A licensee shall notify the chief of police within 10 days of a change or partial change in the ownership or
management of the amusement center, or a change of address or trade name.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.009)
Sec. 4.02.066 Expiration and renewal
(a) Each license shall expire on the first day of January each year and may be renewed only by making
application as provided for an original application. A renewal application must be made at least 30 days before
the expiration date, and the center may not operate without a valid existing license.
(b) When the chief of police denies renewal of a license, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one
year from the date of denial unless the chief of police finds that the basis for denial of a renewal license has been
corrected or abated, in which case the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since
the date denial became effective.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.010)
Sec. 4.02.067 Suspension
The chief of police shall suspend a license for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days if he determines that a
licensee or an employee of a licensee has:
(1) Engaged in excessive use of alcoholic beverages while on the amusement center premises;
(2) Refused to allow an inspection of the amusement center premises as authorized by section
4.02.033 of this article;
(3) Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the amusement center premises;
(4) Knowingly permitted an intoxicated person to remain on the premises; or
(5) Demonstrated inability to operate or manage an amusement center premises in a peaceful and
law-abiding manner.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.011)
Sec. 4.02.068 Revocation
(a) The chief of police shall revoke an amusement center license for one or more of the following reasons:
(1) A false statement as to a material matter made in an application for a license, a license renewal
or a hearing concerning the license;
(2) Conviction of the licensee, his operator, or corporate officer of the licensee of:
(A) A felony; or
(B) A misdemeanor involving an offense of:
(i) Prostitution;
(ii) Promotion of prostitution;
(iii) Public lewdness;
(iv) Gambling;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 113/420
(v) Violation of the Texas Controlled Substances and Dangerous Drug Act, or Texas
Alcoholic Beverage Code;
(vi) Unlawfully carrying a weapon;
and five (5) years have not elapsed since the termination of any sentence, parole, or
probation. The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect;
(3) A licensee or an employee is unable to operate the amusement center because of physical or
mental impairment;
(4) A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled
substances or illegal alcoholic beverages on the premises;
(5) A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises;
(6) Two or more violations within a one (1) year period by the operator of the hours of operation
provisions of this division;
(7) Employment by the licensee of an operator who is under 18 years of age; or
(8) Violation by the licensee or his operator of section 4.02.065(a) of this article.
(b) The chief of police shall send written notice of revocation to a licensee by certified mail, return receipt
requested, setting forth the reasons for the revocation.
(c) When the chief of police revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for one (1) year and the licensee
shall not be issued an amusement center license for one year from the date revocation became final. If,
subsequent to revocation, the chief of police finds that the basis for the revocation action has been corrected or
abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation
became final. If the license was revoked under subsection (a)(6) of this section, the applicant may not be granted
another license.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.012)
Secs. 4.02.069–4.02.100 Reserved
Division 3. Class B Amusement Centers
Part I. In General
Sec. 4.02.101 Responsibilities of licensee; prohibited activities
A license may not permit any of the following activities within the amusement center:
(1) Violation of any possession, sale, or delivery provision of the Texas Controlled Substances Act;
(2) Violation of any provision of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code;
(3) Prostitution;
(4) Gambling; or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 114/420
(5) The operation of any licensed coin-operated amusement device in the amusement center by a
person younger than 17 years between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. during the fall or spring
term when students are required to attend school in the school district in which the center is located.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.021)
Secs. 4.02.102–4.02.130 Reserved
Part II. License
Sec. 4.02.131 Required
(a) No person may operate a class B amusement center within the city limits without first obtaining a license
from the city.
(b) An application for a license must be made on a form to be provided by the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.016)
Sec. 4.02.132 Application
(a) An applicant for a class B license shall file with the city secretary a written application on a form provided
for that purpose, which shall be signed by the applicant, who shall be the owner or operator of the amusement
center. The following information is required in the application:
(1) Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant;
(2) Trade name, address, and telephone number of the amusement center.
(b) No applicant may maintain an amusement center in violation of the comprehensive zoning ordinance of
the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.17)
Sec. 4.02.133 Issuance
The city secretary shall issue a license to an applicant upon receipt of an application and the payment of the
license fee required by this article. (1998 Code, sec. 41.018)
Sec. 4.02.134 Fee
The annual fee for a class B amusement center is $25.00. The fee for issuing a replacement license for one lost,
destroyed, or mutilated is $2.00. The fee is payable to the city secretary upon receipt of the application. No
refund of license fees will be made. (1998 Code, sec. 41.019)
Sec. 4.02.135 Display; expiration
(a) Each license issued pursuant to this division must be posted and kept in a conspicuous place in the
amusement center and must state the number of coin-operated amusement devices for which the license was
issued.
(b) Each license shall expire one year from the date of issuance.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.020)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 115/420
Sec. 4.02.136 Suspension or revocation
(a) The chief of police shall suspend a license for a period not exceeding 30 days if he determines that a
licensee or an employee of a licensee has permitted any of the activities not permitted in section 4.02.101.
(b) The chief of police shall suspend a license for a period of at least three months and not more than six
months for any subsequent violations outlined in section 4.02.101.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.022)
ARTICLE 4.03 DANCES AND DANCE HALLS
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.03.001 Definitions
As used in this article:
Public dance. Any dance or ball to which admission can be had by payment of a fee, or by the purchase,
possession or presentation of a ticket or token, or at which a charge is made for caring for clothing or other
property, or any other dance to which the public generally may gain admission, with or without the payment of a
fee.
Public dance hall. Any room, place or space, open or enclosed, in which a public dance or public ball is held, or
any room, place or space where dancing is permitted.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.031)
Sec. 4.03.002 Review of license and permit applications by chief of police
The chief of police shall examine all applications for dance hall licenses and dance permits and make
recommendations with reference to applications for dance hall licenses and dance permits. (1998 Code, sec.
41.032)
Sec. 4.03.003 Transfer of license or permit
No license or permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferred. (1998 Code, sec. 41.033)
Sec. 4.03.004 Enforcement
The chief of police, or other persons under his direction, shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this
article and all rules, regulations and ordinances relating to public dances and public dance halls. In making
determinations as to proper cleanliness and sanitation conditions, fire safety requirements, building regulations,
uses and requirements, etc., the chief of police or other persons under his direction shall work with and seek the
aid of the proper city department administering such regulations for the city. (1998 Code, sec. 41.034)
Sec. 4.03.005 Remedies cumulative
Any remedy prescribed by this article for the enforcement of the same shall be nonexclusive and shall not
preclude resort to any other remedy provided by law. (1998 Code, sec. 41.035)
Secs. 4.03.006–4.03.030 Reserved
Division 2. Dance Halls
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 116/420
Part I. In General
Sec. 4.03.031 Maintenance of premises
All public dance halls shall be kept at all times in a clean, healthful and sanitary condition and all rooms
connected thereto shall be kept open and the entire place shall be well lighted. (1998 Code, sec. 41.044)
Sec. 4.03.032 Authority to vacate premises
The chief of police, or other persons under his direction, shall have the power, and it shall be his duty, to cause
any place, hall or room where any public dance is held or given to be vacated whenever any provision of this
article is being violated or whenever any indecent act is committed, or when any disorder of a gross, violent or
vulgar character shall take place therein. (1998 Code, sec. 41.046)
Secs. 4.03.033–4.03.060 Reserved
Part II. License
Sec. 4.03.061 Required
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to hold or conduct any public dance within the city unless the dance
hall in which the same is held is licensed for such purpose.
(b) It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to dance at any public dance hall that is not duly licensed, and
any person engaging in a dance or dancing at an unlicensed public dance shall be deemed guilty of disorderly
conduct and a misdemeanor. The owner, proprietor, manager, or person in charge of any unlicensed public dance
hall who permits or condones any person to engage in a dance shall also be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.036)
Sec. 4.03.062 Application
Any person desiring a license to operate a public dance hall shall file with the building inspector an application
for such license on a form furnished by the city, giving the information requested thereon, and it shall be
unlawful for an applicant to misrepresent any fact or make any false statement in such application, and any such
misrepresentation shall, in addition to the other penalties prescribed by law, be sufficient cause for denial,
suspension or revocation of the license. (1998 Code, sec. 41.037)
Sec. 4.03.063 Inspection of premises
No dance hall license shall be granted unless it shall appear, upon inspection and investigation by the chief of
police, the health officer, the fire marshal and the building inspector, that the premises desired to be used for the
purpose of conducting a dance hall comply with the laws of the state, the provisions of this article, the
ordinances of the city regulating zoning, health and sanitation, the fire regulations and the building code, and
that the proposed dance hall is properly ventilated and supplied with sufficient toilet conveniences, and is a safe
and proper place for the purpose for which it is used, as determined by regulations adopted by the city. The
officers named herein shall, in their respective capacities, note their approval or disapproval upon the application
for the license. (1998 Code, sec. 41.038)
Sec. 4.03.064 Fee
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 117/420
An annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged for each dance hall license, which fee shall be
paid prior to issuance of the license. (1998 Code, sec. 41.039)
Sec. 4.03.065 Issuance or denial
When the conditions of this article have been complied with, a dance hall license shall be issued by the city
secretary and certified to and approved by the chief of police. No such license shall be effective until it has been
so approved. In the event the chief of police refuses to approve a license, such action shall be final unless the
applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal, file a written appeal with the city secretary, addressed to
the city council, requesting a hearing by the council upon the question as to whether or not his application shall
be granted. In the event such appeal is filed, the chief of police shall provide the council with a record of all
proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application in question, including the written application,
together with the action of the chief of police and the reasons for such action. The city council shall, within
thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the chief of police, at which
hearing the council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether or not all the pertinent facts appear in
the application. It shall be discretionary with the city council as to whether or not the license shall be granted and
such action as the council may take thereon shall be final and conclusive. (1998 Code, sec. 41.040)
Sec. 4.03.066 Contents; posting
A dance hall license issued under this article shall state on its face to whom it is issued, the date of expiration,
and the address and location of such dance hall, and shall be signed by the city secretary and posted by the
licensee in a conspicuous place and in such a manner and position that it may be easily read at any time of the
day or night. (1998 Code, sec. 41.041)
Sec. 4.03.067 Expiration
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall terminate one (1) year from the date of such
issuance. (1998 Code, sec. 41.042)
Sec. 4.03.068 Suspension or revocation
(a) The granting of any dance hall license shall in no event be construed as the granting or conferring of any
vested right to the licensee or operator, but such license shall be subject to revocation or suspension as provided
for in this section.
(b) If a dance hall licensed under the provisions of this article is not being conducted in accordance with the
laws of the state or this code, or is being conducted in violation of the laws of the state or this code, the chief of
police may at any time give notice in writing to the operator, licensee, manager or other person in control of the
operation and maintenance of such dance hall that the license issued for the operation and maintenance of such
dance hall has been revoked or suspended. The notice of revocation or suspension shall become a final
revocation or suspension after the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of the service of same upon the
operator, licensee, manager or other person in charge, unless, on or before the expiration of such ten (10) days,
the licensee, operator, manager or other person in charge shall file with the city secretary a written appeal
addressed to the city council in which it is requested that the council grant him a hearing upon the question
whether or not the license shall be revoked or suspended. Such appeal, if made and filed as prescribed in this
section, shall operate as a stay or postponement of the revocation or suspension of the license until such time as
the city council shall grant a hearing and make a final adjudication. Such hearing shall be held within thirty (30)
days after the date of the filing of such appeal, and such action and judgment of the council, after hearing all the
evidence and facts, shall be final and conclusive.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.043)
Secs. 4.03.069–4.03.100 Reserved
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 118/420
Division 3. Dance Permit
Sec. 4.03.101 Required
In addition to the public dance hall license required herein, there shall be required a public dance permit, and no
person shall hold a public dance until a permit is issued therefor by the chief of police. (1998 Code, sec. 41.047)
Sec. 4.03.102 Application
Application for a public dance permit shall be made upon a form furnished by the city and shall be filed with the
chief of police at least forty-eight (48) hours before the dance is to begin. (1998 Code, sec. 41.048)
Sec. 4.03.103 Issuance
A public dance permit shall be issued by the chief of police when all the provisions of this article and other
ordinances in reference thereto are complied with. (1998 Code, sec. 41.049)
Sec. 4.03.104 Revocation or suspension
The chief of police may revoke or suspend any dance permit at any time when the provisions of this article are
being violated. (1998 Code, sec. 41.050)
ARTICLE 4.04 CARNIVALS, CIRCUSES, MEDICINE SHOWS,
AMUSEMENT RIDES AND TENT SHOWS*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.04.001 Policing; authority to revoke permit or order closure
(a) The chief of police or his designee shall have supervision of the policing of carnivals, circuses, medicine
shows, amusement riding devices and/or tent shows.
(b) Should the carnival or circus be issued a permit and conduct itself, or should any permittee's agents,
servants or employees conduct themselves, in any unlawful manner, the chief of police may revoke the permit,
and the fees be forfeited, upon notice to the applicant and after an opportunity for hearing concerning such
activity.
(c) In the event any activity of the applicant or the applicant's agents, servants or employees constitutes a
violation of the penal laws of the city or of the state, and such activity endangers the life, health, safety, morals
or general welfare of the public, the chief of police shall have authority to order the carnival or circus closed
immediately, but shall concurrently therewith advise the permit holder of such violation and give such holder an
opportunity for hearing to explain or correct such activity.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.065)
Secs. 4.04.002–4.04.030 Reserved
Division 2. Permit
Sec. 4.04.031 Required
(a) It shall be unlawful to hereafter hold, sponsor or run a carnival, circus, medicine show, amusement riding
device and/or tent show within the city unless a permit to hold such enterprise is obtained in accordance with
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 119/420
this article. This section shall not apply to shows or exhibitions held in established theaters, auditoriums or other
permanent buildings in this city.
(b) A permit issued under this section shall cover one appearance in the city and shall be valid only for as
many days as the carnival or circus remains continuously in the city, and a new permit shall be required each
time the carnival or circus returns to the city.
(c) The term “carnival” shall apply to any show offering amusement rides or devices for public use.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.061)
Sec. 4.04.032 Application; approval
A permit shall be issued by the city secretary to hold such carnival, circus, medicine show, amusement riding
device and/or tent show when and only when a proper application in writing is submitted to him. Such
application shall include:
(1) The names, addresses and telephone numbers of all persons applying for such a permit,
including the name, residence address, telephone number, and driver's license number of the manager
or other individual to be principally in charge of the operation of the carnival or circus;
(2) The exact location where it is to be operated;
(3) The component parts of the enterprise, including:
(A) All concessions, shows, amusements, rides and other businesses;
(B) A description of the toilet facilities to be provided; and
(C) A description of the security to be provided;
(4) The dates and the hours during which such activity is to be kept open to the public;
(5) The names and addresses of local persons connected therewith;
(6) A copy of the current state or federal license issued to the circus or carnival under the
provisions of chapter 824 of the Health and Safety Code of the state or the federal Animal Welfare
Act;
(7) Certificates of insurance in an amount not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) for bodily injuries, including accidental death, per occurrence, and one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage;
(8) A description of the security services to be provided during the hours of operation to insure the
safety of the people attending and in surrounding property;
(9) Proof that the operator is in compliance with all applicable provisions of the Amusement Ride
Safety Inspection and Insurance Act of the state (section 21.60, Insurance Code). A copy of the
current affidavit required by section 5 of that act shall be deemed sufficient;
(10) The applicant's state sales and use tax permit number and a copy of the applicant's state sales
and use tax permit; and
(11) A signed approval by the chief of police or his designee.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.062)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 120/420
Sec. 4.04.033 Fee
The fee for a permit issued under this article shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). (1998 Code, sec. 41.063)
Sec. 4.04.034 Denial
(a) The chief of police may deny a circus or carnival a permit to operate upon a finding of any of the
following:
(1) The application contains false or misleading information or required information is omitted;
(2) The location selected for the circus or carnival is inadequate for the purposes for which it is to
be used;
(3) The circus or carnival does not have adequate toilet facilities on the premises where the circus
or carnival is to be held;
(4) The circus or carnival has not provided for adequate security services in order to protect the
persons in attendance and in surrounding property;
(5) The description of the circus or carnival does not assure that minimum standards of sanitation,
health or safety will be provided, or that the circus or carnival will be conducted in an orderly
fashion;
(6) No proof of liability insurance policy has been provided; or
(7) The failure to provide any other certificate, license or permit required by this article.
(b) If a circus or carnival permit is denied, the chief of police shall give a statement in writing giving the
reasons for denial.
(1998 Code, sec. 41.064)
ARTICLE 4.05 ITINERANT BUSINESSES*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.05.001 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following words and terms have the meanings ascribed to them by this
section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:
Agents and employees. Any person who represents and acts for another person who is licensed and authorized to
transact business in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler.
Agriculture products. Fruits, vegetables, or other foodstuffs grown by the seller.
Bill. A written or printed advertisement posted or otherwise distributed to announce an event of interest to the
public.
Canvasser. Means the same as “solicitor.”
Charitable purpose. The use of money or property for the benefit of:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 121/420
(1) Charity or philanthropy, or poor, impoverished, destitute, underprivileged, needy, refugee,
diseased, injured, crippled, disabled, or handicapped persons, or persons in need of rehabilitation;
(2) Patriotism, that is, for the teaching of patriotism or the relief or assistance of veterans or
veterans' organizations;
(3) Existing educational institutions or for the establishment or endowment of educational
institutions or in aid of the education of a group of persons; or
(4) Any chartered fraternal or social organization.
Charitable solicitation. Conduct whereby a person, organization, society, corporation, or its agent, member, or
representative:
(1) Solicits property, financial aid, gifts in money, or any article representing monetary value, for a
charitable purpose;
(2) Sells or offers to sell a product, article, tag, service, publication, ticket, advertisement, or
subscription, for a charitable purpose; or
(3) Holds, promotes, or participates in an entertainment, sports event, benefit dance, fair, bazaar, or
other type of organized social entertainment, on the plea or representation, whether express or
implied, that the proceeds from the solicitation, sale, or entertainment are for a charitable purpose.
Chief of police. The chief of police of the city.
Circular. Has the same meaning as “handbill.”
City attorney. The city attorney or legal counsel of the city.
Civic organization. An organization within the city in which citizens cooperate to promote the common good
and general welfare of the people of the city.
Commercial traveler. A person who is employed by or who represents a manufacturer, wholesaler, or importer
who sells or exhibits goods to parties who engage in the business of purchasing such goods for the purpose of
resale to the general public.
Flea market. A market or place of business designated for the sale of secondhand merchandise or antiques, at
which persons rent or otherwise obtain a booth, cubicle, or space on a short-term basis for the exhibit and sale of
such merchandise.
Garage sale. An occasional sale, as defined in this article.
Goods. Tangible chattels of every kind and character.
Handbill. A written or printed notice displayed, handed out, or posted, to inform those concerned of something
to be done or some event or some goods offered for sale.
Hawker. Has the same meaning as “peddler.”
Interstate commerce. The soliciting or taking orders for or offering to take orders for goods which, at the time
the order is taken, are in another state or will be produced in another state and shipped or introduced into this
city in the fulfillment of such orders and are not subject to the sales and use tax of the state.
Itinerant. Traveling from place to place as applied to a person engaged in transient businesses either in one
locality or in traveling from one locality to another.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 122/420
Itinerant trader. Any such business transacted or conducted in the city upon, through or from any private
premises or space upon any private property for which no definite arrangement for the legal right of occupancy
thereof for the purpose of conducting such business therein or thereon for a period of at least one month has
been made; or any such business not having a building, room, structure or enclosure within the city. Said
definition shall include any such business as may be operated or conducted by any person or his agents or
employees who resides or is domiciled away from the city, or who has a fixed place of business or business
headquarters outside the city, or who moves stocks of goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property or
samples thereof into the city with the purpose of or intention of removing them or the unused portion thereof
from the city before the expiration of one month.
License. A license or permit issued by the city granting permission to a person, firm, or corporation to pursue the
occupation of a solicitor, peddler, or itinerant trader subject to the regulation of the city under the police power,
which without said license would be illegal. Said license is not a contract between the city and the licensee, but
is a mere personal permit and is neither property nor a property right.
Occasional sales. One or two sales of taxable items at retail during any twelve-month period by a person who
does not hold himself out as engaging (or does not habitually engage) in the business of selling taxable items at
retail, to include such sales described by the seller as a “garage sale.”
Peddler. All persons, as well as their agents and employees, who engage in business in the city, by selling or
offering for sale, in person, any goods or merchandise, and who carry goods or merchandise upon or from a
truck or other vehicle, on the streets of the city, or who go from door to door of residences, offices or places of
business to display, exhibit, sell or offer for sale such goods or merchandise. Said definition shall include all
sales of goods or services for which payment is made upon the immediate delivery of the goods or completion of
said services.
Permit. Has the same meaning as “license.”
Person. An individual natural person, whether residing within or without the city limits, and does not include
any corporation, firm, association, partnership or joint venture.
Poster. A bill or placard for posting in a public place.
Prepared food. Any cooked or otherwise prepared foodstuffs, such as snow cones, tamales, candy, cakes or
cookies.
Public place. Any property open or devoted to public use.
Raw food. Any uncooked or otherwise; [sic] fruit, vegetable, fish, grains, or other foodstuffs.
Religious purpose. The use of money or property for the support of a church, religious society, or other religious
sect, group, or order.
Religious solicitation. Conduct whereby a person, organization, society, corporation, or its agent, member, or
representative:
(1) Solicits property, financial aid, gifts in money, or any article representing monetary value, for a
religious purpose; or
(2) Sells or offers to sell a product, article, tag, service, or printed material, on the plea or
representation, whether express or implied, that the proceeds from the solicitation or sale are for a
religious purpose.
Solicitor. All persons, as well as their agents and employees, who engage in business in the city by selling or
offering for sale, in person, any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting the same for sale, or exhibiting the same
through brochures as well as literature, or price list, for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof for
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 123/420
future delivery or for services to be furnished immediately or performed in the future, and who for the purpose
of carrying on such business conducts such business upon or from a truck or other vehicle, on the streets of the
city, or who goes from door to door of residences, offices or places of business to display, exhibit, sell or offer
for sale such goods or merchandise for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future
delivery. Such definition shall include all sales that require an immediate payment conditional upon future
delivery of goods or services.
Street vendor. Means the same as “peddler.”
Telephone solicitation. A telephone call to or from a person, initiated by a seller, salesperson, automatic dialing
machine, or recorded message device for the purpose of inducing the person to purchase, rent, claim, or receive
an item, and includes a call made by a purchaser in response to a solicitation sent by mail or made by any other
means.
Temporary or transient business. Any business conducted by an itinerant trader as defined under the provisions
of this article.
Trader. A person who has goods for sale and sells them in a fixed place of business.
Zoning district. A section of the city for which the regulations governing land uses are uniform. For the purposes
of this article, R-1, R-2, and R-3 districts shall be referred to as residential districts and C-1, I-1, and I-2 districts
shall be referred to as retail and industrial districts as outlined in the zoning ordinance.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.016)
Sec. 4.05.002 Scope
This article covers all aspects of the regulation of persons engaging in the itinerant business of a solicitor,
peddler or trader and the distribution of handbills, circulars, posters and similar advertising under the authority
of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 43.001)
Sec. 4.05.003 Applicability of article
The provisions of this article shall apply to all territory within the corporate limits of the city and to any and all
territory subsequently annexed into said corporate limits, and shall apply to any individual, corporation,
organization, business trust, partnership or association involved in such activities as may be regulated by this
article. For the purposes of this article, any person shall be deemed to be in business and thus subject to the
requirements of this article when he or she does one act of selling or soliciting any goods or services as
described in this article. (1998 Code, sec. 43.002)
Sec. 4.05.004 Applicability of Home Solicitation Act
The provisions of the Texas Home Solicitation Act (Texas Business and Commerce Code, ch. 39) shall apply to
any individual, corporation, organization, business trust, partnership or association involved in such activities as
may be regulated by this article, and any violation of said statute shall be deemed a violation of this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.003)
Sec. 4.05.005 Violations; penalty
Any person, firm or individual who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article, or
failing to perform any act which this article imposes a duty to perform, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
upon conviction thereof shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each and
every sale or act of solicitation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall result in the automatic
revocation of such convicted person's license. (1998 Code, sec. 43.004)
Sec. 4.05.006 Provisions of article deemed incorporated in license
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 124/420
All of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be incorporated in every license issued by the city under
the provisions of this article, and each person issued a license shall be charged with knowledge of the provisions
of this article and, by applying and/or accepting said license, to have assented to the provisions hereof. (1998
Code, sec. 43.005)
Sec. 4.05.007 Enforcement
The police department of the city shall enforce this article and it shall be the duty of the police officers of the
city to require any person seen soliciting, canvassing, peddling, or set up as a trader without a fixed place of
business, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce such license and to enforce the
provisions of this article against any person found to be in violation of same. (1998 Code, sec. 43.006)
Sec. 4.05.008 Exemption for persons engaged in interstate commerce
Any person may apply to the city secretary for a partial exemption to the provisions of this article and such
partial exemption may be granted if it is found that the person conducting solicitations, as defined in this article,
is engaged in interstate commerce as that term is herein defined; provided, however:
(1) It shall be unlawful for persons engaged in interstate commerce to go from house to house or
place to place in the city without completing an application for and obtaining a solicitor's license with
said exemption;
(2) Said persons shall be exempt from all fees, except for a ten dollar ($10.00) registration fee, and
bonding requirements as provided in this article;
(3) The applicant is charged with the burden of proof to gain benefit of said partial exemption and
it must be shown that said goods are irretrievably committed to interstate commerce under usual and
appropriate documents, and the city attorney is entitled to receive more proof than affidavits and oral
testimony from said applicant to establish that said goods are moved in interstate commerce and
entitled to said partial exemption; and
(4) If said goods are subject to collection of the sales and use tax of the state they are deemed not
to be in interstate commerce.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.007; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 4.05.009 Loud noises and speaking devices
No solicitor, peddler, or itinerant trader, nor any person acting on his behalf, shall shout, make any cry out, blow
a horn or use any sound device where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be capable
of producing a sound that is unreasonably loud, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of
audibility. This shall include the use of any loud-speaking radio or sound-amplifying system upon any of the
streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city. In the event that
citizen complaints are received by the city from persons within the privacy of their homes, the police department
shall take the name and address of such complaining persons and shall advise the license holder to reduce the
volume of the loudspeaker or device. The receipt of two (2) or more complaints from reasonable persons within
seven (7) days shall be sufficient reason for suspension or revocation of any license or permit issued under the
provisions of this article. (1998 Code, sec. 43.008)
Sec. 4.05.010 Use of streets
(a) Manner of use. No solicitor, peddler, or itinerant trader shall have any exclusive right to any location in the
public streets, nor shall any solicitor, peddler, or itinerant trader be permitted a stationary location, nor shall he
be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 125/420
For the purpose of this section, the judgment of the police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed
conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced.
(b) Sale of goods from vehicle. Any person engaged in the selling of goods from a vehicle upon the streets of
the city, in addition to a license as required by this article, shall:
(1) Have a valid Texas vehicle registration and inspection sticker for the vehicle;
(2) Have a valid Texas motor vehicle operator's license for the type of vehicle being operated; and
(3) Have proof of liability insurance for the vehicle being operated.
(c) Operation of vehicles. Any person engaging in the selling of goods from a vehicle upon the streets of the
city shall:
(1) Operate such vehicle in accordance with the traffic regulations of the city and state;
(2) Equip such vehicle with the necessary warning and safety devices as required by state law; and
(3) Operate such vehicle in accordance with the noise regulations of section 4.05.009 of this
article.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.009)
Sec. 4.05.011 Operation at public park, swimming pool area, or other city-owned property
It shall be unlawful for any person to offer or exhibit for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or other
commodities on or at any public park or swimming pool area or upon any other property owned by the city, or to
go on or into or remain on any public park, swimming pool area of the city or other property owned by the city
for the purpose of selling goods, wares, merchandise or any other commodity, or to use any street, alley or other
public property abutting or adjacent to any public park, swimming pool or other property owned by the city for
the purpose of making such sales to persons in a public park or swimming pool area or other property owned by
the city, unless such person has previously applied to the city council for a permit to do so. Provided, however,
that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person or his employee duly operating under a
concession contract between such concessionaire and the city, or at events sponsored by a civic organization
within the city and approved by the city council or city manager. (1998 Code, sec. 43.010)
Sec. 4.05.012 Charitable and religious solicitations
(a) Identification. A person who engages in a charitable or religious solicitation in a public place shall identify
themselves by one of the following means:
(1) Wear and conspicuously display an easily readable identification badge identifying the name of
the soliciting organization and containing the statement “religious solicitation” or “charitable
solicitation”; or
(2) Verbally identify themselves to the persons being solicited by stating the they are engaged in a
charitable or religious solicitation and stating the name of the soliciting organization.
(b) Proof of compliance. A person engaged in charitable or religious solicitation in a public place may be
required to show proof that such solicitation is in accordance with the provisions of this article.
(c) Prohibited conduct. A person engaged in charitable or religious solicitation in a public place shall not:
(1) Obstruct or impede the passage of a pedestrian or a vehicle;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 126/420
(2) Make physical contact with the person being solicited unless the person's permission is
obtained;
(3) Misrepresent the charitable or religious purpose of the solicitation; or
(4) Misrepresent the charitable or religious affiliation or those engaged in the solicitation.
(d) Solicitations on church property. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to any solicitations
made on property owned by any religious organization within the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.011)
Sec. 4.05.013 Other permits
(a) If state statute requires that sales and use tax must be paid upon the purchases of such goods as a person
proposes to offer for sale under the provisions of this article, said person shall hold a valid sales tax permit
issued by the office of the comptroller of public accounts of the state.
(b) If any state or federal statute requires that a person possess a permit for the sale of such goods as a person
proposes to offer for sale under the provisions of this article, said person shall hold said permit before applying
for a permit from the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.013)
Sec. 4.05.014 Food sanitation standards
Each person who proposes to sell or offer for sale, under the provisions of this article, goods consisting of any
raw, cooked, prepared or processed edible substance, ice, beverage, or ingredient used or intended for use or for
sale in whole or in part for human consumption shall secure, on a form to be provided, the signature of the health
officer or sanitarian of the city indicating that such goods meet minimum food sanitation standards of the city
and state. Such approval may be revoked upon inspection by the health officer or sanitarian of the city. This
section shall not apply to a person who sells only non-refrigerated food items packaged and sealed in individual
servings, such as candies and similar confectioneries. (1998 Code, sec. 43.014)
Sec. 4.05.015 Agents and employees
(a) Registration and fee. Any person obtaining a license under the provisions of this article to engage in the
occupation of a solicitor or peddler as defined in this article shall register and pay the prescribed fee for all
agents and employees of said person engaging in said occupation within the city limits.
(b) Responsibility for acts of agents and employees. Any person obtaining a license under the provisions of
this article to engage in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler, as defined in this article, shall be responsible for
all actions and transactions of all agents and employees engaging in said occupation within the city limits.
(c) Minors as agents and employees. No person shall employ any person who is a minor under the age of
sixteen (16) years as an agent or employee in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler, as defined in this article,
without the written consent of the parent or guardian of said minor, unless the applicant is the parent or legal
guardian of said minor.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.015)
Secs. 4.05.016–4.05.050 Reserved
Division 2. Licenses
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 127/420
Sec. 4.05.051 Required; classes
(a) License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the occupation of a solicitor, peddler, or
itinerant trader as defined in this article, within the city limits, without a license to engage in such occupation.
(b) Classes of licenses. The following classes of licenses may be issued under the provisions of this article:
(1) Solicitor's license. Shall be issued for the purpose of conducting the occupation of solicitor as
defined in this article.
(2) Peddler's license. Shall be issued for the purpose of conducting the occupation of peddler as
defined in this article.
(3) Itinerant trader's license. Shall be issued for the purpose of conducting the occupation of an
itinerant trader as defined in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.021)
Sec. 4.05.052 Application
(a) Information required. Applicants for a license under this article must file with the chief of police a sworn
application in writing on a form to be furnished by the chief of police, which shall provide the following
information:
(1) Name and description of the applicant, to include positive identification of the applicant.
(2) Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant.
(3) A description of the nature of the business and goods to be sold, including a copy of all
literature and product information to be supplied to customers.
(4) A description of the method of payment required by the applicant.
(5) If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the
exact relationship. Said credentials may include a company identification card or certificate or a letter
or certificate from an officer of said company stating that the applicant is an employee and/or agent
of such company.
(6) A statement as to whether or not the applicant has:
(A) Been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to a felony or misdemeanor involving an
alleged violation of any provision of this code, or narcotics, dangerous drugs, or crimes with
dangerous weapons; or a felony offense involving the use of force and violence upon the person
of another; fraud, theft, embezzlement, fraudulent conversion, misappropriation of property,
burglary, crimes against children or senior citizens, or any sex-related offense;
(B) Entered a final judgment or order in a civil or administrative action, including a
stipulated judgment or order, in which the complaint or petition alleged acts constituting a
violation of this article, fraud, theft, embezzlement, fraudulent conversion, or misappropriation
of property, the use of untrue or misleading representations in an attempt to sell or dispose of
real or personal property, or the use of unfair, unlawful, or deceptive trade practices; or
(C) Been subject to an injunction or restrictive court order relating to business activity as the
result of an action brought by a federal, state, or local public agency, including an action
affecting any vocational license.

Said statement shall identify the court or administrative agency rendering the conviction,
judgment, or other order, the docket number of the matter, the date of the conviction,
judgment or order, and the name of the governmental agency, if any, that brought the
action resulting in the conviction, judgment or order.
(7) The sales tax permit number issued by the office of the comptroller of public accounts of the
state.
(8) The names of the immediate last preceding three (3) cities in which the applicant worked or
engaged in the business of a solicitor, peddler or itinerant trader or in the distribution of handbills,
circulars, posters and similar advertising.
(9) If the applicant is applying for an itinerant trader's license, the following shall be supplied:
(A) The address or location of the place the business will be conducted.
(B) The name, address, and telephone number of the property owner of the place the business
will be located.
(C) Certification that the applicant has permission to use the property at the place the
business will be located.
(10) The applicant shall also furnish the following information about any and all vehicles used in
the course of any activity regulated in this article:
(A) A description of the vehicle;
(B) The name of the registered owner of said vehicle; and
(C) The license number of said vehicle.
(b) Application for agents and employees of solicitors and peddlers.
(1) Separate application required. A separate application, on a form to be provided by the chief of
police and including the information required in subsection (a) of this section, shall be required for
each agent or employee engaged in the occupation of solicitor or peddler as defined in this article.
(2) Written consent for minors. If said agent or employee is a minor under the age of sixteen (16)
years old, written consent of the parent or guardian of said minor to engage in said occupation under
the direction of the licensee is required, unless the applicant is the parent or legal guardian of said
minor. The chief of police may require proof of the relationship before approving any license.
(c) Certification required. Such license application shall be accompanied by all certificates of approval as may
be required by this article.
(d) Attachments required. Such license application shall be accompanied by the following documents as
required by this article:
(1) A bond, if required;
(2) A copy of a valid sales tax permit issued by the office of the comptroller of public accounts of
the state;
(3) If the applicant proposes to sell or offer for sale goods consisting of any raw, cooked, prepared
or processed edible substance, ice, beverage, or ingredient used or intended for use or for sale in
whole or in part for human consumption, a certificate with the signature of the health officer or
