https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 129/420
sanitarian of the city indicating that such goods meet minimum food sanitation standards of the city
and state;
(4) If said agent or employee is a minor under the age of sixteen (16) years old, written consent of
the parent or guardian of said minor to engage in said occupation under the direction of the licensee;
and
(5) If the applicant is applying for an itinerant trader's permit and if the applicant proposes to
display goods to the public or to offer such goods for sale from a designated location, such applicant's
application form shall be accompanied by certification that the owner or the duly authorized agent of
the owner of the property at the location at which the applicant proposes to display or offer for sale
any goods consents that the applicant may use and occupy such property for the purpose of selling or
offering for sale such goods.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.022)
Sec. 4.05.053 Denial
The following reasons shall be grounds for denial of a license required by this division:
(1) The applicant does not present a valid state driver's license or other positive proof of
identification;
(2) The applicant does not complete the application form or procedure;
(3) The applicant or the proposed activity of the applicant does not comply with the applicable city
ordinances and codes, including the zoning ordinance, building codes and health codes;
(4) The applicant makes false or fraudulent statements on the application form;
(5) The applicant has been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to an offense involving
narcotics, dangerous drugs, or crimes with dangerous weapons; or a felony offense involving the use
of force and violence upon the person of another; or an offense of fraud, misrepresentation,
embezzlement, forgery, burglary or theft, fraudulent conversion, misappropriation of property,
burglary, crimes against children or senior citizens, or any sex-related offense when such offense is
designated as a felony, at any time within the preceding five-year period;
(6) The applicant has entered a final judgment or order in a civil or administrative action, including
a stipulated judgment or order, in which the complaint or petition alleged acts constituting a violation
of this article, fraud, theft, embezzlement, fraudulent conversion, or misappropriation of property, the
use of untrue or misleading representations in an attempt to sell or dispose of real or personal
property, or the use of unfair, unlawful, or deceptive trade practices;
(7) The applicant has been subject to an injunction or restrictive court order relating to business
activity as the result of an action brought by a federal, state, or local public agency, including an
action affecting any vocational license;
(8) The applicant or licensee has been convicted in a court of proper jurisdiction of violating any
provision of this article within the preceding five (5) year period;
(9) The applicant or licensee has been convicted in a court of proper jurisdiction of violating any
provision of an ordinance regulating solicitors, itinerant vendors, or transient vendors in the state
within the preceding five (5) year period; or
(10) The applicant has failed to pay or report sales tax on sales made within the city to the
comptroller of public accounts of the state as required.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 130/420
(1998 Code, sec. 43.023)
Sec. 4.05.054 Issuance
Upon submission of a license application approved by the chief of police, and payment of any and all required
license or registration fees, the city secretary shall issue a license. (1998 Code, sec. 43.024)
Sec. 4.05.055 Fees
Any person, firm, company, partnership, association, or corporation engaging in the occupation of a solicitor,
peddler, or itinerant trader shall pay a license or registration fee as specified in this article. The fee shall be
payable upon issuance of the license, and shall not be prorated or otherwise modified for reason of duration of
additional licenses issued, or otherwise. (1998 Code, sec. 43.025)
Sec. 4.05.056 Exhibition
Any person issued a license under the provisions of this article is required to exhibit such license upon request.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.026)
Sec. 4.05.057 Transfer
Licenses issued under the provisions of this article are not transferable from one person to another and no such
license shall be used at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. (1998 Code, sec.
43.027)
Sec. 4.05.058 Term; expiration
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for one (1) year and shall expire on the date
specified on the license. All additional licenses issued to agents or employees shall expire on the same date as
the original license, regardless of the date issued. The term of a license may not be extended beyond one (1)
year. (1998 Code, sec. 43.028)
Sec. 4.05.059 Renewal
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article may be considered for renewal upon submission of a new
application for a license. All conditions and requirements for a renewal of a license shall be the same as an initial
application. No license shall be issued with the expectation or implied promise that it will be renewed and no
property or reliance interest shall be vested in any license issued under the provisions of this article. (1998 Code,
sec. 43.029)
Sec. 4.05.060 Suspension or revocation; hearings
(a) Suspension authorized. Any license issued under the provisions of this article may be temporarily
suspended by the chief of police after an opportunity to demonstrate or achieve compliance and notice has been
provided. A license may be suspended if complaints are received from two (2) or more reasonable persons that
the license holder has committed a willful violation of any of the requirements of this article, or if the chief of
police has reason to believe that the public health, interest or safety requires that said licensee not be permitted
to continue activities permitted under said license. Said suspension shall not be for a period of more than five (5)
days unless a hearing has been convened as provided herein.
(b) Revocation authorized. For serious or repeated willful violation of any of the requirements of this article,
or for reasons contained herein, a permit or license issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by
the chief of police after an opportunity to demonstrate or achieve compliance and notice for a hearing has been
provided.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 131/420
(c) Reasons for suspension or revocation. In addition to any other penalty provided by this code, licenses
issued under the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked by the chief of police after notice and
hearing for any of the following cases:
(1) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license;
(2) Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on of business as
defined in this article;
(3) Any violation of the provisions of this article;
(4) Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude;
(5) Conducting business as defined in this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to
constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of
the public;
(6) Failure to remit sales tax receipts to the office of the state comptroller of public accounts as
required by state law;
(7) Failure to maintain minimum food sanitation standards as required in this article; or
(8) Any violation of any of the provisions of the Texas Home Solicitation Act (Texas Business and
Commerce Code, ch. 39).
(d) Hearing for suspension or revocation of license. If the chief of police has reason to suspend or revoke a
license issued herein, the chief of police shall convene a hearing to provide an opportunity for the person holding
the license to present reasons why the license should not be suspended or revoked. Notice of the hearing for
suspension or revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint
and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known
address at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing. Failure to appear at said hearing, or respond in
writing to said notice before the time of same, shall be sufficient reason to immediately revoke said license or
permit and said license shall be automatically revoked.
(e) Hearing for denial of license. If the chief of police has reason to deny the issuance of a license, a hearing
shall be convened, upon request of the applicant, to provide an opportunity for the person denied the license to
present reasons why the license should not be issued. Notice of the hearing shall be given in writing, setting
forth specifically the grounds for the denial and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed,
postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing.
Failure to appear at said hearing, or respond in writing to said notice before the time of same, shall be sufficient
reason to continue the denial of a license and said license shall be automatically denied.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.030)
Sec. 4.05.061 Appeals
Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police in the denial of an application for a license as provided
in this article or in the decision with reference to the suspension or revocation of a license shall have the right of
appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city secretary, within fourteen (14) days
after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement
setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The city secretary shall set a time and place for a hearing on such
appeal at the next council meeting, as allowed by law, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant
in the same manner as provided in this article for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the
council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. (1998 Code, sec. 43.031)
Sec. 4.05.062 Limitations
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 132/420
(a) License not a franchise. Licenses issued under the provisions of this article are not a franchise and will not
grant unto any licensee any property right, exclusive area or class of service and do not create a contractual
relationship between the city and the licensee or the consumer purchasing goods from said licensee.
(b) License not a warranty; no liability assumed. The city does not accept any responsibility for any acts or
omissions of the licensee or agents and employees of the licensee and does not warrant or guarantee or assume
any liability for any goods or services offered or sold by such licensee.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.032)
Secs. 4.05.063–4.05.090 Reserved
Division 3. Solicitors and Peddlers
Sec. 4.05.091 License required; classes of licenses
(a) License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler,
as defined in this article, within the city limits, without a license to engage in such occupation.
(b) Classes of licenses. The following classes of licenses may be issued under the provisions of this division:
(1) Solicitor's license. Shall be issued for the purpose of conducting the occupation of solicitor as
defined in this article.
(2) Peddler's license. Shall be issued for the purpose of conducting the occupation of peddler as
defined in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.041)
Sec. 4.05.092 License fees
The license fee for a solicitor or peddler, as defined in this article, shall be one hundred and fifty dollars
($150.00); provided, however, when any person, firm, company, partnership, association or corporation engages
in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler through two (2) or more agents or employees, such person, firm,
company, partnership, corporation or association shall, in addition to said one hundred and fifty dollars
($150.00) above mentioned, pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each agent or employee so engaged, in
excess of one. The fee shall be payable upon issuance of the license, and shall not be prorated or otherwise
modified for reason of duration of additional licenses issued, or otherwise. (1998 Code, sec. 43.042; Ordinance
adopting Code)
Sec. 4.05.093 Solicitor's bond
(a) Required. The application for a solicitor's license required in this article shall be accompanied by a signed
and sealed original bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), signed by the applicant, and
signed as surety by some surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned on the final delivery
of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines or newspapers, in accordance with the terms of
any order obtained prior to delivery; and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers and customers for
any and all defects in material and workmanship which may exist in the article sold by the principal of said bond
at the time of delivery, and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within thirty (30) days after
delivery; and which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons which may make any purchase or give
any order to the principal of said bond, or to an agent or employee of the principal.
(b) Action to recover against security. A person who is injured by the actions of a person bonded under the
provisions of this article may bring and maintain an action to recover against the bond.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 133/420
(1998 Code, sec. 43.043)
Sec. 4.05.094 Approval of license by chief of police
Each application for a license required in this division shall be approved by the chief of police before such
license is granted. The chief of police shall have a reasonable time to conduct an investigation of an applicant for
such license, but such an investigation shall be completed within five (5) business days. After inspection or
investigation, the chief of police shall either approve or disapprove the application for license. (1998 Code, sec.
43.044)
Sec. 4.05.095 Hours of operation; exhibition of card prohibiting solicitors
(a) Hours of operation. No person engaging in the occupation of a solicitor or peddler and required to obtain a
license under the provisions of this article shall commence operations and go from place to place, or door to
door, in a residential area without prior invitation or appointment with the occupant of the premises, before nine
o'clock (9:00) a.m. or thirty minutes after sundown on any day. Violation of this section shall constitute another
cause for revocation of any license in addition to those enumerated in this article, and in the manner as
prescribed in said section.
(b) Exhibition of card prohibiting solicitors.
(1) A person desiring that no peddler, solicitor, or other person engage in a home solicitation at his
residence shall exhibit in a conspicuous place, upon or near the main entrance to the residence, a
weatherproof card or sign, not less than three inches by four inches in size, containing the words,
“NO SOLICITORS.” The letters shall be not less than two-thirds of an inch in height.
(2) Every peddler or solicitor going onto any premises upon which a residence is located shall first
examine the residence to determine if any notice prohibiting soliciting is exhibited upon or near the
main entrance to the residence. If notice prohibiting soliciting is exhibited, the peddler or solicitor
shall immediately depart the premises without disturbing the occupant, unless the visit is the result of
a request made by the occupant.
(3) No person shall go upon any residential premises and ring the doorbell, or rap or knock upon
the door or create any sound in a manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of the
residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and engaging in or attempting to
engage in a home solicitation transaction, if a card or sign as described in subsection (1) above is
exhibited in a conspicuous place upon or near the main entrance to the residence, unless the visit is
the result of a request made by the occupant.
(4) No person, other than the occupant of the residence, shall remove, deface, or render illegible a
card or sign placed by the occupant pursuant to subsection (1) above.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.045)
Sec. 4.05.096 Departure from premises upon request of occupant
Any solicitor or peddler who has gained entrance to a residence, or audience with the occupant, whether invited
or not, shall immediately depart the premises without disturbing the occupant further, when requested to leave
by the occupant. (1998 Code, sec. 43.046)
Sec. 4.05.097 Exemptions
Except for the provisions of this article dealing with minimum food standards, loud noises and speaking devices,
the use of streets, hours of operations in residential districts, exhibiting cards or signs prohibiting solicitors,
conduct of telephone solicitations, and solicitations on or at city-owned property, public parks, or swimming
pools, the provisions of this division shall not apply to:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 134/420
(1) Ordinary commercial travelers who sell or exhibit for sale goods, wares or merchandise to
persons, firms or corporations engaged in the business of selling, buying and dealing in goods or
merchandise;
(2) Persons engaged in charitable or religious solicitations as defined in this article;
(3) Newspaper delivery persons;
(4) Telephone solicitations as defined and regulated in this article;
(5) Solicitations made at the request of a person, solicitations made in connection with an existing
debt or contract, or solicitations from a solicitor with whom the person has an existing business
relationship;
(6) A person licensed under the Insurance Code, if the solicited transaction is governed by the
Insurance Code;
(7) A person who periodically delivers catalogs to potential purchasers if the catalog:
(A) Includes at least 24 pages of written material or illustrations; and
(B) Is circulated in more than one state;
(8) A person selling merchandise under an arrangement in which the seller periodically ships or
delivers the merchandise to a consumer who has consented in advance to receive the merchandise on
a periodic basis; or
(9) A person who has for at least one year been operating under the same name as that used in
connection with its soliciting operations a retail establishment where consumer goods are displayed
and offered for sale on a continuing basis and involves the buyers obtaining services or products at
the person's retail establishment.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.047)
Secs. 4.05.098–4.05.130 Reserved
Division 4. Itinerant Traders
Sec. 4.05.131 License required
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the occupation of an itinerant trader, as defined in this article, in
the city without obtaining a license to engage in such occupation. (1998 Code, sec. 43.061)
Sec. 4.05.132 License fee
The license fee for an itinerant trader, as defined in this article, shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). The fee
shall be payable upon issuance of the license. (1998 Code, sec. 43.062; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 4.05.133 Approval of license by chief of police
Each application for a license required in this division shall be approved by the chief of police before such
license is granted. The chief of police shall have a reasonable time to conduct an investigation of an applicant for
such license, but such an investigation shall be completed within five (5) business days. After inspection or
investigation, the chief of police shall either approve or disapprove the application for license. (1998 Code, sec.
43.063)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 135/420
Sec. 4.05.134 Permission of property owner required
If the applicant proposes to display goods to the public or to offer such goods for sale from a designated
location, such applicant shall have permission from the owner or the duly authorized agent of the owner of the
property at the location at which the applicant proposes to display or offer for sale any goods. (1998 Code, sec.
43.064)
Sec. 4.05.135 Location restrictions; compliance with zoning ordinance
(a) Residential districts. No permit under this article shall be issued for the operation of any temporary or
transient business by an itinerant trader, as defined in this article, in a residential district as defined in this article.
(b) Retail and industrial districts. Any person wishing to operate a temporary or transient business as an
itinerant trader, as defined in this article, in a retail or industrial district, as defined in this article, shall comply
with all applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.065)
Sec. 4.05.136 Flea markets
(a) Operator to be licensed. Every promoter or operator of a flea market shall be considered as engaging in the
operation of an itinerant trader and shall obtain a license as required in this division.
(b) Sales by participants exempt from license. Sales by individual sellers or participants at a licensed flea
market are exempt from the provisions of the individual licensing requirements of this division.
(c) Responsibilities of operator. The promoter or operator of a flea market shall comply with all other
provisions of this article and state law, and shall keep a register or record of such sellers or participants which
shall give all of the following information:
(1) Name of the person renting the space;
(2) Permanent home address and full local address of such person;
(3) A brief description of the nature of the goods to be sold; and
(4) A state sales tax permit number, if state statute requires that sales tax must be paid upon the
purchases of such goods that the seller or participant proposes to offer for sale.
The operator or promoter of a licensed flea market shall be responsible for retention of the register of
participants as required by this article for one (1) year.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.066)
Sec. 4.05.137 Exemptions
Except for the provisions of this article dealing with minimum food sanitary standards, loud noises and speaking
devices, the use of streets, and solicitations on or at city-owned property, public parks, or swimming pools, the
provisions of this division shall not apply to:
(1) Sales or exhibits at fairs, rodeos, conventions, or city civic organizations, church, or chamber of
commerce sponsored events.
(2) The sale of goods, wares and merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds of
which are to be used and applied to charitable, religious, or philanthropic purposes.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 136/420
(3) Occasional sales as defined in this article, to include garage sales.
(4) Persons selling agricultural products grown in the county by the seller or members of the
seller's immediate family.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.067)
Secs. 4.05.138–4.05.170 Reserved
Division 5. Handbills, Circulars, Posters and Similar Advertising
Sec. 4.05.171 Distribution of handbills or circulars
(a) Prohibitions. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create, permit, keep or otherwise scatter, place,
deliver, or distribute any circular, handbill, paper, announcement, advertisement, printed matter or other
advertising matter on any street, alley, gutter, sidewalk, drain, public building, public ground or other place,
public or private, or any other place immediately adjacent to such premises, or in any vehicle of any kind, within
the city.
(b) Exceptions. The provisions of this division shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States
post office, nor to the circulation and distribution of regularly circulated and distributed newspapers, magazines,
periodicals, and religious and educational literature, and shall not apply to handbills or circulars personally
handed to another individual person.
(1998 Code, sec. 43.081)
Sec. 4.05.172 Posting on private property
Any person who shall, without first having obtained permission from the owner, stick, paint, or stamp upon any
house, fence, wall, pavement, utility pole or other object not his own, within the corporate limits of this city, any
written, printed or other notice, bill, sign, circular, poster or advertisement, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1998 Code, sec. 43.082)
ARTICLE 4.06 ALARM SYSTEMS*
Sec. 4.06.001 Definitions
As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
Alarm system. Any devices used to detect or prevent burglary, theft, robbery, or other similar illegal activity on
private property.
Automatic dialing device. An alarm system device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is
programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit by voice message or code signal an
emergency message indicating a need for emergency response.
Central alarm installation. A device, or collection of devices, located within the police department building, that
indicates activation of alarm systems.
False alarm. The activation of an alarm system which is not the result of an illegal activity or threat of illegal
activity for which the system was designed to give notice; for the purposes hereof, false alarm shall not include
any activation of an alarm system caused by an act of God.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.061; Ordinance adopting Code)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 137/420
Sec. 4.06.002 Requirements for connection to central alarm system
(a) Permission required. No person shall connect or cause or permit the connection of any alarm system to the
central alarm location without the express permission of the chief of police.
(b) Factors to be considered. In determining whether to authorize such a connection, the chief of police shall
consider the following factors and requirements:
(1) The alarm system shall be installed by a security services contractor licensed by the state;
(2) The premises served by the alarm system shall be provided with reasonable security measures
other than the alarm system to prevent illegal activity;
(3) The proposed connection circuit in the central alarm installation shall not exceed the space
requirements established by the chief of police;
(4) The alarm system equipment and installation shall be subject to inspection and approval by the
chief of police or an authorized representative;
(5) The premises served by the alarm system shall not be equipped with an audible alarm.
(c) Required information. The chief of police shall require information to be provided by the owner or person
in control of the premises served by such an alarm system, including but not limited to the following:
(1) The name and address of the owner or person in control of the premises;
(2) The type of alarm system being installed;
(3) The name of the person who will install the alarm system;
(4) The names and addresses of all persons who will receive notice of activation of the alarm
system;
(5) The name, address and telephone number of at least two (2) persons acceptable to the chief of
police who have agreed:
(A) To receive notice of activation of the system at any time;
(B) To come to the premises served by the system within thirty (30) minutes after receiving a
request from the police department to do so; and
(C) To grant access to the premises and to deactivate the alarm system if necessary.
(d) Automatic dialing devices; audible alarm cutoff.
(1) No owner or person in control of premises shall use an automatic dialing device leading to the
police department.
(2) All audible alarms shall be equipped to automatically shut off no more than fifteen (15) minutes
after activation.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.062)
Sec. 4.06.003 Disconnection from central alarm system
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 138/420
(a) Reasons for disconnection. The chief of police may cause disconnection of an alarm from the central alarm
installation for failure to pay the appropriate fee as provided in this article.
(b) Notice of disconnection. The chief of police shall give at least thirty (30) days' notice of such
disconnection to the owner or person in control of the premises.
(c) Reconnection.
(1) The chief of police may require an inspection or reinspection to be made of an alarm system
disconnected because of a failure to pay false alarm fees as a condition for reconnection.
(2) An alarm system disconnected from the central alarm installation shall not be reconnected until
the system is certified in writing to be operating properly by a security service contractor licensed by
the state.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.063)
Sec. 4.06.004 False alarms
The following provisions shall apply to all false alarms to which a response is made by the police department,
regardless of whether the alarm system involved is connected to the central alarm installation:
(1) The chief of police shall notify the owner or person in control of the premises served by an
alarm system of all false alarms generated by such system and shall keep a record of all such false
alarms.
(2) Additional fees shall be charged for false alarms as provided for in this article.
(3) A false alarm is not considered to have occurred unless a response is made by the city or other
law enforcement agency within thirty (30) minutes of the alarm notification and the city determines
from an inspection of the interior or exterior of the premises that the alarm was false.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.064)
Sec. 4.06.005 Connection of systems outside city to central alarm system
Alarm systems serving premises outside of the city limits may be connected to the central alarm installation
subject to the following provisions:
(1) The only responsibility of the city police department in connection with such alarms shall be to
notify the appropriate law enforcement agency in the jurisdiction in which the alarm system is
located. No response shall be made by any officer of the city police department unless there exists an
interlocal assistance agreement with said jurisdiction approved by the city council in accordance with
the provisions of state law.
(2) Such additional fees may be charged as provided for in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.065)
Sec. 4.06.006 Fees
(a) Annual fee for connection to central alarm system. An annual fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be
paid on or before December thirty-first for connection of an alarm system to the central alarm installation for the
following year.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 139/420
(b) False alarms. A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid by the owner or person in control of the
premises served by an alarm system for each false alarm in excess of eight (8) false alarms during the preceding
twelve (12) month period and less than sixteen (16) false alarms; an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall
be paid for each false alarm in excess of fifteen (15) false alarms generated from such system during the
preceding twelve (12) month period.
(c) Fees not refundable. Fees paid according to this section shall not be refundable.
(d) Alarm systems outside city limits. All fees for alarm systems serving premises outside of the city limits
shall be double those provided in this article, with no exceptions, except the fee may not exceed fifty dollars
($50.00) per alarm.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.066)
ARTICLE 4.07 AMBULANCES*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.07.001 Definitions
As used herein, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated:
Ambulance. Every motor vehicle used, designed or redesigned for the transportation of sick or injured persons.
Ambulance operator. Any person, partnership or corporation holding a permit from the city to operate an
ambulance.
Driver's permit. A city ambulance driver's permit.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.001)
Sec. 4.07.002 Penalty
A person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in any sum not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
such offense. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. (1998 Code, sec. 42.005)
Sec. 4.07.003 Supplies
The city manager may, from time to time, with the advice of the city health officer, make a list of supplies to be
carried at all times in any emergency ambulance, and notification shall be given to the operators of all such
vehicles as to such requirements. The failure of any permit holder to comply with the requirements so
established and published shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of this permit. (1998 Code, sec.
42.002)
Sec. 4.07.004 Refusal to transport person on account of inability to pay
It shall be unlawful for an ambulance operator to refuse to carry or transport any sick or injured person at the
place of an emergency on account of the apparent indigence of such person or the inability of such person to pay
for emergency ambulance service. The operator shall not be required to furnish ambulance service of a nonemergency
nature unless the recipient of such service shall make satisfactory financial arrangements with such
operator. (1998 Code, sec. 42.003)
Sec. 4.07.005 Exemption of governmental bodies
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 140/420
This article shall not apply to any ambulance service whole or partially owned, operated, or controlled by any
governmental body. (1998 Code, sec. 42.004)
Secs. 4.07.006–4.07.040 Reserved
Division 2. Operator's Permit
Sec. 4.07.041 Required
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in furnishing ambulance service by operating
or driving or causing to be operated or driven an ambulance upon the public streets of the city without having
first obtained a city ambulance operator's permit. (1998 Code, sec. 42.006)
Sec. 4.07.042 Application; notice of hearing
(a) Application for an ambulance operator's permit shall be filed with the secretary of the city. Such
application shall be in a form acceptable to the city secretary, shall be sworn to before a notary public or other
officer authorized to take oaths and shall contain proof of the following matters:
(1) That the applicant or applicants have not been convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor
involving moral turpitude within ten (10) years from the date of filing such application.
(2) A statement that the applicant has obtained or will obtain liability insurance in accordance with
the requirements hereinafter provided before commencing ambulance service in the event the city
council determines an ambulance operator's permit should be granted to such applicant. No
ambulance operator's permit shall be issued until such insurance is in effect, and until satisfactory
proof of such fact is made to the city secretary.
(3) A statement that the applicant has been issued a permit by the state board of health pursuant to
the terms and provisions of the Emergency Medical Services Act (section 773.041, Health & Safety
Code). No ambulance permit will be issued unless the applicant has obtained such a permit.
(b) Upon receipt of the application in due form and containing all information required by the city secretary,
the city secretary shall cause a notice to be published in the city's newspaper one (1) time at least ten (10) days
and not more than fifteen (15) days prior to the next regular meeting of the city council, and such notice shall
state that the application has been received by the city secretary. In addition to the public notice set forth above,
the city secretary shall notify in writing each holder of a current ambulance operator's permit of the receipt of
such application and such notice shall indicate that a public hearing will be had at the next regular council
meeting, giving the date of such meeting. The applicant shall pay to the city secretary upon the filing of his
application the cost of publication of such notice as is required by this article.
(c) Any person operating an ambulance service within the city as of the effective date of this article shall be
issued a permit without notice and hearing upon such person making application within ten (10) days after the
effective date of this article and upon such persons furnishing the certificate of insurance as herein provided.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.007)
Sec. 4.07.043 Determination of public convenience and necessity
(a) The city council shall hold a public hearing at the time and place specified in the published notice.
(b) The applicant shall not be granted an ambulance operator's permit unless the city council finds and
determines that the public convenience and necessity will be served by the issuance of such permit. The city
council shall hear all of the relevant and material evidence presented by the applicant and his witnesses, and by
persons who appear in opposition to the application. The council shall also have the right to call any other
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 141/420
witnesses that it may deem necessary or appropriate. In all such hearings the burden of proof shall be upon the
applicant to establish by clear and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity will be served
by the granting of the ambulance operator's permit.
(c) Public convenience and necessity shall mean that:
(1) The existing ambulance service within the city will not be adversely affected so as to lower the
standards of existing services within the city.
(2) There is a need for additional ambulance service within the city.
(3) Existing ambulance service is inadequate to serve the needs of the public, whether such
inadequacy is caused by the lack of equipment, the lack of competent personnel, mismanagement, or
any other cause whatsoever.
(4) The financial responsibility of the applicant to furnish the service for which he has made
application.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.008)
Sec. 4.07.044 Granting or denial
The city council shall make a determination as to the existence or nonexistence of public convenience and
necessity within fifteen (15) days of the date of the conclusion of such hearing and it shall notify the applicant
and all other parties who appeared at such hearing as a party of interest of the decision of the city council.
Unless such application is granted within fifteen (15) days of the conclusion of the public hearing, it will be
deemed to have been denied. (1998 Code, sec. 42.009)
Sec. 4.07.045 Liability insurance
(a) Before an ambulance operator's permit is granted to an applicant, or before any renewal thereof, the
applicant or the operator seeking renewal shall provide evidence to the city secretary that he has in full force and
effect a public liability insurance policy on each ambulance, such insurance policy to be issued by an insurance
company licensed to do business in the state. Such insurance policy or policies shall provide liability insurance
in the amount of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one accident and not less
than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to any one person. Such insurance policy shall not
contain a passenger liability exclusion.
(b) Evidence of such insurance shall be in the form of a certificate of insurance stating fully the nature and
extent of coverage provided, and such certificate shall contain a provision to the effect written notice will be
given to the city secretary at least ten (10) days prior to the effective date of any cancellation of such insurance
policy or policies.
(c) Failure of the operator to maintain at all times a currently effective certificate of insurance shall be grounds
for the cancellation of this permit.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.010)
Sec. 4.07.046 Duration
An ambulance operator's permit issued pursuant to this article shall remain valid so long as all terms and
provisions of this article are complied with and so long as ambulance service is provided by the holder of such
permit. Should the holder of any such permit cease doing business, or cease furnishing adequate ambulance
service, or should he permit or suffer his liability insurance to lapse, after notice and hearing, such permit shall
be automatically forfeited and canceled, and may be reinstated only upon submission of a new application.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.011)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 142/420
Sec. 4.07.047 Changes in organization or ownership of permit holder
All changes in the organization or ownership of any partnership or corporation shall be promptly reported to the
city secretary within ten (10) days after such change occurs, and any individual becoming connected with the
operation of such ambulance shall file his individual application with the city secretary certifying to the
qualifications set forth in section 4.07.042 above. (1998 Code, sec. 42.012)
Sec. 4.07.048 Inspection of books and records
The books and records of the holder of any ambulance operator's permit shall be open for inspection by the city
manager or personnel under his direction. (1998 Code, sec. 42.013)
Secs. 4.07.049–4.07.080 Reserved
Division 3. Driver's Permit
Sec. 4.07.081 Required; application; issuance
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate an ambulance unless such person has obtained from
the city an ambulance driver's permit. The application for an ambulance driver's permit shall be made to the city
secretary, and such sworn application shall contain the following information:
(1) That the applicant is twenty-one (21) years of age or older; and
(2) That the applicant has not been convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude within the last ten (10) years.
(b) Upon receipt of such application, the city secretary shall cause an investigation to be made of the driving
record of such applicant, and if such driving record appears satisfactory, and if all other provisions of this article
have been complied with, the city secretary shall issue the ambulance driver's permit.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.014)
Sec. 4.07.082 Suspension or revocation
The city council may, after notice and hearing, suspend or revoke the permit issued to any driver under this
article if such driver has violated the terms of this article or any other ordinance regulating traffic in the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.015)
ARTICLE 4.08 WRECKER SERVICES*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 4.08.001 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings hereinafter ascribed to them:
Certificate. Authorization granted by the chief of police of the city, under the provisions of this article, to use a
designated vehicle as a wrecker.
Chief of police. The chief of police of the city or a person designated by him to act in his stead for the purposes
of this article.
Motor vehicle. Any vehicle which is self-propelled, except motor-assisted bicycles as defined by the laws of the
state.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 143/420
Owner. Any person who holds the legal title to a motor vehicle or who has the legal right to possession thereof.
Permit. Authorization granted by the city under the provisions of this article to engage in the wrecker business in
the city.
Permit holder. Any person possessing a current, valid permit to engage in the wrecker business in the city.
Person. An individual, corporation, partnership, joint venture or association. This does not include a
governmental agency.
Point of origin. The point where a vehicle is picked up for towing.
Private parking lot. Any private property used for restricted and/or paid parking of vehicles.
Vehicle. Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a
public highway, but not including devices moved solely by human power, or used exclusively upon stationary
tracks or rails.
Vehicle depository. The site to which a permit holder tows and/or stores vehicles.
Wrecker. Any motor vehicle used for the purpose of towing or removing vehicles.
Wrecker business. The business of towing vehicles not belonging to the towing person on a public street within
the incorporated limits of the city for compensation, or with the expectation of compensation and/or repair,
including the operation of a wrecker or wreckers in connection with some other business. It does not include the
operation of wreckers by any governmental entity or tows into or out of the city at the owner's request, except as
otherwise provided in this article.
Wrecker rotation lists. Lists prepared by the city police department in accordance with the provisions of this
article of wrecker businesses which have requested and qualified for placement upon such lists.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.061)
Sec. 4.08.002 Penalty
Violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to such administrative action as set out herein in
addition to being guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, subject to a fine not to exceed two
hundred dollars ($200.00). (1998 Code, sec. 42.062)
Sec. 4.08.003 Maximum charges
The following maximum fees may be charged by permit holders under this article for the use of designated
capacity wreckers and no additional charges may be made.
(1) Towing fees.
(A) Collision haul - anytime day or night: $100.00.
(B) Clean up and labor, per hour minimum: $80.00.
(C) Recovery charge - winching for vehicle/per hr. min.: $150.00.
(D) Storage of towed vehicles, per day: $20.00.
(E) Storage of towed tractor/trailer rig, per day: $35.00.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 144/420
(F) Fuel surcharge: $10.00.
(Ordinance O-01-11 adopted 1/18/11)
Secs. 4.08.004–4.08.030 Reserved
Division 2. Business Permit and Wrecker Certificate
Sec. 4.08.031 Required
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the wrecker business within the city unless such person
possesses a valid permit therefor.
(b) It shall be unlawful to drive or cause to be driven in the wrecker business a wrecker for which no valid
certificate is possessed.
(c) The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not apply to a wrecker tow which originates
outside the limits of the city.
(d) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, in any circumstance in which a vehicle or other object
is so located on a public street as to constitute a hazard or obstacle, or to interfere with traffic, or in the event a
stolen vehicle is found, or in any other circumstance in which a police officer in the course of his duty deems it
necessary, he may require such a vehicle or object to be removed at the owner's expense by any practical means,
including use of the wrecker rotation lists in accordance with the provisions of this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.071)
Sec. 4.08.032 Application for permit; fee; display
(a) Applications for permits shall be made upon forms supplied by the city secretary, shall be verified and
shall contain the following information:
(1) The true name, trade name, address and telephone number of the wrecker business.
(2) The number and category of wreckers proposed to be operated.
(3) The names and addresses of the true owners of the wrecker business and, if the business is a
corporation, the names and addresses of the corporate officers.
(4) The true owners of the wreckers to be used, if different from the true owners of the business.
(5) A statement from the appropriate taxing authority that all city taxes on the permit applicant's
property, both real and personal, to be used in the business are current.
(6) A certificate of public liability and property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance
company authorized to do business in the state, in the standard form approved by the state department
of insurance, containing a provision that at least ten (10) days' prior notice of cancellation of said
insurance shall be given to the city secretary by the insurance company and with the city expressly
named as an additional insured and the coverage provision of such policy insuring members of the
public from any loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by reason of the operation of
the permit holder's wrecker business and providing that the amount of coverage shall comply with the
limits set forth in this article.
(b) The annual fee for a permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall entitle the holder to operate a wrecker
business in compliance with this article for one year from the date of the issuance of the permit.

(c) Permits shall be prominently displayed at the permit holder's place of business.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.072)
Sec. 4.08.033 Issuance of certificate
(a) A permit holder desiring to have a wrecker certified shall do the following:
(1) Submit a copy of the manufacturer's certificate of title to the police chief or his designated
representative along with a request for certification on a form provided by the city secretary.
(2) Submit such wrecker for inspection by the chief of police or his designated representative.
(b) Following a determination that such wrecker complies with applicable state laws and the provisions of this
article, the chief of police or his designated representative shall issue a certificate of compliance to the permit
holder and cause to be affixed to the vehicle windshield a sticker or other device as the chief of police shall
deem to be of assistance in identifying properly certified wreckers.
(c) The permit holder shall pay a nonrefundable fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each wrecker for which
certification is sought.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.073)
Sec. 4.08.034 Wrecker requirements
(a) Wreckers shall be classified as class I or class II and shall meet the following equipment requirements for
class I certification:
(1) Shall not be less than one (1) ton in capacity, as reflected on the manufacturer's certificate, title
or by certification by a mechanical engineer licensed as a professional engineer in the state.
(2) Shall be equipped with booster brakes.
(3) Shall be equipped with a power-operated winch, winch line and boom with a rated or tested
lifting capacity of not less than six thousand (6,000) pounds single line capacity.
(4) Shall carry as standard equipment at least one of each of the following: tow bar, safety chain
and fire extinguisher. If such wrecker is to be used in collision hauls, it shall also carry a wrecker bar,
broom, ax, shovel and dolly.
(5) Shall display the permit number of the permit holder as reflected on the permit in letters at least
three (3) inches high on each side of the wrecker. Such numbers shall be permanently attached,
legible, and on a contrasting background. Nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the display
of the name of the wrecker business upon the wrecker.
(6) Shall be in such a condition that it can safely and reliably be used as a wrecker.
(7) Shall comply with the motor vehicle equipment laws of the state.
(b) Class II wreckers shall meet the following additional requirements:
(1) Shall not be less than three (3) tons in capacity, as reflected on the manufacturer's certificate,
title or by certification by a mechanical engineer licensed as a professional engineer in the state.
(2) Shall be equipped with air brakes.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 146/420
(3) Shall be equipped with a power-operated winch, winch line and boom with a rated or tested
lifting capacity of not less than twenty-five thousand (25,000) pounds capacity.
(4) Shall carry at least two (2) snatch blocks and two (2) scotch blocks.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.074)
Sec. 4.08.035 Insurance
All permit holders shall maintain public liability and property damage insurance in the following minimum
amounts:
(1) Class I wreckers.
(A) For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one collision:
$100,000.00.
(B) For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one
collision: $300,000.00.
(C) For damage to or destruction of property in one collision: $100,000.00.
(D) For general garage liability: $100,000.00.
(2) Class II wreckers. Requirements shall be the same as for class I wreckers, except that cargo
insurance shall be in an amount of at least $75,000.00.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.075)
Sec. 4.08.036 Equipment requirements
All wreckers must be equipped as follows:
(1) Shall display atop the highest part of the wrecker a revolving amber or amber and blue light.
(2) Two white floodlights projecting to the rear of the wrecker, mounted in such a manner as to
light up the vehicle being loaded or unloaded, which lights shall be extinguished while towing is in
progress.
(3) Shall have a cradle sling or bar to provide rigid spacing between the wrecker and the towed
vehicle and which is capable of lifting the front or rear of a towed vehicle clear of the roadway.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.076)
Sec. 4.08.037 Grounds for suspension or revocation
The city secretary shall issue a permit to those persons complying with the requirements of this article. The
police chief shall issue a certificate for any permitted wrecker complying with the requirements of this article.
Since the proper and safe functioning of wreckers has critical impact on the health, safety and welfare of the
public, and involves use of the public streets of the city, often in conditions necessitating the prompt and safe
removal of dangerous obstructions to traffic and said streets, the privilege of operating a wrecker within the city
shall be subject to strict regulation in order to protect the public, including the following administrative actions
in lieu of or in addition to any permitted criminal or civil remedy at law:
(1) Suspension of permit. Grounds for suspension of permit include the following:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 147/420
(A) Failure to meet the requirements of this article for a permit at any time.
(B) Operating a wrecker in such a manner as to endanger any person or property.
(C) Collecting or charging any fees in excess of those set out in this article.
(D) Violation of state law or city ordinance by a permit holder or his employee in connection
with the operation of the wrecker business.
(2) Revocation of permit. Grounds for revocation shall be the repeated violation of those items
listed for suspension, but revocation shall not be done unless the permit holder has been suspended at
least twice within the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the revocation.
(3) Suspension of certificate. The certificate of any wrecker may be suspended and the evidence of
certification removed from the wrecker following:
(A) Operating a wrecker in such a condition that it cannot safely tow a vehicle.
(B) Operating a wrecker not covered by insurance as required by this article.
(C) Operating a wrecker that does not meet the requirements for certification set out in this
article.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.077)
Sec. 4.08.038 Procedure for suspension or revocation
(a) Suspension or revocation of permit. Suspension or revocation of a permit may be accomplished by the
chief of police until such time as the deficiency under section 4.08.037(1)(A) is corrected or not more than
fifteen (15) days for a violation of section 4.08.037(1)(B), (C) or (D). Notice of the hearing, the administrative
action proposed to be taken and the grounds therefor shall be given to the permit holder ten (10) days prior to the
hearing. Mailing such notice by certified mail to the last known business address of the permit holder not less
than ten (10) days prior to the hearing shall constitute adequate notice. Suspension of a permit shall be
accomplished by a notice in writing to the permit holder within ten (10) days of the hearing. Said notice shall set
out the date of the suspension and the date of reinstatement and shall advise the permit holder that he may appeal
such decision to the city manager. Revocation of a permit may be accomplished in the same manner. Following
revocation, no new permit shall be given to that former permit holder for a period of at least six (6) months from
the date of revocation.
(b) Suspension of certificate. Suspension of a certificate may be accomplished by the chief of police or by any
police officer who shall discover a wrecker in operation in violation of the provisions of section 4.08.037(3).
Suspension will be accomplished by the removal of the device signifying certification from the wrecker. Such
certificate shall be reissued when the condition is corrected and the vehicle reinspected by the chief of police or
his authorized representative. Cost for such reinspection shall be twenty dollars ($20.00). Such suspension may
be appealed by giving written notice of such appeal to the chief of police within ten (10) days of the suspension
of such certificate. Such hearing shall [be] before the chief of police within ten (10) days of the receipt of the
written notice. The chief of police shall notify the certificate holder of his decision in writing within ten (10)
days of the hearing. If such suspension is upheld, the notice of decision shall state what action will be necessary
to have the certificate reissued and that such decision may be appealed to the city manager.
(1998 Code, sec. 42.078)
Secs. 4.08.039–4.08.070 Reserved
Division 3. Operational Regulations
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
