OFFENSES AND NUISANCES
ARTICLE 8.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 8.01.001 Adoption of state penal laws
Any act the commission of which constitutes a misdemeanor under the laws of the state is prohibited within the
city, and if committed within the city is hereby declared to be an offense; provided, however, that the penalty
therefor shall not exceed the penalty for such offense prescribed in section 1.01.009 of this code. (1998 Code,
sec. 86.001)
Sec. 8.01.002 Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages on city property
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume any alcoholic beverage in or upon any property
owned by the city, except as permitted in this section.
(b) The possession or consumption of beer and wine only in and upon property owned by the city is permitted
provided the person is attending an event sponsored by the city or a non-profit or religious organization which
has obtained the appropriate permit from the city and only within the area designated in the permit.
(c) A permit for the sale of beer and wine only required by subsection (b) may be granted by the city if the
following conditions are met:
(1) The sale of beer and wine on city property may be granted by the city for events sponsored by
the city or by a non-profit or religious organization.
(2) An applicant wishing to obtain a permit shall submit an event application to the city secretary at
least ten (10) business days prior to the proposed event.
(3) Organizations requesting a permit shall use the services of a caterer licensed by the Texas
Alcoholic Beverage Commission or acquire such permit as may be required by the Texas Alcoholic
Beverage Commission to sell beer and wine, and all sales shall be subject to all applicable rules and
requirements established by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission.
(4) Both the organization requesting the permit and the licensed caterer must insure that no beer or
wine being sold under the terms of the permit will be allowed outside the permitted area.
(5) Hours of permitted sales of beer and wine are limited to the hours between 10:00 a.m. and
midnight of the same day. Further hourly restrictions as imposed by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage
Commission and state law must be observed should they be more restrictive.
(6) Beer and wine must be sold, possessed and consumed only in accordance with state law.
(7) The applicant must provide the types and terms of insurance as may be required by the city
which insurance shall name the city as an additional insured.
(8) The event must be conducted in accordance with all applicable municipal codes and ordinances
including zoning, food service, building or other codes.
(Ordinance O-07-12 adopted 4/17/12)
Sec. 8.01.003 Abandoned refrigerators or airtight containers
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 212/420
Abandoned refrigerators, freezers, and similar airtight containers shall be regulated in accordance with the
provisions of the Texas Health and Safety Code, sec. 756.011 et seq. (Ordinance adopting Code)
State law reference–Regulation of abandoned refrigerators, freezers, and similar containers, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec.
756.011 et seq.
ARTICLE 8.02 NOISE†
Sec. 8.02.001 General prohibition
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or wantonly use or operate or cause to be used or operated any
mechanical or electrical device, machine, apparatus, or instrument which causes or produces any sound or noise
which is reasonably calculated to disturb the peace and good order of the neighborhood or the persons owning,
using or occupying property within the city. (1998 Code, sec. 86.061)
Sec. 8.02.002 Specific noises prohibited
The noise or sound caused or produced by the operation of the devices, machines, apparatus or instruments
mentioned below is hereby defined as noises or sounds which are prohibited by this article:
(1) The operation of any mechanical or electrical device, machine, or instrument to intensify or
amplify or to reproduce the human voice or any other sound, within any building or on any premises
in the city, whereby the sound therefrom is cast directly upon the public streets or places or where
such device is maintained and operated for advertising purposes or for the purpose of attracting
attention of the passing public, or which is so placed or operated that the sounds coming therefrom
can be heard to the annoyance or inconvenience of travelers upon any street or public place, or of
persons in neighboring premises;
(2) The operation of open-air roller rinks or open-air skating rinks;
(3) Unnecessarily sounding automobile horns or warning devices;
(4) Open blast furnaces under or connected with steam boilers or water heaters;
(5) The operation of any steam boiler or water heater to which is attached an instrument or outlet,
commonly called a “pop-off valve,” through which steam is permitted to escape when the steam
pressure within a boiler or water heater to which it is attached has reached a given pressure.
(1998 Code, sec. 86.061(b))
Sec. 8.02.003 Exemptions
This article shall not apply to:
(1) Delegations from neighboring towns and cities visiting in the city on goodwill tours;
(2) The operation of microphones or any mechanical or electrical device, machine or instrument to
intensify the human voice or any other sound at any public or community gathering of a civic or
religious nature;
(3) Community trades day activity; and
(4) Political speakings.
(1998 Code, sec. 86.061(c))
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 213/420
ARTICLE 8.03 WEAPONS*
Sec. 8.03.001 Slingshots
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, discharge, shoot, propel or use on the streets and public property
in the city a weapon or instrument used for propelling missiles, commonly known as a slingshot, or to discharge,
shoot or propel the missiles therefrom over the streets and public property of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 86.091)
Sec. 8.03.002 Discharge of firearms
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any pistol, gun, or firearm of any kind, or discharge any cannon
cracker or torpedo, airgun, air pistol, pellet gun or missile, within the city limits or on or across any public
square, street, or alley in the city. (1998 Code, sec. 86.092)
ARTICLE 8.04 JUNKED VEHICLES*
Sec. 8.04.001 Definitions
Junked vehicle. A vehicle that is self propelled and:
(1) Does not have lawfully attached to it:
(A) An unexpired license plate; or
(B) A valid motor vehicle inspection certificate; and
(2) Is:
(A) Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or
(B) Inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than:
(i) 72 consecutive hours, if the vehicle is on public property; or
(ii) 30 consecutive days, if the vehicle is on private property.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Nuisance vehicle. A junked vehicle that is located in a place where it is visible from a public place or public
right-of-way is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the general public, tends to reduce the value of private
property, invites vandalism, creates fire hazards, constitutes an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health
and safety of minors, and is detrimental to the economic welfare of the city by producing blight adverse to the
maintenance and continuing development of the city, and is a public nuisance.
(1998 Code, sec. 91.051)
Sec. 8.04.002 Penalty
In addition to the other remedies provided by this article and any other remedies provided by applicable state
law, it is hereby expressly provided that any person maintaining a public nuisance upon private property, public
property, or on a public right-of-way, as defined in this article, who fails to remove and abate such public
nuisance after notice as provided in this article and who fails to request a public hearing within a ten (10) day
period as provided in this article, shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a public nuisance. On conviction, the
court shall order removal and abatement of the nuisance. (1998 Code, sec. 91.058)
Sec. 8.04.003 Enforcement
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 214/420
(a) Generally. The provisions of this article and the procedures to be followed for its administration shall be
administered by the chief of police of the city or his designee, provided that the actual removal of vehicles or
parts thereof from property may be performed by any other person duly authorized by the city manager.
(b) Authority to enter private property. A person authorized by this article to administer the procedures
authorized by this article may enter private property for the purpose specified in this article to examine a vehicle
or vehicle part, obtain information as to the identity of the vehicle, and remove or cause the removal of a vehicle
or vehicle part that constitutes a nuisance. The municipal court of the city may issue orders necessary to enforce
the procedures set forth in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 91.052)
Sec. 8.04.004 Notice to remove
(a) Vehicle on private property. When it is determined that such public nuisance is being maintained on
private property within the city, a ten-day notice stating the nature of the public nuisance on private property, and
that it must be removed and abated within ten (10) days, must be mailed to the last known registered owner of
the junked motor vehicle, any lienholder of record, and the owner or occupant of the private premises
whereupon such public nuisance exists, by certified mail with a five-day return requested. Such notice shall
further provide that a request for a hearing must be made by any interested party before the expiration of said
ten-day period. If the notice required herein is returned undelivered by the United States post office, official
action to abate said nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten (10) days from the date of such return.
(b) Vehicle on public property or public right-of-way. When it is determined that such public nuisance is
being maintained upon public property or a public right-of-way within the city, a ten-day notice stating the
nature of the public nuisance on public property or on a public right-of-way, and that it must be removed and
abated within ten (10) days, must be mailed, by certified mail with a five (5) day return requested, to the last
known registered owner of the junked motor vehicle, any lienholder of record, and the owner or occupant of the
public premises or to the owner or occupant of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way on which the
public nuisance exists. If the notice is returned undelivered by the United States post office, official action to
abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than ten (10) days after the date of the return.
(1998 Code, sec. 91.053)
Sec. 8.04.005 Hearing
Within ten (10) days after service of notice to abate the public nuisance, the owner or occupant of the premises
adjacent to the public right-of-way on which the vehicle is located, as the case may be, may request a public
hearing before the city manager prior to the removal, as a public nuisance, of the junked vehicle or any part
thereof. An order by the city manager requiring the removal of a vehicle or vehicle part must include a
description of the vehicle and the correct identification number and license number of the vehicle if the
information is available at the site. (1998 Code, sec. 91.054)
Sec. 8.04.006 Notification to state department of transportation
Notice shall be given to the state department of transportation not later than the fifth day after the date of
removal of any vehicle or part thereof pursuant to the provisions of this article. Such notice shall identify the
vehicle or the vehicle parts thus removed. (1998 Code, sec. 91.055)
Sec. 8.04.007 Disposal to demolisher; reconstruction of removed vehicle prohibited
(a) Disposal. A junked vehicle or vehicle part may be disposed of by removal to a scrap yard, demolisher, or
any suitable site for processing as scrap or salvage. The process of disposal must comply with the provisions of
this article.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 215/420
(b) Reconstruction of removed vehicle prohibited. A junked vehicle that has been removed pursuant to this
article shall not be reconstructed or made operable after it has been removed.
(1998 Code, sec. 91.056)
Sec. 8.04.008 Exceptions
This article shall not apply to:
(1) A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner
where it is not visible from the street or other public or private property;
(2) A vehicle or vehicle part that is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in
connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard; or
(3) An unlicensed operable or inoperable antique or special interest vehicle stored by a collector on
the collector's property, if the vehicle and the outdoor storage area are maintained in a manner so that
they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from ordinary public view by means of a
fence, rapidly growing trees, shrubbery, or other appropriate means.
(1998 Code, sec. 91.057)
ARTICLE 8.05 SEX OFFENDERS' RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS*
Sec. 8.05.001 Prohibition
It is unlawful for any person who is required to register on the state department of public safety sex offender
database (the “database”) under section 62 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure because of a reportable
conviction or adjudication involving a victim younger than seventeen (17) years of age or who has been civilly
committed as a sexually violent predator under chapter 841 of the Texas Health and Safety Code and is subject
to outpatient treatment and supervision under that chapter, to establish a permanent or temporary residence
within 1,000 feet of any premises where children commonly gather, including, but not limited to, a school,
daycare facility, playground, park, ballpark, public or private youth center, public or private swimming pool,
video arcade facility, or church, as those terms are defined in section 481.134 of the Texas Health and Safety
Code. Each and every day such violation shall continue shall be deemed and constitute a separate offense.
Sec. 8.05.002 Evidentiary matters; measurements
(a) It shall be prima facie evidence that this article applies to such a person if that person's record appears on
the database and the database indicates that the victim was a minor.
(b) For the purposes of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be measured by
following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent or temporary residence to the nearest
property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as defined herein, or, in the case of multiple
residences on one property, measuring from the nearest property line of the premises to the nearest property line
of the premises where children commonly gather.
(c) A map depicting the prohibited areas shall be maintained and annually updated by the police department
which shall be available to the public at the police department.
Sec. 8.05.003 Culpable mental state not required
Neither the allegation, nor evidence, of a culpable mental state is required for the proof of an offense defined by
this article.
Sec. 8.05.004 Affirmative defenses
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 216/420
It is an affirmative defense to prosecution that any of the following conditions apply:
(1) The person required to register on the database established the permanent or temporary
residence and has complied with all of the sex offender registration laws of the state prior to the date
of the adoption of this article.
(2) The person required to register on the database was a minor when such person committed the
offense requiring such registration and was not convicted as an adult.
(3) The person required to register on the database is a minor.
(4) The premises where children commonly gather, within 1,000 feet of the permanent or
temporary residence of the person required to register on the database was opened after the person
established the permanent or temporary residence and complied with all sex offender registration
laws of the state.
(5) The information on the database is incorrect, and, if corrected, this article would not apply to
the person who was erroneously listed on the database.
Sec. 8.05.005 Penalty
An offense under the article is deemed to be a misdemeanor and upon conviction be punishable by a fine not to
exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ordinance O-10-09 adopted 11/17/09)
ARTICLE 8.06 CURFEW FOR MINORS*
Sec. 8.06.001 Definitions
For the purposes of this article the following words or terms shall have the meanings given below:
Curfew hours. Those hours between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. each day and those hours between 9:00 a.m.
and 4.00 p.m. on each day the Lamesa Independent School District is officially conducting classes on any of its
campuses.
(Ordinance O-04-16 adopted 4/9/16)
Emergency. An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting conditions that call for immediate
action, including, but not be limited to, a fire, natural disaster, automobile accident, or any unforeseen situation
requiring immediate action to prevent serious illness, bodily injury, loss of life, or for the preservation of
property.
Establishment. Any privately owned place of business to which the public has access or is invited, including, but
not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment.
Guardian. A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor or a public or private
agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court.
Minor. Any person under 17 years of age.
Operator. Any individual, firm, association, partnership, entity, or corporation operating, managing, or
conducting the operation of any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association,
entity, or partnership and the officers of a corporation.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 217/420
Parent. A person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent of a minor, or a person at least 18 years
of age who is authorized by the parent or guardian of a minor or by court order to have the care and custody of
such minor.
Police department. The Lamesa police department and shall include any law enforcement agency working with
the city through any inter-agency agreement.
Public place. Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and shall include, but
not be limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office
buildings, transportation facilities, restaurants, theaters, game rooms, shops, shopping centers, or any other place
that offers for sale services, merchandise, or entertainment services.
Remain. To linger or stay, or to fail to leave, when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator,
or other person in control of the premises.
Sec. 8.06.002 Offenses
(a) It shall be unlawful for any minor to knowingly remain, walk, run, or stand, or to operate or ride about in
any motor vehicle or bicycle, in or upon any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city
during curfew hours.
(b) It shall be unlawful for the parent or guardian of a minor to knowingly permit, or by insufficient control
allow, a minor to knowingly remain, walk, run, or stand, or to operate or ride about in any motor vehicle or
bicycle, in or upon any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours.
Sec. 8.06.003 Defenses
(a) It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under section 8.06.002(a) of this article that a minor was:
(1) Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian;
(2) On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian; provided, however, that the
minor has in his or her possession at the time he is stopped by law enforcement personnel, a written
note signed by the parent or guardian authorizing the errand;
(3) In a motor vehicle involved in intrastate or interstate travel, and traveling by a direct route
between the point of departure and destination;
(4) Engaged in a lawful employment activity, or going directly to the employment activity, or
returning directly to the minor's residence or place designated by the minor's parent or guardian from
the employment activity;
(5) Involved in an emergency;
(6) On an errand made necessary by a verifiable illness, injury, or emergency;
(7) On the sidewalk abutting the minor's permanent residence or place designated by the minor's
parent or guardian or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor of the minor's permanent
residence or place designated by the minor's parent or guardian, if the neighbor did not complain to
the police department about the minor's presence at their residence;
(8) Attending a school, religious, or government-sponsored or other civic activity supervised by
adults and sponsored by an educational, religious, or governmental institution, civic organization, or
other similar entity, or traveling directly to, or returning from, any such activity;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 218/420
(9) Engaged, participating in, or traveling to or from any event, function, or activity for which the
application of section 8.06.002(a) of this article would contravene the minor's rights protected by the
United States Constitution including, but not limited to, First Amendment rights such as the free
exercise of religion, freedom of speech, or the right of assembly; or
(10) Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with
chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code; or
(b) It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under section 8.06.002(a) of this article that the minor has been
directed by the minors parent or guardian to engage in a specific activity or to carry out expressed instructions,
during the time that the minor is actually engaged in fulfilling those directions or responsibilities.
Sec. 8.06.004 Enforcement
(a) A police officer, upon finding a minor in violation of section 8.06.002(a) of this article, shall:
(1) Ascertain the name and address of the minor;
(2) Ascertain the name and address of the minor's parent(s) or guardian(s);
(3) Ask the minor's reason for being in a public place and determine if a defense to prosecution
pursuant to section 8.06.002(a) of this article applies;
(4) If the police officer reasonably believes that the minor is violating section 8.06.002(a) of this
article and that no defense described in section 8.06.003 of this article is present, issue to the minor a
municipal court misdemeanor citation for a violation of said section;
(5) Immediately notify the parent(s) or guardian(s) to pick up the minor at the location where the
minor is being detained, advise the parent(s) or guardian(s) of the fact that the minor was charged
with a violation of this article by issuance of a municipal court misdemeanor citation, soliciting
cooperation in the future, and including a warning that any subsequent violation will possibly result
in prosecution of the parent(s) or guardian(s) pursuant to section 8.06.002(b) of this article.
(6) Submit a copy of the citation to the police department which shall then send a letter to the
parent(s) or guardian(s) of the minor advising of the fact that the minor was charged.
(b) After following the procedures described in subsection (a) above, the police officer may take the minor
into custody and deliver the minor to a holding location if the officer reasonably believes that the minor is in
violation of section 8.06.002(a) of this article, that no defense described in section 8.06.003 of this article is
present, and:
(1) The minor has received a municipal court misdemeanor citation for a violation of section
8.06.002(a) of this article on more than one (1) previous occasion; or
(2) Reasonable grounds exist to believe that the minor has engaged in delinquent conduct or
conduct indicating a need for supervision in accordance with section 51.03 and section 52.01 of the
Texas Family Code.
(c) When a minor is taken into custody under subsection (b) above, the police department shall immediately
notify the minor's parent(s) or guardian(s) to pick up the minor at the holding location. After a parent or guardian
of the minor arrives at the holding location and provides the information required by the police department to
file an incident report, if the officer reasonably believes the parent(s) or guardian(s) has violated section
8.06.002(b) of this article and that no defense described in section 8.06.003 of this article exists, the police
officer may, in his or her discretion, issue to the parent(s) or guardian(s) a municipal court misdemeanor citation
for a violation of section 8.06.002(b) of this article.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 219/420
Sec. 8.06.005 Penalties
(a) A person who shall intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or with criminal negligence violates any provision
of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount not to
exceed $500.00.
(b) When required by section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, as amended, the municipal court shall waive
original jurisdiction over a minor who violates section 8.06.002(a) of this article and shall refer the minor to
juvenile court.
(Ordinance O-04-10 adopted 8/3/10)
CHAPTER 9
PERSONNEL
ARTICLE 9.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 9.01.001 Emergency actions by city officers, agents and employees
Officers, agents, and employees of the city are hereby empowered and authorized to take whatever action is
deemed necessary in response to emergency situations arising within the city in order to deal with such situation
in the most effective manner possible under the existing circumstances. Neither the city nor the officer, agent or
employee of the city shall in any way be liable for any failure to use “ordinary care” in such emergency
situations. This section shall prevail over any other section of this code, ordinance, policy or work rule with
regard to the standard of care to be exercised by an officer, agent or employee engaged in emergency action.
(1998 Code, sec. 5.001(b))
Sec. 9.01.002 Liability for penalty for failure to perform duties
No provision of this code designating the official duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to
make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless
the intention of the city council is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1998 Code,
sec. 5.001(a))
Sec. 9.01.003 Neglect of duty
If any officer of this city shall willfully or negligently fail to perform any duty imposed upon him by any section
of this code or ordinance of the city, he shall, when the act or omission is not otherwise defined, be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. (1998 Code, sec. 5.002)
Sec. 9.01.004 Moneys collected to be submitted to director of finance
All officers and/or employees of the city, whether they be elective or appointive and whose duty it may be to
collect money, shall turn all moneys collected over to the director of finance, who, on call of the city council,
shall submit a detailed report of any or all collections submitted to him. (1998 Code, sec. 5.003)
Sec. 9.01.005 Purchasing or acquiring witness fees
It shall be unlawful for any mayor, councilman, policeman, or other officer of this city, whether elective or
appointive, to purchase or otherwise acquire from the party interested any fee or fees coming to any witness in

https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 220/420
any proceeding whatsoever before the municipal court. (1998 Code, sec. 5.004)
ARTICLE 9.02 EMPLOYEE BENEFITS
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 9.02.001–9.02.030 Reserved
Division 2. Workers' Compensation
Sec. 9.02.031 Adoption of state law
The provisions of the Texas Workers' Compensation Act, Labor Code 401.001 et seq. and 504.001 et seq., are
hereby adopted and made applicable to the city and to all employees thereof. (1998 Code, sec. 6.001)
Sec. 9.02.032 Coverage
By authority of the act referred to in section 9.02.031, the city may elect to be self-insuring or join a joint
insurance fund and all employees of the city are hereby insured by the city in the manner and to the extent
authorized by such act and the laws referred to therein. The city shall pay to any and all employees, and to their
representatives and beneficiaries, the compensation and benefits to which they may become entitled from and
after such time and date under the terms of such act and the workers' compensation laws of the state made
applicable by such act to cities, towns and villages adopting its provisions. (1998 Code, sec. 6.002)
Sec. 9.02.033 Administration of program; notice to employees
(a) Administration. The workers' compensation program shall be administered by the personnel director, or
under his supervision and direction, and he shall promulgate such rules and prescribe such forms as may be
necessary for its effective administration.
(b) Notice to employees. The personnel director, on behalf of the city council, shall give written notice to all
employees of the city that, in accordance with state law, the city has provided workers' compensation insurance
for all of its employees and for payment to each employee, his representatives and beneficiaries, of the workers'
compensation insurance benefits provided by law.
(c) Coordination of claims. The personnel director, on behalf of the city council, shall coordinate all workers'
compensation claims with the state workers' compensation commission.
(1998 Code, sec. 6.003)
Sec. 9.02.034 Risk management and safety fund
(a) Established. There is hereby established an account to be known as the city risk management and safety
fund, from which account [shall] be paid any costs, administrative expenses, charges, benefits, insurance and
awards authorized by the laws adopted and made applicable to the city by sections 9.02.031 and 9.02.032. The
records of such account shall show the appropriations made thereto, all receipts from other sources, and all
disbursements authorized hereby.
(b) Investment of funds. It is further provided that the funds be invested in securities of the United States, [or]
of the city, or deposited in the city's depository.
(1998 Code, sec. 6.004)
Secs. 9.02.035–9.02.070 Reserved

Division 3. Texas Municipal Retirement System*
Sec. 9.02.071 Ordinances on file
The specific ordinances providing for participation in the Texas Municipal Retirement System, as adopted by the

ARTICLE 9.03 POLICE
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 9.03.001 Prisoners
(a) Communications with prisoners. No person, without prior consent of the chief of police, shall hold any
communication with any prisoner confined in the city jail.
(b) Delivery of intoxicants or other articles. It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver to any prisoner
confined in the city jail intoxicating liquors or other articles whatsoever without proper authority.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.002)
Sec. 9.03.002 Refusal to assist officer
Every person who shall refuse to aid or assist the chief of police or any policeman to make any arrest, or to
suppress any disturbance, when called upon to do so by them, shall be fined as provided in this code. (1998
Code, sec. 83.003)
Sec. 9.03.003 Giving false name or address to officer
It shall be unlawful for any person when giving a written promise to appear, or given a written notice by any
police officer to appear before the municipal court of the city to answer for an offense against any law of this
state or section of this code or any ordinance of the city, to give an assumed or fictitious name or a false place of
residence or address, or any other than the true name and the true place of his residence or address, upon the
request of such officer. (1998 Code, sec. 83.004)
Sec. 9.03.004 Arrest without warrant
Arrest without warrant may be made by the chief of police or any other police officer of the city when offenses
against the laws, sections of this code or ordinances of the city are committed in their presence or when persons
are found in suspicious places and under circumstances which reasonably would indicate that such persons have
been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threaten or are about to commit some offense against the
law. (1998 Code, sec. 83.005)
Secs. 9.03.005–9.03.040 Reserved
Division 2. Police Department*
Sec. 9.03.041 Chief of police
(a) Appointment; oath. There shall be appointed by the city manager a chief of police. Before assuming his
duties of office he shall take and subscribe to the oath of office prescribed in the constitution of the state.
(b) Duties.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 222/420
(1) It shall be the duty of the chief of police to execute all process or orders issued to him by the
mayor or other officer of the city having authority to issue same, and to make return thereof
according to law. He shall supervise, control and direct the police force of the city and shall see that
they promptly and faithfully perform their duties. He shall also apportion the police force into
different watches so that the entire city shall be diligently protected at all times, and shall assign each
policeman his round of duty.
(2) The chief shall also be active in quelling riots, disorder and disturbances of the peace within the
city. It shall be his duty to arrest without warrant all violators of the police peace [sic], and all who
obstruct or interfere with him in the execution of the duties of his office, and who shall be guilty of
any disorderly conduct or disturbance whatsoever; and he shall have authority to take suitable and
sufficient bail for the appearance before the corporation court of any person charged with an offense
against any section of this code or ordinance of the city.
(c) Chief of police as officer of court. The chief of police shall, either in person or by deputy, attend upon the
municipal court when in session, shall preserve order therein, and shall promptly and faithfully execute all writs
and processes issued from such court. He shall bring all prisoners for trial before such court at the opening
thereof each day, and shall furnish the city manager with a list of arrests made, by whom made and offenses
charged and the names and residences of witnesses, together with such other and further information as may be
required. He shall enforce and collect all judgments rendered by the court.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.021)
Sec. 9.03.042 Interlocal police assistance
(a) Authority to render assistance. The mayor, city manager or chief of police of the city is authorized to
assign the regularly employed law enforcement personnel of the city police department to assist any other
county or municipality in this state when a state of civil emergency in such other county or municipality has
been declared by proper authority, upon request by such proper authority, and when, in the opinion of such
proper authority, a need exists in such other county or municipality for the services of additional law
enforcement officers to protect the health, life, and property of such other county or municipality, its inhabitants,
and the visitors thereto, by reason of riot, unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force and violence, or
threat thereof by three (3) or more persons acting together or without lawful authority, or during time of natural
disaster or man-made calamity.
(b) Status of officers of other jurisdiction assigned to city. When any law enforcement officer of any other
county or municipality is assigned to this city under authority of an order adopted by the governing body of such
other county or municipality to assist under circumstances as described above which may exist in this city, such
officer shall be deemed a peace officer of this city and shall be under the command of the chief of police of this
city while so assigned, and he shall have all the powers of a regular law enforcement officer of this city as fully
as though he were regularly employed by the city, and his qualifications, respectively, for office where regularly
employed shall constitute his qualification for office in this city, and no other oath, bond, or compensation shall
be made.
(c) Compensation of city officers performing duties outside city. When any law enforcement officer of this
city is ordered by proper authority to perform peace officer duties outside the territorial limits of this city, he
shall be entitled to the same wage, salary, pension, and all other compensation and all other rights for such
service, including injury or death benefits, the same as though the service had been rendered within the limits of
this city; and he shall also be paid for any reasonable expenses of travel, food, or lodging, as well as for damage
to equipment and clothing, and medical expenses, which he may incur while on duty outside such limits, or
while traveling to or from such assignment.
(d) Reimbursement for services of officer of other jurisdiction. When any law enforcement officer is assigned
to this city from another county or city under circumstances described above, and upon request of the proper
authority, this city will reimburse the county or city furnishing the services of such law enforcement officer for
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 223/420
actual expenses of travel, food, and lodging, and for such cost or damage to equipment and clothing resulting
from the services of such law enforcement officer in this city and for which the county or city where he is
regularly employed has paid.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.022)
State law reference–Law enforcement services provided through cooperation of municipalities, counties and certain other local
governments, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 362.001 et seq.
Secs. 9.03.043–9.03.080 Reserved
Division 3. Abandoned or Stolen Property*
Sec. 9.03.081 Sale authorized
All abandoned, stolen or recovered property of every kind, including motor vehicles, which shall remain
unclaimed in the possession of the police department for a period of thirty (30) days without being claimed or
reclaimed by the owner, whether known or not, may be sold at public auction or otherwise disposed of as
provided in article 18.17 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. (1998 Code, sec. 83.041)
Sec. 9.03.082 Delivery of property to purchasing agent
The chief of police shall give to the purchasing agent of the city a list of all property subject to sale under the
provisions of this division, and shall thereafter, when requested by the purchasing agent, deliver such property,
except motor vehicles, to the purchasing agent before the date of sale and take a receipt therefrom showing in
detail all property so delivered. Motor vehicles shall be kept by the chief of police until a sale has been made.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.042)
Sec. 9.03.083 Disposition of proceeds of sale
All funds received for property sold pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be deposited to the credit of
the general fund of the city to be thereafter disbursed as the governing body of the city shall order. (1998 Code,
sec. 83.043)
Secs. 9.03.084–9.03.120 Reserved
Division 4. Police Reserve*
Sec. 9.03.121 Established; maximum number of members
There is hereby established a police reserve force for the city. The police reserve force shall not exceed twenty
members. (1998 Code, sec. 83.081)
Sec. 9.03.122 Appointment and dismissal of members
Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed and/or relieved at the discretion of the chief of police and
shall serve as police officers during the actual discharge of official duties. (1998 Code, sec. 83.082)
Sec. 9.03.123 Qualifications of members
The chief of police may establish minimum physical, mental, educational and moral standards as used by the
regular police department, but in no case shall the standards be less than those established by the state
commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. (1998 Code, sec. 83.083)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 224/420
Sec. 9.03.124 Training of members
Reserve police officers must comply with the minimum training standards of the state commission on law
enforcement officer standards and education established for all reserve law enforcement officers, and such
standards must be met before a person appointed as a reserve law enforcement officer may carry a weapon or
otherwise act as a peace officer. The chief of police shall establish qualifications and standards of training for
members of the police reserve force and shall establish rules and regulations governing reserve police officers.
(1998 Code, sec. 83.084)
State law reference–Commission on law enforcement officer standards and education, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, ch. 1701.
Sec. 9.03.125 Compensation of members; benefits; members to serve in supplementary capacity
Members of the police reserve force shall serve without compensation. Uniforms and uniform compensation
may be provided to the reserve police officers at the discretion of the chief of police. The uniform compensation
shall be based solely upon time served by the member of the police reserve while in training for or in the
performance of official duties. The city may provide hospital and medical assistance to members of the police
reserve force who sustain injury in the course of performing official duties, in the same manner as provided by
the city for its full-time police officers, and reserve officers shall be eligible for death benefits as set out in
chapter 86, Acts of 60th Legislature, Regular Session 1967, as amended (article 6228f V.T.C.S); provided,
however, that nothing in this division shall be construed to authorize or permit a member of the police reserve
force to become eligible for participation in any pension fund created pursuant to state statute, to which regular
officers may become a member by payroll deductions or otherwise. Reserve police officers shall act only in a
supplementary capacity to the regular police force and shall in no case assume the full-time duties of regular
police officers. (1998 Code, sec. 83.085)
State law reference–Hospital and medical assistance and death benefits for police reserve force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code,
sec. 142.003.
Sec. 9.03.126 Call to service
Members of the police reserve force shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and may be called into
active service at any time the chief of police considers it necessary to have additional police officers to preserve
the peace and enforce the laws. (1998 Code, sec. 83.086)
CHAPTER 10
SUBDIVISION REGULATION
ARTICLE 10.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
(Reserved)
ARTICLE 10.02 SUBDIVISION ORDINANCE†
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 10.02.001 Short title
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 225/420
The following regulations shall be and the same are hereby adopted and approved and shall be known as and
may be cited as “City of Lamesa Subdivision Regulation.” (1998 Code, sec. 22.001)
Sec. 10.02.002 Definitions
The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall, for the purpose of this article, have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the
context:
Alleys. Minor ways, which are used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties
otherwise abutting on a street.
Authority. The health authority of the city as provided for in section 6.01.001 of this code.
Board of education. The Lamesa Independent School District.
Cul-de-sac. A street closed at one end.
Lot. An undivided tract or parcel of land having access to a street, either occupied or to be occupied by a
building or building group together with accessory buildings, which parcel of land is designated as a separate
and distinct tract and is identified by a tract or lot number or symbol in a duly approved subdivision plat filed of
record.
May. Is deemed permissive.
Planning commission or commission. The planning and zoning commission of the city.
Shall. Is deemed mandatory.
Street. A way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway,
road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place or however otherwise designated.
(1) Arterial streets and highways are those which are used primarily for fast or heavy traffic.
(2) Collector streets are those which carry traffic from minor streets to the major system of arterial
streets and highways, including the principal entrance streets of a residential development and streets
for circulation within such a development.
(3) Marginal access streets are minor streets which are parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets
and highways; and which provide access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic.
(4) Minor streets are those which are used primarily for access to the abutting properties.
Subdivider. One who owns, controls, develops or creates a subdivision.
Subdivision. The division of a parcel of land into two (2) or more lots or parcels for the purpose of transfer of
ownership or building development, provided that a division of land for agricultural purposes into lots or parcels
of five (5) acres or more and not involving a new street or alley shall not be deemed a “subdivision.” The term
“subdivision” includes resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of
subdividing or to the context [sic], shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.002)
Sec. 10.02.003 Application of article; violations in area within city's extraterritorial jurisdiction
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 226/420
(a) The rules and regulations prescribed in this article shall govern the approval and requirement of plats of
subdivisions within that land or area annexed to the city on or after February 15, 1959, and within the territory
and area outside the city limits over which the city has extraterritorial jurisdiction. This article, in its application,
shall include all of the area within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city, and the provisions of this article
shall have the same force and effect within such area of extraterritorial jurisdiction as within the applicable area
of the city, except as provided in subsections (b) and (c).
(b) No violation of any provision of this article outside the corporate limits of the city, but within the city's
area of extraterritorial jurisdiction, shall constitute a misdemeanor, nor shall any fine provided be applicable to a
violation within such area of extraterritorial jurisdiction.
(c) In the event any provision of this article is violated within the area of extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city
and outside its corporate limits, the city may institute any appropriate action or proceedings in the district court
to enjoin the violation.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.003)
State law reference–Extension of subdivision rules to extraterritorial jurisdiction, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, sec. 212.003.
Sec. 10.02.004 Purpose of procedure, standards specified in article
The procedure and standards for the development, layout and design of subdivisions of real estate within the
corporate limits and extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city as prescribed in this article, are intended to:
(1) Guide, assist and expedite the subdivider in correct procedures to be followed and to inform
them of the general standards which shall be required.
(2) Protect the public interests by controlling the location, design, class and type of streets,
sidewalks, utilities and essential services required.
(3) Provide, for the public welfare, the essential areas required for educational, recreational,
industrial and commercial purposes.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.004)
Sec. 10.02.005 General requirements
The following requirements shall be applicable to all subdivisions within the city or its extraterritorial
jurisdiction:
(1) Streets.
(A) The width of main thoroughfares and traffic streets shall be determined by the planning
commission.
(B) No street dedication shall be less than sixty feet (60') wide.
(C) All new streets shall be continuations of existing streets, of the same or greater width and
having the same names.
(D) Dead-end streets may be platted where the land adjoins property not subdivided, in
which case the streets shall be carried to the boundaries thereof. Where dead-end streets are
otherwise necessary, a cul-de-sac with a minimum radius of fifty feet (50') shall be provided.
(E) No intersecting street shall be platted with the angle included between adjoining street
lines less than thirty degrees (30°) nor more than one hundred fifty degrees (150°).
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 227/420
(F) Streets shall be platted to allow two (2) tiers of lots with an alley between. Intersecting
cross streets may not be more than twelve hundred feet (1200') apart.
(G) Streets shall be platted with appropriate regard to topographical features lending
themselves to attractive treatment.
(H) Where plats are presented for approval which adjoin unplatted property, the owner of the
proposed subdivision shall provide his pro rata part of boundary streets.
(2) Alleys, reserve strips.
(A) Alleys shall be laid in the rear of lots fronting on adjoining streets. The minimum width
of any alley shall not be less than twenty feet (20') and shall be graded and leveled.
(B) Subdivision showing reserve strips of land controlling the access to public ways or
adjoining properties will be approved.
(3) Lots and blocks.
(A) In general, lots shall conform in width, depth and area to the pattern already established
in the adjacent areas, having due regard to the character of the neighborhood, its particular
suitability for development for residential purposes and, also taking into consideration the
natural topography of the ground, drainage, sanitary sewage facilities and the proposed layout
of the streets.
(B) In locations where sanitary sewers are not already available, and where there is no
immediate prospect for installation of sanitary sewers, then septic tanks of approved type may
be installed in conformity with the sections of this code, and rules, regulations and ordinances
of the city pertaining to public health; provided, however, that in no case shall septic tanks be
installed on lots having a frontage of less than sixty feet (60'), and a depth of less than one
hundred twenty-five feet (125'). Provided however, that if the soil texture in the area is such as
will not lend itself to the utilization of a septic tank, then the proposed size of the lots must be
increased to provide for a safe absorption of the effluent, as determined by the city health
authority.
(C) It shall be unlawful for the building inspector to issue a permit for any residence in any
subdivision utilizing as a building site the rear portion of any corner lot, or the rear portion of
any corner lot merged with a portion of any adjoining lot, to produce a plottage of sufficient
size to meet the minimum requirements for a permissible residential use.
(D) The minimum measurements, restrictions and conditions controlling the area and
dimensions of each lot in a subdivision shall conform to the deed restrictions therefor.
(E) For private housing projects and shopping villages, it will not be necessary to subdivide
tracts of land. Site plans, however, must be filed showing the arrangement of the project in
detail, together with essential requirements such as parking facilities, locations of buildings and
the other uses to be permitted.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.005)
Sec. 10.02.006 Changes and variations from article requirements
If it appears that strict observance of the provisions of this article will work undue hardship on the subdivider, or
is made impracticable or impossible due to unusual circumstances, the planning commission may grant such
change or variations from these rules and regulations it deems just and proper, provided that variations of any
one provision hereof in no way affects or mitigates the remainder. (1998 Code, sec. 22.006)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 228/420
Sec. 10.02.007 Flood area and flood damage
The city council will review all subdivision proposals and other proposed new developments to assure that:
(1) All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood damage.
(2) All public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical, and water systems are located,
elevated, and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage, and
(3) Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood hazards, and
(4) Require new or replacement water supply systems and/or sanitary sewage systems to be
designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the
system into floodwaters, and require on-site waste disposal systems to be located so as to avoid
impairment of them or contamination from them during flooding.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.007)
Secs. 10.02.008–10.02.040 Reserved
Division 2. Preliminary Plats
Sec. 10.02.041 Prerequisites to conditional approval
The subdivider shall have prepared a preliminary plat, together with improvement plans and other
supplementary material as required by this article. Six (6) copies of the preliminary plat with written application
for conditional approval shall be submitted to the city building inspector's office not less than ten (10) days prior
to the meeting of the planning commission at which it is to be considered. The following notice shall be stamped
on the face of each preliminary plat by the city engineer: “Preliminary plat for inspection purposes only and in
no way official or approved for record purposes” and shall have the other designated city department and the
board of education review the plat and written comments relative to the conformity thereof with the provisions
of this article. (1998 Code, sec. 22.021)
Sec. 10.02.042 Scale, contents
The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') and shall include
the following items:
(1) Boundary, street, alley and building lines.
(2) Width and names of streets and location with reference to all streets and alleys adjacent to and
leading to the subdivision.
(3) Width and depth of all lots.
(4) Watercourses and drainageways.
(5) Contour lines on not more than one foot (1') intervals with elevations based on USC and GS
datum.
(6) Layout, in dotted lines, of all lots adjacent to the subdivision showing lot size, lot and block
numbers, and the name of the existing subdivision or the name of the property owner if undeveloped
land, all shown in dotted lines and figures.
(7) Scale and north point.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 229/420
(8) Name and address of subdivider.
(9) Name and address of engineer and surveyor.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.022)
Sec. 10.02.043 Duties of city officials, departments, etc., to check subdivision features
Upon receipt of an application for approval of a subdivision and the preliminary plat required by this article, the
following items shall be checked by the designated official, department or other agency:
(1) Building inspector.
(A) Contour map and drainage.
(B) Street layout and proposed street grades.
(C) Type of paving.
(D) Boundary lines.
(E) Monuments and benchmarks.
(F) Protective covenant restrictions.
(G) Location and width of alleys.
(H) Building lines and setback requirements.
(I) Occupancy regulations and requirements.
(J) Lot and block numbers.
(K) Street numbering layout.
(L) Street names.
(2) Water and wastewater department.
(A) Availability of adequate water and sewer mains to the subdivision.
(B) Water system layout and probable fire hydrant locations.
(C) Sanitary sewer layout and sewer easement designations.
(3) Electric utility company.
(A) General power line layout.
(B) Location of necessary guy easements.
(C) Availability of lines for adequate service conditions.
(D) Future streetlight service.
(4) Board of education.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 230/420
(A) Probable new school sites.
(5) Natural gas utility company.
(A) Availability of adequate gas mains to the subdivision.
(B) Gas system layout.
(6) Telephone utility company.
(A) General cable line layout.
(B) Location of necessary guy easements.
(C) Availability of lines for adequate service conditions.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.023)
Sec. 10.02.044 Conditional approval
Following a review of the preliminary plat and other material submitted for conformity thereof to these
regulations and negotiations with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and extent of
improvements to be made by him, the planning commission shall, within (30) days, act thereon as submitted or
modified. If the plat be approved, the planning commission shall express its approval as conditional approval
and state the conditions of such approval, if any, or if disapproved shall express its disapproval and its reason
therefor with a recommendation to the city council for further action by that body. The action of the planning
commission shall be noted on all six (6) copies of the preliminary plat, referred and attached to any conditions
determined. One (1) copy shall be returned to the subdivider, one (1) copy retained by the planning engineer and
the others retained by the city engineer, after it has been considered by the council. Conditional approval of a
preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat; rather it shall be deemed an expression of
approval to the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat which will
be submitted for approval of the planning commission and for recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of
these regulations and the conditions of the conditional approval, if any. (1998 Code, sec. 22.024)
Sec. 10.02.045 Notification requirement for certain replats
Where any of the area to be resubdivided or replatted was, within the immediate preceding five (5) years, limited
by an interim or permanent zoning classification to residential use for not more than two dwelling units per lot,
or if any lot in the preceding plat was limited by deed restrictions to residential use for not more than two
residential units per lot, then the following additional procedures shall apply:
(1) Notice of the public hearing shall be published at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing, in
a newspaper of general circulation in the county.
(2) Written notice of the public hearing shall be mailed to the owners (according to the most
recently approved ad valorem tax roll) of all lots that are within the original subdivision and that are
within 200 feet of the lots to be replatted, together with a copy of Section 212.015(c) in the Local
Government Code for the State of Texas.
(3) If the proposed replat is protested in accordance with this subsection, the proposed replat must
receive, in order to be approved, the affirmative vote of at least three-fourths of the members present
of the planning commission and/or city council, as applicable. For a legal protest, written instruments
signed by the owners of at least 20 percent of the area of the lots or land immediately adjoining the
area covered by the proposed replat and extending 200 feet from that area, but within the original
subdivision, must be filed with the municipal authority responsible for approving the replat, prior to
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 231/420
the close of the public hearing. In computing this percentage of land area, the area of streets and
alleys shall be included within the adjacent lots.
(4) Compliance with subsection (3) above is not required for approval of a replat of part of a
preceding plat, if the area to be replatted was designated or reserved for other than single or twofamily
residential use, by notation on the last legally recorded plat or in the legally recorded
restrictions applicable to the plat.
(Ordinance adopting Code)
Secs. 10.02.046–10.02.080 Reserved
Division 3. Final Plats
Sec. 10.02.081 Generally
(a) The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat, as approved; and, if desired by the
subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which he proposes to record and
develop at the time, provided however, that such portion conforms to all requirements of this article.
(b) In cases where a final plat is submitted for approval and where no change from the approved preliminary
plat has been made, it will not be necessary for the planning commission to pass upon such final plat before the
same is presented to the city council for approval. When such procedure is not necessary, such final plat shall be
approved by the engineering department; provided however, that the engineering department shall not consider
final approval of the plat unless the same has been delivered thereto on or before the Thursday immediately
preceding the regular meeting of the city council.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.031)
Sec. 10.02.082 Effect of change prior to submission
In the event that changes or alterations are made to the plat before submitted as final, the final plat shall be filed
with the office of the city engineer not less than five (5) days before the meeting of the planning commission at
which it is considered. The city engineer will check the plat as to compliance with this article and prepare a
report to be submitted to the planning commission along with the plat. (1998 Code, sec. 22.032)
Sec. 10.02.083 Scale, contents, etc.
(a) Number and size. A reproducible sepia and three (3) copies of the final plat shall be drawn upon sheets
twenty-four inches by thirty inches (24" x 30") and to a scale of not less than one inch equals one hundred feet
(1" = 100'). Where more than one sheet is required, an index sheet twenty-four inches by thirty inches (24" x
30") shall be filed showing the entire subdivision on the one sheet.
(b) Boundary symbol. The shape and the exterior boundaries of the land subdivided shall be indicated by the
use of a distinctive and individual symbol.
(c) Dimensions. The length of all straight lines, deflection angles, radii, arcs and central angles of all curves
shall be given along the property lines of each street or tabulated on the same sheet by showing all curve data
with its symbol. All dimensions along the lines of each lot, together with the angles of intersection which they
make with each other, shall be indicated.
(d) Adjacent landmarks. The names of all adjoining subdivisions, the side lines of abutting lots, lot and block
numbers, all in dotted lines, shall be indicated with, where possible, accurate reference ties to at least two
adjacent recognized land corners.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 232/420
(e) Survey monuments. The description and location of all survey monuments placed in the subdivision shall
be given. Two (2) permanent concrete monuments shall be placed on one of the longer lines of the subdivision as
far apart as possible, and still being visible to each other; with the azimuth and distance between them and from
each of them to the nearest boundary corner of the subdivision accurately established and recorded on the plat.
Such monuments shall be not less than ten inches (10") in diameter if poured in a drilled hole or not less than six
inches (6") if poured in a pipe; they shall be set at least one foot (1') in good caliche or in sound rock, and
backfilled with concrete. The exact point in the top of the monument shall be marked by a copper or brass bolt
set in the concrete with a cross filed or scored thereon.
(f) Title, general information. A title shall be included showing the name of the subdivision, the name of the
subdivider, scale and the location of the subdivision, with reference to original surveys and a north point, which
may be magnetic or true north, with notation stating which.
(g) Survey's certificate. A survey's certificate shall be placed on the plat in the following form:
KNOW ALL MEN BY THESE PRESENTS:
That I, ____________, do hereby certify that I prepared this plat from an actual and accurate
survey of the land and that the corner monuments shown thereon were properly placed under
my personal supervision, in accordance with the Subdivision Regulations of the City of
Lamesa, Texas.
(h) Certificate of ownership, dedication of land. A certificate of ownership and of dedication of all streets,
alleys, easements and lands to public use forever, signed and acknowledged before a notary public by the owner
of land, shall appear on the face of map, and shall contain a complete and accurate description of the land
subdivided and the streets dedicated.
(i) Certificate of approval. The certificate of approval by the city council which shall be place[d] on plat, shall
be in the following form:
Approved this ______ day of ______________, _____, by the City Council of the City of
Lamesa, Texas.
Mayor
City Secretary
(j) Deed restrictions. The subdivider shall furnish the city a copy of his deed restrictions and the authorization
for the city to record the plat and deed restrictions at the same time the final plat is submitted for approval.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.033)
Sec. 10.02.084 Approval
After final approval, the mayor and city secretary shall sign the reproducible sepia, and the developer shall then
have the plat filed for record and a certified copy returned immediately to the city secretary. No work shall be
started by the city before such certified copy is returned. (1998 Code, sec. 22.034)
Secs. 10.02.085–10.02.120 Reserved
Division 4. Improvements

Sec. 10.02.121 Agreement for improvements and utilities; escrow deposit
(a) After the final plat has been approved and before any improvements are made or utilities installed, the
engineering department will complete a preliminary engineering survey and study detail to determine the
requirements for such work. The subdivider will then be required to enter into a contract agreement with the city
authorizing the construction of the necessary water and sewer extensions to provide service to the subdivision.
The subdivider shall agree to pay into an escrow construction account an amount equal to one hundred percent
(100%) of the estimated costs of the required extensions and engineering. This cost will be based upon estimated
quantities, as determined by the engineering department from their preliminary survey and study, using the
lowest unit prices received for each phase of construction, as established by formal or informal proposals from at
least two (2) outside contractors at the time the work is to be done.
(b) The city will furnish the necessary engineering and furnish supervision of construction, at a cost to the
subdivider, provided that outside contracts can be awarded upon a unit cost basis.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.041)
Sec. 10.02.122 Street signs and markers; installation, cost
Street signs and markers, in accordance with standards adopted by the city, will be required at each intersection
within the subdivision and at street entrances into the subdivision. An advance deposit in an amount equal to the
actual cost of the signs alone will be made by the subdivider at the time the utility agreement is completed. The
city will provide posts for the markers and make the installations as the subdivision progresses, with all signs in
place by the time the subdivision is open for use. (1998 Code, sec. 22.042)
Sec. 10.02.123 Completion, deposit as prerequisite to issuance of building, plumbing, electrical permits
No building permit, or any water, sewer, plumbing or electrical permit shall be issued by the city to the owner or
any other person with respect to any property in said subdivision or resubdivision covered by this article until:
(1) The developer and/or owner has fully completed and paid for the improvements required to be
made by the terms of this article, including the installation of streets with proper paving, curb and
gutter, drainage structures, storm sewers, alleys and the installation of water and sanitary sewer
mains, all according to the specifications of the city; or
(2) An escrow deposit sufficient to pay for the cost of such improvements as determined by the city
engineer computed on a private commercial rate basis has been made with the city secretary,
accompanied by an agreement signed by the developer and/or owner authorizing the city to make
such improvements at prevailing private commercial rates or to have the same made by a private
contractor and paid for out of the escrow deposit.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.043)
Sec. 10.02.124 Work to be done by city; responsibility of city
The city will:
(1) Make all water service taps at their regular charge for such service.
(2) (A) Install or construct all water and sanitary sewer mains as approved on the plans
either directly or by contract.
(B) The water and sewer lines as completed will become the property of the city and the
developer or builder shall have no right or title in same and the city will maintain said lines at
its own expense. Extensions of said lines may be made at any time the city may desire.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 234/420
(C) The city shall never be liable for payment of interest on any deposits, payments or
refunds provided for herein.
(D) The builder or developer shall never have the right to demand payment hereunder out of
any funds of the city.
(3) Not reimburse any part of the cost of engineering, constructing paving, curb and gutter,
drainage structures, storm sewers, street name signs, water and sanitary sewer mains that are
necessary to serve the subdivision.
(4) Upon approval by the city council, pay to the developer of a subdivision within the city, the
difference of cost in extending a water and sewer main in excess of mains necessary to serve the
subdivision, provided the city council finds that water and sewer main in excess of mains necessary
to serve the same is necessary to take care of future development and is beneficial and necessary to
maintain adequate flow of water and sewer.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.044)
Sec. 10.02.125 Storm sewers; installation, expense
(a) Plans and specifications for the improvements enumerated in section 10.02.123 shall meet the approval of
the engineering department. If it is determined that additional drainage facilities in the form of storm sewers
within the subdivision are necessary, the developer shall prepare, with the approval of the engineering
department, plans and specifications to be used by him in correcting the drainage. All such work necessary to be
done under such plans and specifications shall be done at the sole expense of the developer. Storm sewers
required to provide drainage from the point where stormwater emanates from the subdivision to an adequate
drainage point along existing streets, may, at its discretion, be provided by the city.
(b) In the event that the cost of the storm drain construction is so great as to be prohibitive for either the
subdivider or the city, all areas affected by such drainage shall be omitted from the development.
(1998 Code, sec. 22.045)
Sec. 10.02.126 Final accounting between city and developer for water and wastewater mains
A final accounting of each project shall be the basis of final settlement with the developer for actual costs of
water and wastewater mains and shall, in all cases, be one hundred percent (100%) of the actual costs of the
project, including engineering, based on the unit prices set out in the agreement. In the event that it is impossible
to award a contract for such work upon unit price basis, it will then become the obligation of the developer to
provide complete engineering information, including plans and specifications, on which contractors may bid, to
determine a lump sum price for such work. The ratio of payment between the developer and the city shall remain
the same, with one hundred percent (100%) of such costs by the developer. (1998 Code, sec. 22.046)
Sec. 10.02.127 Temporary water service to structures under construction
The city may furnish temporary water service to houses, buildings or other structures under construction.
Temporary water service may be provided upon application at any desired location. The developer shall be
required upon application for such service to pay all unrecoverable cost of such temporary service, to pay such
tap charge as required by the city, and to make such deposits as required by the city for water service, before
temporary service is provided. The developer shall be refunded the deposit for water service, less the amount of
water used, upon the termination of temporary water service. (1998 Code, sec. 22.047)
Sec. 10.02.128 Small tract subdivisions
Any subdivider proposing to subdivide and bring into the city limits City of Lamesa, Texas a tract of land the
total size of which does not exceed one acre may apply to the city council of the City of Lamesa, Texas for
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 235/420
authority to subdivide said tract and bring it into the city limits of the City of Lamesa, Texas without providing
for the installation of paving, curb and gutter with respect to the streets of said subdivision and without paying
for the cost of constructing water and sewer lines to said subdivision. Any subdivider making application to the
city council as herein provided shall contain in his application to the city council an obligation binding on the
subdivider, his heirs and assigns, that at such time that any street or streets within said subdivision or abutting
said subdivision are paved, either voluntarily or by assessment, the subdivider shall pay the cost thereof to the
city on the same basis that adjoining property owners pay for same. Said application shall also contain a
subdivider's agreement to not contest in any way the paving of said subdivision and shall also contain an
obligation binding upon the subdivider, his heirs and assigns, that at such time as the property within the
subdivision is assessed for the cost of providing sewer and water to the subdivision, the subdivider, his heirs and
assigns, shall not contest the same and shall pay the cost thereof to the city on the same basis that the city
charges subdividers who are required to pay the cost of such services at the time their subdivision is brought into
the city limits. (1998 Code, sec. 22.048)
CHAPTER 11
TAXATION
ARTICLE 11.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 11.01.001 Payment of taxes; penalties
The provisions of state law applicable to municipalities shall apply to and govern the payment of taxes due and
owing to the city and penalties in connection therewith, to the same extent as if such provisions have been, by
the terms thereof, made applicable to city taxes by ordinances of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 16.001)
State law references–Imposition of penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, secs. 33.01, 33.07, 33.08.
Sec. 11.01.002 Tax liens
(a) Creation. A lien is hereby created on all property, personal and real, in favor of the city for all taxes owed
in connection with that particular item of property, ad valorem, occupation or otherwise. Such lien shall exist
from the first of January in each year until all the taxes are paid. Such lien shall be prior to all other claims and
liens then existing or thereafter arising, and no gift, sale, assignment or transfer of any kind or judicial writ of
any kind can ever defeat such lien.
(b) Date of attachment. The lien for taxes created above shall attach to all property of the taxpayer owned on
the first of January and subsequently acquired, whether assessed or not.
(1998 Code, sec. 16.002)
Charter reference–Tax liens, art. V, sec. 3.
State law reference–Tax liens, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, ch. 32.
Sec. 11.01.003 Freeport goods
The city elects to tax that tangible personal property described in article VIII, section 1-j, subsection (a) of the
constitution of the state and section 11.251 of the Texas Property Tax Code, which would otherwise be exempt.
(1998 Code, sec. 16.003)
