ARTICLE 12.06 PEDESTRIANS*
Sec. 12.06.001 Generally
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic-control signals at intersections as provided in this chapter, but at all other
places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 92.081)
Sec. 12.06.002 Crosswalks
(a) Right-of-way in crosswalks.
(1) When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall
yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 295/420
roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the
vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the
roadway as to be in danger, but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and
walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield.
(2) Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an
intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching
from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle.
(b) Use of crosswalk mandatory at certain places.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross any street or roadway in the fire limits of the
city except in a designated crosswalk.
(2) Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, pedestrians
shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk.
(c) Use of right half of crosswalk. Pedestrians shall move, whenever possible, upon the right half of
crosswalks.
(1998 Code, sec. 92.082)
State law references–Pedestrian right-of-way at crosswalk, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.003; pedestrian to keep to right,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.004; crossing at other than crosswalk, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.005.
Sec. 12.06.003 Use of roadway
(a) Roadways with sidewalks. Where sidewalks are provided it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk
along and upon an adjacent roadway.
(b) Roadways without sidewalk. Where sidewalks are not provided any pedestrian walking along and upon a
highway or street shall when possible walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic
which may approach from the opposite direction.
(c) Hitchhiking. No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any
vehicle.
(1998 Code, sec. 92.083)
State law references–Pedestrian walking along roadway, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.006; solicitation of ride by
pedestrian, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.007.
Sec. 12.06.004 Drivers to exercise due care
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care when
traveling upon any roadway to avoid colliding with any pedestrian and shall give warning by sounding the horn
when necessary and shall exercise proper caution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated
person upon a roadway. (1998 Code, sec. 92.084)
State law reference–Drivers to exercise due care, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 552.008.
ARTICLE 12.07 BICYCLES AND PLAY VEHICLES*
Sec. 12.07.001 Use of roller skates, skateboards, etc., prohibited in certain places
(a) Definitions.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 296/420
Downtown district. That area of the city lying south of North 2nd Street, west of Dallas Avenue, north of South
2nd Street, and east of Avenue G.
Rollerblades. Shoes with inline wheels located along their soles, used for gliding or rolling along a hard surface.
Roller skates. Shoes with a pair of small wheels located on the ends, used for gliding or rolling along a hard
surface.
Scooter. A foot-operated or engine-powered vehicle consisting of a narrow board mounted between two wheels
tandem, with an upright steering handle attached to the front wheel.
Skateboard. Any device propelled by human power upon which a person may ride, consisting of a short, oblong
board with four or more wheels, typically ridden in a standing position.
(b) Downtown district. No person shall ride rollerblades, scooters, skateboards, roller skates or other similar
devices on or along the sidewalks or on any square or park within the downtown district of the city.
(c) Areas outside downtown district. No person shall ride rollerblades, scooters, skateboards, roller skates or
other similar devices on any public or private property located within the city outside the downtown district
where such activity is prohibited by one or more signs conspicuously displayed upon such property by or at the
direction of the owner or lawful occupier of such property. Signs prohibiting such activity must state that a
violation may subject the violator to a fine up to $500.00.
(d) Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon
conviction shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00.
(1998 Code, secs. 92.085–92.088)
Sec. 12.07.002 Riding roller skates, coasters or similar devices on roadway
No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon
any roadway except while crossing a street or a crosswalk, and when so crossing such person shall be granted all
of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. (1998 Code, sec. 92.003(b))
Sec. 12.07.003 Riding on bicycle; lights on bicycles
(a) Use of seat. A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat
attached thereto.
(b) Passengers. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is
designed and equipped.
(c) Riding on sidewalk. No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district.
(d) Lights. Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit
a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred feet (500') to the front and with a red reflector on the
seat of a type which shall be visible from all distances from fifty feet (50') to three hundred feet (300') to the rear
when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle.
(1998 Code, sec. 92.003(c))
State law references–General operation, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code, sec. 551.102; safety equipment, V.T.C.A., Transportation
Code, sec. 551.104.
ARTICLE 12.08 IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 297/420
Sec. 12.08.001 Impounding uninsured vehicles
(a) A police officer is authorized to remove or cause to remove a vehicle from a public street to a place
designated by the chief of police when:
(1) The vehicle is involved in an accident and the vehicle's owner or operator fails to show proof of
established financial responsibility as required under chapter 601 of the Texas Transportation Code,
as amended; or
(2) The vehicle is stopped by a police officer for an alleged violation of a city or state traffic law or
other law applicable to the operation of a vehicle on the roadway, and the vehicle's operator fails to
show proof of established financial responsibility as required under chapter 601 of the Texas
Transportation Code, as amended.
(b) A vehicle removed and towed under this section must be kept at the place designated by the chief of police
until application for redemption is made by the owner or the owner's authorized agent, who will be entitled to
possession of the vehicle upon payment of costs of towing, notification, impoundment, storage, and upon
showing proof of financial responsibility. Fees for vehicles impounded under this section shall be in accordance
with the currently active section 4.08.003 of this code - wrecker service fees.
(c) The chief of police or a designated representative may release a vehicle without payment of fees if
subsequent or investigation results in a determination that there was no violation of this code of the Texas Motor
Vehicle Laws. Furthermore, the city may reimburse the wrecker service company for the towing and storage fees
as approved by chief of police and city manager.
(Ordinance O-05-11 adopted 4/19/11)
CHAPTER 13
UTILITIES
ARTICLE 13.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 13.01.001 Ordinances saved from repeal
The repeal provided for in the ordinance adopting this code shall not affect any ordinance relating to the granting
of any franchise or the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities, or any ordinance purporting to be an
agreement between the city and a utility company, excepting as this code may contain provision for such
matters, in which case this code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect of such
provisions only. (1998 Code, sec. 47.001)
Sec. 13.01.002 Third party natural gas sales
(a) Definitions.
Consumer. Any individual person, corporation, company, partnership, firm, unincorporated association, trust,
state agency, government entity, political subdivision of the state, school district, institution of higher learning,
or public corporation that uses or consumes natural gas within the corporate limits of the city.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 298/420
Permit. The right, license, and privilege granted by the city to a consumer or seller to use the public ways for the
purpose of transporting gas owned by any party other than the transporter and to be used or consumed by
consumer.
Permittee. A consumer or seller granted a permit under this section.
Pipeline system. A gas system installed in the public ways and consisting of works, pipes, pipelines, apparatus,
machinery, structures, appliances, and appurtenances reasonably necessary for the sale, transportation, or
distribution of natural gas.
Public way. Any street, alley, avenue, boulevard, lane, park, parkway, sidewalk, driveway, utility easement, or
right-of-way, and any other public ways, places, areas, or grounds within the corporate limits of the city as now
constituted or as may be added hereafter.
Purchase price. The total purchase price paid by a consumer to a seller for natural gas that is used or consumed
within the corporate limits of the city and that is transported to the consumer through a pipeline system.
Seller. Any individual person, corporation, company, partnership, firm, unincorporated association, trust, or
public corporation (excluding, however, any transporter) that sells natural gas to any consumer, which natural
gas is transported to the consumer through a pipeline system.
Transporter. Any individual person, corporation, company, partnership, firm, unincorporated association, trust
or public corporation that transports and delivers gas owned by any party other than the transporter through the
transporter's pipeline system.
(b) Permit required.
(1) No consumer shall receive, directly or indirectly, gas within the city that was purchased from a
seller outside of the corporate limits of the city and that is to be transported through any pipeline
system installed in the public ways unless the consumer or the seller shall hold a valid permit from
the city. Such permit shall be issued for the purpose of granting the permittee authority to use the
public ways.
(2) After the operative date of this section, no transporter shall enter into any agreement or
arrangement by which natural gas owned by any party other than such transporter shall be transported
through any portion of the transporter's pipeline system for delivery to any consumer within the
corporate limits of the city unless:
(A) The consumer or seller shall have obtained a permit from the city for the use of the
public ways in transporting and delivering gas pursuant to such agreement or arrangement;
(B) If requested by the city, the transporter agrees to collect from the permittee any and all
fees to be paid pursuant to such permit and to remit such fees so collected to the city on a
monthly basis; and
(C) The transporter agrees to report to the city, on a monthly basis, all volumes transported
through its pipeline system for delivery to any consumer within the corporate limits of the city
pursuant to any such agreement or arrangement.
(3) This section shall not apply to or affect any transportation agreements or arrangements that are
in existence as of the effective date of this section.
(c) Fee. In consideration of the issuance of a permit by the city, a permittee shall pay to the city a fee for the
use of the public ways in an amount equal to three percent (3%) of the purchase price of the gas transported or
delivered within the city during the preceding calendar month for consumption or use within the corporate limits
of the city.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 299/420
(d) Application for permit; issuance.
(1) Every application for a permit, as required in this section, shall be in writing and shall include
the following information:
(A) The date of the application;
(B) The name of the applicant;
(C) The address of the principal place of business of the applicant;
(D) The name and address of the principal place of business of the consumer of the natural
gas;
(E) The name and address of the principal place of business of the seller of the natural gas;
(F) The name of and the principal place of business address of the transporter of the natural
gas;
(G) The date that the applicant proposes to begin delivery of said natural gas;
(H) The name of the party who is to be responsible for the collection and payment of all fees
pursuant to said permit; and
(I) The proposed purchase price of the gas to be transported or delivered within the city.
(2) Every application for a permit shall be filed with the city secretary at least sixty (60) days
before the proposed date to begin delivery of the natural gas.
(3) The city council shall, within sixty (60) days of the filing of the application for a permit, as
required in this section, first consider the application to determine whether or not the application
complies with all respects and provisions of this section, and if it does so comply, pass an ordinance
issuing said permit.
(4) Any permit issued shall contain the following material terms:
(A) The permittee shall pay the fee set forth in subsection (c) of this section to either the city
or transporter, as the case may be, on a monthly basis, according to the city's direction;
(B) The permittee shall grant to the city the right to audit at reasonable times the books and
records of the permittee to verify the correct payment of the fee set forth in subsection (c) of
this section; and
(C) The permit shall specify the beginning and ending dates that the permit will be effective;
provided that said permit not be granted for a period to exceed five (5) years and may be
granted for a lesser period upon the discretion of the city council.
(e) Penalty for operation without permit; revocation of permit.
(1) Any consumer or seller adjudged guilty of operating without the permit required by subsection
(b) of this section shall be subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense, and
each day of a continuing violation shall be deemed a separate offense.
(2) A permit may be revoked by the city, upon action by the city council, at any time, upon ten (10)
days' prior written notice to the permittee and transporter.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 300/420
(1998 Code, sec. 47.021)
ARTICLE 13.02 SOLID WASTE*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.02.001 Purpose; scope
This article covers all aspects of solid waste management under the authority of the city and is enacted to
implement the stated purpose of the Solid Waste Disposal Act, chapter 361, Texas Health and Safety Code, as
amended; the Municipal Solid Waste Regulations as promulgated by the state commission on environmental
quality; and the Comprehensive Municipal Solid Waste Management, Resource Recovery, and Conservation
Act. (1998 Code, sec. 71.001)
Sec. 13.02.002 Applicability of article
The provisions of this article shall apply to all territory within the corporate limits of the city and to any and all
territory subsequently annexed into said corporate limits and to the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city as
specified, and shall apply to any individual, corporation, organization, government, governmental subdivision or
agency, business trust, partnership, association, or other legal entity, including all federal installations involved
in any aspect of the collection, storage, handling, transportation, processing, or disposal of any solid wastes
within the city limits. (1998 Code, sec. 71.002)
Sec. 13.02.003 Applicability of Solid Waste Disposal Act
The provisions of the Solid Waste Disposal Act, chapter 361, Texas Health and Safety Code, shall apply, and the
city shall exercise all authority granted under said statute when it appears that a violation of said statute, or any
rule, regulation, permit, license, or other order of the state commission on environmental quality granted in said
statute, occurs or is occurring within the jurisdiction or extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city, or is causing or
will cause injury to or an adverse effect on the health, welfare or physical property of the city or its inhabitants.
The city may cause a civil suit to be instituted in district court through its own attorney for the injunctive relief,
or civil penalties, or both, as authorized in said statute, against the person who committed, is committing, or is
threatening to commit the violation. (1998 Code, sec. 71.003)
Sec. 13.02.004 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following words and terms have the meanings ascribed to them by this
section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise:
Apartment. A room or suite of rooms arranged, designed or occupied by a family, and shall include, but not
exclusively, a subordinate dwelling occupied as a garage apartment or a servant's quarters.
Apartment house. A building or portion thereof, or buildings, arranged, designed or occupied by three (3) or
more families.
Asbestos-containing materials. Includes the following:
(1) Category I nonfriable asbestos-containing material (ACM). Asbestos-containing packings,
gaskets, resilient floor covering, and asphalt roofing products containing more than 1.0% asbestos as
determined using the method specified in appendix A, subpart F, 40 CFR, part 763, section 1,
Polarized Light Microscopy.
(2) Category II nonfriable ACM. Any material, excluding category I nonfriable ACM, containing
more than 1.0% asbestos as determined using the methods specified in appendix A, subpart F, 40
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 301/420
CFR, part 763, section 1, Polarized Light Microscopy, that, when dry, cannot be crumbled,
pulverized, or reduced to powder by hand pressure.
(3) Friable ACM. Any material containing more than 1.0% asbestos that, when dry, can be
crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder by hand pressure.
(4) Nonfriable ACM. Any material containing more than 1.0% asbestos that, when dry, cannot be
crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder by hand pressure.
Authorized landfill employee. Any employee of the city assigned to the sanitation department, including the
sanitation superintendent, all landfill attendants, operators and technicians, sanitation truck drivers, the city
manager, and any other employee engaged in enforcement of the provisions of this article.
Battery. An electrochemical device that generates electric current by converting chemical energy. Its essential
components are positive and negative electrodes made of more or less electrically conductive materials, a
separate medium, and an electrolyte. There are four major types:
(1) Primary batteries (dry cells);
(2) Storage or secondary batteries;
(3) Nuclear and solar cells or energy converters; and
(4) Fuel cells.
Battery acid (also known as electrolyte acid). A solution of not more than 47% sulfuric acid in water suitable for
use in storage batteries, which is water white, odorless, and practically free from iron.
Brush. Tree trimmings, weeds, large hedge trimmings and trees.
CFR. Code of Federal Regulations.
Collection. The act of removing solid waste (or materials which have been separated for the purpose of
recycling) for transportation elsewhere.
Collection system. The total process of collecting and transporting solid waste. It includes dumpsters or other
collection containers, collection crews, vehicles, equipment and management, and operating procedures.
Commercial solid waste. All types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other
nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes.
Conditionally exempt small-quantity generator. A person who generates no more than 220 pounds of hazardous
waste in a calendar month.
Construction and demolition waste. Waste which typically results from construction or demolition projects, and
includes all materials which are directly or indirectly the byproducts of construction work or which result from
demolition of buildings and other structures, including but not limited to paper cartons, gypsum board, wood,
excelsior, rubber, and plastics.
Container. A mechanically loaded refuse container as defined below.
Customer. A person legally consuming and paying for service from the sanitation department or sanitary landfill
of the city.
Discard. To abandon a material and not use, reuse, reclaim, or recycle it. A material is abandoned by being
disposed of or burned or incinerated (except where the material is being burned as a fuel for the purpose of
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 302/420
recovering usable energy); or physically, chemically, or biologically treated (other than burned or incinerated) in
lieu of or prior to being disposed.
Disposal. The discharge, disposal, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking, or placing of any solid waste or
hazardous waste (whether containerized or uncontainerized) into any land or water so that such solid waste or
hazardous waste or any constituent thereof may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged
into any waters, including groundwaters.
Dumpster. A mechanically loaded refuse container as defined below.
EPA. United States Environmental Protection Agency.
Excessive weight or volume. A weight or volume which exceeds or impairs the ability of the city's mechanical
loading equipment to empty or load the contents of a mechanically loaded refuse container, or any weight
exceeding one thousand pounds (1000 lbs.).
Family. One (1) or more individuals living as a single housekeeping unit.
Garbage. Solid waste consisting of putrescible animal and vegetable waste materials resulting from the
handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food, including waste materials from markets, storage
facilities, handling, and sale of produce and other food products.
Generator. Any person, by site or location, whose act or process produces a solid waste or first causes it to
become regulated.
Hazardous household waste. Any solid waste generated in a household by a consumer, which, except for the
exclusion provided in 40 Code of Federal Regulations 261.4(b)(1), would be classified as a hazardous waste
under 40 Code of Federal Regulations, part 261.
Hazardous waste. Any solid waste identified or listed as a hazardous waste by the administrator of the U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource
and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq., as amended.
Household waste. Any solid waste (including garbage, trash, and sanitary waste in septic tanks) derived from
households (including single and multiple residences, hotels, and motels, bunkhouses, ranger stations, crew
quarters, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day-use recreation areas); does not include yard waste or brush that
is completely free of any household wastes.
Industrial hazardous waste. Hazardous waste determined to be of industrial origin.
Industrial solid waste. Solid waste resulting from or incidental to any process of industry or manufacturing, or
mining or agricultural operations, and which may be classified by the state commission on environmental quality
as class I, II, or III industrial solid wastes. Such classifications shall apply to any such wastes under this
definition.
(1) Class I industrial solid waste or class I waste. Any industrial solid waste designated as class I
by the executive director of the state commission on environmental quality as an industrial solid
waste or mixture of industrial solid wastes which because of its concentration or physical or chemical
characteristics is toxic, corrosive, flammable, or a strong sensitizer or irritant, or a generator of
sudden pressure by decomposition, heat, or other means, and may pose a substantial present or
potential danger to human health or the environment when improperly processed, stored, transported,
or otherwise managed, including hazardous industrial waste.
(2) Class II industrial solid waste. Any individual solid waste or combination of industrial solid
wastes which cannot be described as class I or class III.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 303/420
(3) Class III industrial solid waste. Inert and essentially insoluble industrial solid waste, including
materials such as rock, brick, glass, dirt, and certain plastics and rubber, etc., that are not readily
decomposable.
Inert material. A naturally occurring nonputrescible material which is essentially insoluble, such as soil, dirt,
clay, sand, gravel, and rock.
Infectious waste. Waste containing pathogens or biologically active material which because of its type,
concentration, and quantity is capable of transmitting disease to persons exposed to the waste.
Junk. All worn-out, worthless, and discarded material, including odds and ends, old iron or other metal, glass,
and cordage.
Leachate. Liquid that has passed through or emerged from solid waste and contains soluble, suspended, or
miscible materials removed from such waste.
Lead. The metal element, atomic number 82, atomic weight 207.2, with the chemical symbol “Pb”.
Lead acid battery. A secondary or storage battery that uses lead as the electrode and dilute sulfuric acid as the
electrolyte and is used to generate electrical current.
Liquid waste. Any waste material that is determined to contain “free liquids” as defined by EPA Method 9095
(Paint Filter Test), as described in Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Wastes, Physical/Chemical Methods (EPA
Publication Number SW-846).
Litter. Rubbish and putrescible waste.
Mechanically loaded refuse container. A mechanically loaded refuse container, or dumpster, shall mean a
container constructed in accordance with plans of the city for refuse containers and can be loaded with the
mechanical loading equipment operated by the city.
Medical waste. Waste generated by health care related facilities and associated with health care activities, not
including garbage or rubbish generated from offices, kitchens, or other non-health-care activities.
Motel. The area, including a building or portion thereof, or buildings, where families, transients or tourists are
accommodated, and shall include, but not exclusively, a trailer camp.
Municipal hazardous waste. Any municipal solid waste or mixture of municipal solid wastes that has been
identified or listed as a hazardous waste by the administrator, United States Environmental Protection Agency.
Municipal solid waste (MSW). Solid waste resulting from or incidental to municipal, community, commercial,
institutional, and recreational activities, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals,
abandoned automobiles, and all other solid waste other than industrial solid waste.
Non-RACM. Non-regulated asbestos-containing material as defined in 40 CFR 61. This is asbestos material in a
form such that potential health risks resulting from exposure to it are minimal.
Nuisance. Municipal solid waste that is stored, processed, or disposed of in a manner that causes the pollution of
the surrounding land, the contamination of groundwater or surface water, the breeding of insects or rodents, or
the creation of odors adverse to human health, safety, or welfare.
One-family residence. A detached building having accommodations for and occupied by one (1) family.
Other regulated medical waste. Medical waste that is not included within special waste from health care related
facilities but that is subject to special handling requirements within the generating facility by other state or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 304/420
federal agencies, excluding medical waste subject to chapter 289 of title 25 [of the Texas Administrative Code]
(relating to occupational safety and radiation control).
PCB. Polychlorinated biphenyl molecule.
PCB waste. Those PCBs and PCB items that are subject to the disposal requirements of 40 CFR 761. Substances
that are regulated by 40 CFR 761 include, but are not limited to, PCB articles, PCB article containers, PCB
containers, PCB-contaminated electrical equipment, PCB equipment, PCB transformers, recycled PCBs,
capacitors, microwave ovens, electronic equipment, and light ballasts and fixtures.
Person. An individual, corporation, organization, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business
trust, partnership, association, or any other legal entity.
Premises. A tract of land with the buildings thereon, or a building or part of a building with its grounds or other
appurtenances.
Private hauler. A person or business, other than the city, that engages in the collection and transportation of
municipal and/or industrial solid wastes within the city limits.
Prohibited waste. Material named by the state commission on environmental quality, the federal Environmental
Protection Agency or any other federal, state, or local agency having jurisdiction which is prohibited to be
placed in a permitted sanitary landfill as operated by the city.
Putrescible waste. Organic waste, such as garbage, wastewater treatment plant sludge, and grease trap waste,
that is capable of being decomposed by microorganisms with sufficient rapidity as to cause odors or gases or is
capable of providing food for or attracting birds, animals, and disease vectors.
RACM. Regulated asbestos-containing material as defined in 40 CFR 61, as amended, includes friable asbestos
material; category I nonfriable ACM that has become friable; category I nonfriable ACM that will be or has
been subjected to sanding, grinding, cutting, or abrading; or category II nonfriable ACM that has a high
probability of becoming or has become crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder by the forces expected to act
on the material in the course of demolition or renovation operations.
Radioactive waste. Waste that requires specific licensing under 25 TAC chapter 289 or chapter 401 Health and
Safety Code (relating to radioactive materials and other sources of radiation), and the rules adopted by the
commission under that law.
RCRA. Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.
Recyclable material. A material that has been recovered or diverted from the nonhazardous waste stream for
purposes of reuse, recycling, or reclamation, a substantial portion of which is consistently used in the
manufacture of products that may otherwise be produced using raw or virgin materials. Recyclable material is
not solid waste. However, recyclable material may become solid waste at such time, if any, as it is abandoned or
disposed of rather than recycled, whereupon it will be solid waste with respect only to the party actually
abandoning or disposing of the material.
Recycling. A process by which materials that have served their intended use or are scrapped, discarded, used,
surplus, or obsolete are collected, separated, or processed and returned to use in the form of raw materials in the
production of new products. Except for mixed municipal solid waste composting, that is, composting of the
typical mixed solid waste stream generated by residential, commercial, and/or institutional sources, recycling
includes the composting process if the compost material is put to beneficial use.
Refuse. The same as “rubbish.”
Regulated hazardous waste. A solid waste that is a hazardous waste as defined in 40 CFR, part 261.3, and that is
not excluded from regulation as a hazardous waste under 40 CFR, part 261.4(b), or that was not generated by a
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 305/420
conditionally exempt small-quantity generator.
Resource recovery. The recovery of material or energy from solid waste.
Rubbish. Nonputrescible solid waste (excluding ashes) consisting of both combustible and noncombustible
waste materials; combustible rubbish includes paper, rags, cartons, wood, excelsior, furniture, rubber, plastics,
yard trimmings, leaves, used or scrap tires and similar materials; noncombustible rubbish includes glass,
crockery, tin cans, aluminum cans, metal furniture, and like materials which will not burn at ordinary incinerator
temperatures (1600 degrees Fahrenheit to 1800 degrees Fahrenheit).
Salvaging. The controlled and authorized removal of materials for utilization, for recycling, or for sale.
Sanitary landfill. Means the same as “solid waste landfill.”
Sanitation collection services. The collection of solid wastes from residences and commercial and industrial
establishments by the city.
Sanitation department. Either the department of sanitation of the city or the duly authorized agents of said
department.
Sanitation superintendent. Either the superintendent of sanitation, his superiors, or his duly authorized agents.
Scavenging. The uncontrolled and unauthorized removal of materials at any point in the solid waste management
system of the city.
Scrap tire. Any tire that can no longer be used for its original intended purpose.
Septage. The liquid and solid material pumped from a septic tank, cesspool, or similar sewage treatment system.
Sludge. The solid, semisolid, or liquid waste generated by the wastewater treatment plant of the city.
Solid waste. Any garbage, rubbish, refuse, or sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, and any other discarded
material, including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, municipal,
commercial, mining, and agricultural operations, and from community and institutional activities, but does not
include:
(1) Solid or dissolved material in domestic sewage, or solid or dissolved material in irrigation
return flows, or industrial discharges subject to regulation by permit issued pursuant to chapter 26 of
the Water Code;
(2) Soil, dirt, rock, sand, and other natural or man-made inert solid materials used to fill land if the
object of the fill is to make the land suitable for the construction of surface improvements;
(3) Waste materials which result from activities associated with the exploration, development, or
production of oil or gas and are subject to control by the state railroad commission.
Solid waste landfill. The permitted disposal site owned and operated by the city.
Special waste. Any solid waste or combination of solid wastes that because of its quantity, concentration,
physical or chemical characteristics or biological properties requires special handling and disposal to protect
human health or the environment. If improperly handled, transported, stored, processed, or disposed of or
otherwise managed, it may pose a present or potential danger to human health or the environment. Special
wastes include, but are not limited to:
(1) Hazardous wastes from small generators that may be exempt from full controls under state
solid waste regulations;

https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 306/420
(2) Class I industrial nonhazardous waste not routinely collected with municipal solid waste;
(3) Special waste from health care related facilities (refers to certain items of medical waste), and
includes infectious and pathological wastes from health care facilities, veterinary hospitals, or

(4) Municipal wastewater treatment plant sludges that have not been treated by one of the

(8) Slaughterhouse wastes;
(9) Dead animals;

wastes;
(11) Pesticide (insecticide, herbicide, fungicide, or rodenticide) containers;

Stabilized sludges. Those sludges processed to significantly reduce pathogens as specified in federal regulations
under CFR part 257, appendix II.

Storage battery. A secondary battery, so called because the conversion from chemical to electrical energy is
reversible and the battery is thus rechargeable. Secondary or storage batteries contain an electrode made of
sponge lead and lead dioxide, nickel-iron, nickel-cadmium, silver-zinc, or silver-cadmium. The electrolyte used
is sulfuric acid. Other types of storage batteries contain lithium, sodium-liquid sulfur, or chlorine-zinc using
titanium electrodes.
Transporter. A person who collects and transports municipal solid waste; does not include a man or woman
transporting his or her household waste or city collection crews.
Trash. Rubbish such as paper, boxes, grass, shrubs, yard cleanings, yard clippings, leaves, tree trimmings,
weeds, hedge trimmings and similar matter.
Triple rinse. To rinse a container three times using a volume of solvent equal to ten percent of the volume of the
container or liner for each rinse.
Two-family residence. A detached building having separate accommodations for and occupied as a dwelling by
two (2) families.
Used tire. Any tire that has been mounted upon a wheel and utilized for any period of time, or any tire that
cannot be legally described as new.
Vector. Any agent, such as an insect, snake, rodent, or animal, capable of mechanically or biologically
transferring a pathogen from one organism to another.
Yard waste. Leaves, grass clippings, yard and garden debris, and brush, including clean woody vegetative
material not greater than six inches in diameter, that results from landscaping maintenance and land-clearing
operations. The term does not include stumps, roots, or shrubs with intact root balls.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.008)
Sec. 13.02.005 Penalty
Any person, firm or individual who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be fined a sum not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2000.00), and each and every day's violation shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense. (1998 Code, sec. 71.004)
Sec. 13.02.006 Assent to provisions by consumers
All of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be incorporated in every contract between the sanitation
department and its consumers, and each customer shall be charged with knowledge of the provisions of this
article and, by applying and/or accepting sanitation service from the sanitation department, to have consented to
the provisions hereof. (1998 Code, sec. 71.005)
Sec. 13.02.007 Efforts to obtain voluntary compliance
Nothing in this article shall prevent the city or its agents from making efforts to obtain voluntary compliance
through warning, conference or any other appropriate means. (1998 Code, sec. 71.006)
Sec. 13.02.008 Exemptions
Any person may apply to the city council for an exemption or partial exemption to the provisions of this article,
and an exemption may be granted, after a public hearing and affirmative vote of the city council, if it is found
that:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 308/420
(1) The violation occurring or proposed to occur does not constitute a danger to public health or
safety;
(2) The violation occurring or proposed to occur will not be for more than ninety (90) days;
(3) Compliance with the provisions from which exemption is sought would produce serious
hardship without equal benefits to the public;
(4) If the exemption is granted, it would not constitute a violation of any federal or state law or
regulation; and
(5) If the violation occurring or proposed to occur does not involve the collection, transportation or
disposal of any class I, class II, special, infectious, hazardous, prohibited or any other wastes
regulated by state or federal law or regulations.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.007)
Secs. 13.02.009–13.02.040 Reserved
Division 2. Disposal
Sec. 13.02.041 Permitted methods of disposal
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, dump or unload any garbage, rubbish, refuse or other waste
matter at any place within the city or its jurisdiction, except as follows:
(1) Approved methods of disposal. All disposal of solid wastes shall be by one of the following
methods:
(A) Disposal by city. At a state permitted sanitary landfill.
(B) Individual disposal. The disposal of solid wastes in any place within the city and within
five thousand (5,000) feet outside of the city limits except at the designated sanitary landfill, a
recycling or composting facility or a collection site, or at an approved facility or collection site
for special or hazardous wastes, is prohibited, except that occupants of private dwellings
outside the city limits where garbage pickup is not available may dispose of their solid wastes
by any state approved method so long as the method of disposal does not create a nuisance.
(2) Placing waste for collection. All items of garbage, trash and other waste material shall be
placed in approved type containers except as hereinafter specifically exempted. Large volumes of
brush and other approved materials may be placed on the ground for collection near the alley
property line of the property from which it originated and clear of the traveled right-of-way. Such
accumulations will be collected by the sanitation department when possible. It shall be unlawful to
place any other waste material in the alley or public right-of-way except as herein provided.
(3) Yard waste generated by contractors, utilities, etc. It shall be the duty of all tree surgery
operators, commercial nurserymen, yard work contractors or public utility concerns to provide their
own facilities for the removal, hauling and disposal of trees, tree trunks or any other accumulation of
brush, grass clippings, dirt, or similar yard wastes generated by them, and to remove the same in a
manner which shall be designated by the department of sanitation, the provisions of this article
notwithstanding. Such wastes shall not be placed in sanitation containers.
(4) Waste placed in container must be free of liquids. It shall be the duty of every person placing
solid wastes in any container provided for by this article to eliminate, as far as possible, all water and
liquid from such solid wastes, and to securely wrap the solid waste before placing it in the container.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 309/420
It shall be unlawful to pour water or any liquid over the solid wastes or into the container. Liquid
material or semi-liquid material that will harden must be sealed in a container that will not break or
spill during a normal loading cycle. Flammable liquids may not be placed in the container.
(5) Animal matter. Animal matter that is subject to decomposition shall be placed in a plastic
container or bag before being placed in a sanitation container.
(6) Manure, waste oils, and residue from wash drains. Manure from cow lots, horse stables, poultry
yards and pigeon lofts, human excrement, dog and cat excrement, waste oils and all residue which
collects in wash drains from garages and filling stations shall be disposed of by the owner or agent
responsible and shall not be placed in sanitation containers or at the sanitary landfill. Disposal shall
be at a disposal site permitted to accept such wastes at the expense of the party responsible for the
same.
(7) Heavy refuse and industrial waste. Discarded automobile bodies and frames and other heavy,
bulky refuse and all industrial waste resulting from manufacturing operations must be disposed of by
the owner or occupant of the building or premises where such industrial waste originates. This
subsection shall include accumulations from packing houses, killing and dressing plants for poultry
and fowl, wholesale fruit and vegetable houses and stores, and cotton gins, cotton oil mills and cotton
compresses.
(8) Waste resulting from building construction or cleanup of vacant property.
(A) Rock, waste building materials or other trash resulting from building or remodeling
operations, or resulting from a general cleanup of vacant or improved property, will not be
removed by the city. Such waste shall be removed by the contractor, owner or occupant of the
building at his own expense and at no time shall this material be placed in a sanitation
container, unless approved by the sanitation superintendent, or placed in any alley in such a
manner that the alley will be obstructed or blocked.
(B) It shall be the duty of all roofing contractors, carpet layers, electricians, plumbers,
carpenters, or any other person contracting for residential, commercial, or industrial
construction or improvements to provide their own facilities for the removal of wastes
generated by them, and to remove the same in a manner which shall be designated by the
department of sanitation, the provisions of this article notwithstanding. Such wastes shall not be
placed in sanitation containers.
(9) Boxes and cartons. All boxes and cartons not suitable for placement in a container must be
broken down and bundled, and no bundle shall exceed seventy-five (75) pounds in weight. Such
bundles shall be placed in a location designated by the department of sanitation. Boxes and cartons
not broken down and bundled shall not be placed outside of the container.
(10) Dead animals. When any horse, cow, jack, jennet, goat, sheep, hog, chicken or any other kind
of large animal or fowl shall die within the corporate limits of the city, the owner or person in control
of the animal or fowl shall be required to remove the body or carcass thereof outside the city limits,
and to bury or otherwise dispose of such body or carcass so that the sight or odor thereof shall not be
offensive to any citizen of the city. Dogs, cats or any other small dead animals shall not be placed in
sanitation containers. The animal control officer of the police department may, upon notice, remove
such small dead animals.
(11) Ashes. Ashes shall be wrapped or placed in a paper sack before placement in the container.
No live coals or embers shall be placed in the containers.
(12) Trees, tree limbs and brush. All trees to be removed from premises shall be trimmed free of
branches, and cut into lengths not to exceed ten inches (10") in diameter and four feet (4') in length,
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 310/420
and the weight of such lengths shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds. All brush, trees and tree limbs
prepared in accordance with this section may not be placed in containers and shall be placed on the
ground in the alley adjacent to the premises for collection by individual occupants of private
residences. If such brush, trees and tree limbs are placed in the alley adjacent to the premises, they
shall be placed in a neat and orderly manner so as to not obstruct vehicular use of the alley. Materials
exceeding ten inches (10") in diameter and four feet (4') in length and weighing more than sixty (60)
pounds shall be removed by the resident or property owner.
(13) Grass clippings, leaves and weeds. Grass clippings, leaves and weeds may be placed in plastic
bags and on the ground in the alley adjacent to the premises for collection, by individual occupants of
private residences. Said bags shall not be intermingled with tree limbs and brush. All commercial
nurserymen and firms shall provide for hauling and disposal of tree trunks, limbs and trimmings, and
for the dirt and grass combinations generated in renovating lawns, the provisions of this subsection
notwithstanding.
(14) Dirt, rocks and turf. Dirt, rocks and turf shall not be placed in the street or alley or in a
sanitation container.
(15) Records, books, and confidential matter. Records, books, and confidential matter may be
disposed at the landfill or in any collection container, except that the city will not guarantee the
destruction or confidentiality of same in any manner whatsoever.
(16) Heavy accumulations. Heavy accumulations, such as brick, broken concrete, lumber,
construction materials, cinders, dirt, plaster, sand or gravel, automobile frames, dead trees and other
bulky, heavy material, including debris from vacant lots, shall be immediately disposed of at the
expense of the owner or person controlling the same. Such heavy accumulations shall not be stored or
placed in an alley or other public right-of-way or on any private property except the premises on
which such accumulation originated. The city reserves the right to pick up all material, waste or
otherwise, placed in the alley and shall not be held liable for the disposal of said material regardless
of its nature. If removed by the sanitation department the charge shall be at the rate of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per truckload.
(17) Demolition and removal of dilapidated residential structures. The city may demolish and
dispose of dilapidated residential buildings in accordance with the provisions in section 3.05.010
through section 3.05.013 of the Code of Ordinances for the city. The charge for demolition, removal,
and disposal of the demolished materials shall be $100.00 per truckload in accordance with
subsection (16) of this section. The charges for demolition, removal, and disposal shall be assessed
according to section 3.05.011(b)(3). Property owners who voluntarily wish to have the city perform
the demolition shall sign a written consent form allowing the demolition and giving the city
permission to enter the property to perform the work. The owner shall then pay the city a minimum
of $200.00 in advance with the balance due upon completion of the demolition, or the city may place
a lien on the property in accordance with the provisions in section 3.05.011(b)(3) to cover the cost of
the demolition.
(18) Demolition and removal of dilapidated commercial and/or industrial structures.
(A) The city may demolish and dispose of dilapidated commercial and/or industrial buildings
in accordance with the provisions in section 3.05.010 through section 3.05.013 of the Code of
Ordinances for the city. The charge for demolition, removal, and disposal of the demolished
materials shall be the posted rate per hour of each piece of equipment used in the demolition,
plus $100.00 per truckload, plus $20.00 per ton disposed of in the city landfill. The charges for
demolition, removal, and disposal shall be assessed according to section 3.05.011(b)(3).
Property owners who voluntarily wish to have the city perform the demolition shall sign a
written consent form allowing the demolition and giving the city permission to enter the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 311/420
property to perform the work. The owner shall then pay the city a minimum of $500.00 in
advance with the balance due upon completion of the demolition.
(B) The city encourages commercial and industrial property owners to seek out all available
local contractors for bids to demolish their structures before approaching the city to contract for
demolition work. The city manager may review each bid from local contractors before
considering any request for demolition.
(C) Demolition of commercial and/or industrial buildings is not generally within the normal
scope of services provided by the city. However, if no local contractors are available to perform
the work, and the removal of such building is considered necessary to prevent blight, and/or to
protect life and safety, in accordance with section 3.05.010, the city may undertake such
activities necessary to demolish the structures in accordance with the above guidelines and
within a schedule to be set by the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.011)
Sec. 13.02.042 Prohibited acts
The following acts, among others, are declared to be unlawful and in violation of this section, and are declared
to be trespasses, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive:
(1) Placing solid waste on public property. To dump, throw, or place any garbage, rubbish, refuse,
junk, ashes, filth, wastepaper, weeds, grass cuttings, rock or other waste matter of whatever kind in or
on any public building, street or alley, other than the city's solid waste landfill, except as herein
otherwise provided.
(2) Placing solid waste on private property. To dump, throw, or place any garbage, rubbish, refuse,
junk, ashes, filth, wastepaper, weeds, grass cuttings, rock or other waste matter of whatever kind in or
on any private property, except the premises on which such waste matter originated.
(3) Sweeping solid waste into public street or alley. To sweep paper, litter, or debris into any public
street or alley.
(4) Placing solid waste in gutter or drainage ditch. To put any garbage, refuse, junk, rubbish, or any
other substance capable of impeding the flow of water into any gutter or drainage ditch.
(5) Placing vegetation trimmings on public property. To throw, place, dump or deposit any lawn
trimmings, hedge trimmings or other cuttings or trimmings of weeds, flowers or other vegetation on
or in any gutter, street, sidewalk, parkway, driveway, curb, or alley, or on any other public property of
the city.
(6) Placing vegetation trimmings on private property. To throw, place, dump or deposit any lawn
trimmings, hedge trimmings or other cuttings or trimmings of weeds, flowers or other vegetation on
any lot, vacant or occupied, driveway, or any other private property.
(7) Disposal of unsanitary matter. To cause or permit to be or remain in or upon any premises,
private or public, any animal, vegetable or mineral matter or any composition or residue thereof
which is in an unsanitary condition or injurious to public health.
(8) Disposal of scrap or used tires. To throw, place, dump or deposit any scrap or used tire on or in
any gutter, street, sidewalk, parkway, driveway, curb, or alley, or on any other public property of the
city, or on any lot, vacant or occupied, driveway, or any other private property. In addition to any fine
levied for said violation, an administrative fee of at least ten dollars ($10.00) per tire shall be charged
for the disposal of said tires if removed by the city.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 312/420
(9) Depositing equipment or appliances containing freon or PCBs. To throw, place, dump or
deposit any appliance or equipment containing freon or PCBs on or in any gutter, street, sidewalk,
parkway, driveway, curb, or alley, or on any other public property of the city, or on any lot, vacant or
occupied, driveway, or any other private property. In addition to any fine levied for said violation, an
administrative fee of at least one hundred dollars ($100.00) per item shall be charged for the disposal
of said items if removed by the city.
(10) Explosives, highly volatile chemicals, drugs, narcotics and other harmful matter. To dispose
of explosives, highly volatile chemicals, drugs, narcotics and any other harmful matter in a sanitation
container, at the landfill, or in any other manner prohibited by law. Such materials will not be
accepted for disposal by the city either at the landfill or in any collection container.
(11) Medical wastes. To dispose of any medical wastes either at the landfill or in any collection
container in a manner not approved or allowed by state or federal law.
(12) Hazardous household waste. To engage in any activity to collect, aggregate or dispose of any
hazardous household waste that has been segregated from other solid wastes either at the landfill or
in any collection container.
(13) Scrap or used tires. To engage in any activity to collect, aggregate or dispose of any scrap or
used tires at the landfill or in any collection container, except as herein otherwise provided.
(14) Used oil or oil filters. To engage in any activity to collect, aggregate or dispose of any used oil
or oil filters at the landfill or in any collection container, except as herein otherwise provided.
(15) Disposal of household appliances. To engage in any activity to collect, aggregate or dispose of
any household appliances, including refrigerators and air conditioners, at the landfill, in any
collection container, or in a vacant lot, alley or other right-of-way, except as herein otherwise
provided.
(16) Disposal of equipment containing PCBs. To engage in any activity to collect, aggregate or
dispose of any equipment containing PCBs, including electric motors, capacitors and transformers, at
the landfill, in any collection container, or in a vacant lot, alley or other right-of-way, except as herein
otherwise provided.
(17) Accumulations of garbage, refuse, etc. To place, deposit or throw, or permit or cause to be
placed, deposited or thrown, any garbage, brush, broken glass, bottles, loose waste or refuse of any
kind, on public or private property outside of any house, building, flat or tenement in the city, unless
the same has been deposited in accordance with the provisions of this article. The presence of
garbage, brush, rubbish or miscellaneous waste upon any street, alley or public place shall be held to
constitute a violation of this section on the part of the owner or occupant upon whose half of the alley
such garbage, brush, rubbish or miscellaneous waste is permitted to remain for longer than twentyfour
(24) hours.
(18) Removal of solid waste. To scavenge, salvage, separate and collect, carry off or dispose of
solid wastes and other materials lawfully deposited or otherwise introduced into the solid waste
management system of the city, including any dumpster or other collection point, such materials
being the property of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.012)
State law reference–Illegal dumping, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, sec. 365.012.
Secs. 13.02.043–13.02.080 Reserved

Division 3. Collection
Sec. 13.02.081 Receptacles; storage of waste
(a) Mechanically loaded refuse containers may be furnished by the city. When a mechanically loaded
container is placed to provide for garbage collection, no other type of container may be placed in the alley or any
other collection point.
(1) The mechanically loaded container shall be used to dispose of garbage, litter, trash, and other
normally generated refuse.
(2) Building material, rocks, bricks, junk metal, dirt, tires, brush, large tree limbs and other
material that produces excessive weight or volume may not be placed in the mechanically loaded
container.
(3) Excessive weights or volumes of residential yard waste may not be placed in the mechanically
loaded container. Large volumes of grass clippings shall be packed in plastic bags and placed in the
alley or other public right-of-way adjacent to the owner's property, in a manner specified in this
article, for collection, or shall be disposed of by the owner at the owner's expense.
(b) All material placed in the container must not project above the lip of the container at any point so that the
lid may close properly.
(c) All solid waste shall be stored in such a manner that does not constitute a fire, safety, or health hazard or
provide food or harborage for animals and vectors, and shall be contained or bundled so as not to result in litter.
(d) It shall be the responsibility of the occupant of a residence or the owner or management of an
establishment to utilize city-provided containers of an adequate size, and in sufficient numbers, to contain all
solid waste that the residence or other establishment generates in the period of time between collections.
(e) Establishments generating solid wastes containing food wastes shall store said wastes in covered or closed
containers which are leakproof, and the owner or management of said establishment shall be responsible for
maintaining said containers in a clean condition so that they do not constitute a nuisance and to retard the
harborage, feeding, and propagation of vectors.
(f) Each occupant of a residence, or owner, occupant, tenant, lessee or management of an establishment, shall
be responsible for maintaining the area around the garbage containers in a clean and sanitary condition, free of
weeds, tall grass, garbage and trash.
(g) It shall be unlawful for any person who is a residential sanitation service customer to deposit or dispose of
any solid wastes in a collection container more than two hundred feet (200') from their residence unless said
container is the nearest container to said residence or the person is directed to do otherwise by the sanitation
superintendent.
(h) It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or dispose of any solid wastes in a collection container
located at and paid for by a commercial or industrial establishment that is not their own or without the
permission of the person in control of said container.
(i) It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or dispose of any solid wastes in a collection container if that
person is not a current paying customer of the city's sanitation service.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.031)
Sec. 13.02.082 Collection of waste containing putrescibles

The collection and removal of solid wastes containing putrescibles shall be made at least once weekly to prevent
propagation and attraction of vectors and the creation of public health nuisances. In the event that circumstances
prevent the normal collection of such wastes, it shall be the responsibility of the person or establishment
generating such wastes to collect and transport them to the city's solid waste landfill. (1998 Code, sec. 71.032)
Sec. 13.02.083 Charges for residential collection
(a) An assessment is hereby levied for removing garbage, rubbish and trash in accordance with the schedule
listed in this section. This shall be a minimum assessment, and additional charges for extra pickups, extra service
or extra containers [shall] be assessed in addition to this minimum charge. (1998 Code, sec. 71.033)
(b) The minimum rate for commercial and industrial sanitation collection service, which shall be charged all
customers, except as otherwise provided, shall be twenty-nine dollars ($29.00) per month effective October 1,
2009. (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
(c) The city through its water and waste department shall charge and collect, and every commercial customer
shall pay, for sanitation collection service furnished to the customer, the amount calculated by application of the
following rates for all billing cycles on or after October 1, 2009:
Type of Service Rate

(d) The minimum monthly charge per individual customer shall never be less than the minimum charge set out
in subsection (b) above, and the total charge to all customers sharing one container shall not be less than $84.00
per month unless the container has been placed at its location for the sole convenience of the city in furnishing
such service. None of these charges shall be interpreted to place a maximum amount that can be charged on one
container when it has multiple users. (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
(e) In calculating the minimum rate to be charged apartment houses, townhouses, or other multifamily living
units, each living unit shall be deemed a residential unit and subject to a minimum rate charge for each unit.
(f) For service outside the city limits, residential users of city sanitation service shall pay two hundred twentyfive
percent (225%) of the established rate for similar customers inside the city limits.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.033)

Sec. 13.02.087 Collection services outside city limits
(a) The city shall have the right, but shall not have the obligation, to provide solid waste collection services
outside of its corporate limits and within Dawson County. Any entity within Dawson County, whether public or
private, commercial, industrial, or residential, may apply for collection services with the city.
(b) All wastes collected must comply with section 13.02.081(a) through (i) of the Code of Ordinances.
(c) In order to determine which customers will be served, each request will be reviewed according to, but not
specifically limited to, the following:
(1) Be within Dawson County, Texas;
(2) Be within a reasonable distance to established routes;
(3) Generate enough waste to need service at least once per week; and
(4) Have a dedicated roadway which is paved and rated for the weight of the solid waste collection
vehicles.
(d) All requests for service to be considered must be in compliance with the above conditions, and, in the
opinion of the city manager, prove beneficial to the city. Service may be denied for any reason, and all decisions
made by the city manager are final.
(e) Either party may terminate the service for any reason upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
(f) Collection services provided for other municipalities within the county shall be negotiated by the city
manager. Upon reaching an acceptable agreement, a written service agreement showing all rates and fees, and
outlining the scope of services to be provided, shall be presented to the city council for approval.
(g) All wastes collected shall be deposited in the city municipal solid waste landfill and will be subject to the
terms and conditions of divisions 5 and 6 of this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.038)
