Division 4. Private Haulers
Sec. 13.02.121 Permit required
It shall be unlawful for any person (other than the city and its employees acting in the scope of their
employment) to collect, remove or dispose of garbage or trash from any premises within the city, except
premises owned or controlled by the person, without first obtaining a permit therefor, [and] unless the council
has, after hearing, determined that there is a present public need and necessity for such additional service by
passing a resolution authorizing the city secretary to issue said permits. (1998 Code, sec. 71.037(a))
Sec. 13.02.122 Use of private hauler
The owner or person in charge of any premises may remove or contract for the removal of garbage or trash, or
both, otherwise than by the sanitation department, if the hauler complies with the requirements of this division.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(b))
Sec. 13.02.123 Scope of permit
A commercial hauler's permit may be issued for the collection of solid waste by a private hauler. Said permit
entitles the holder to collect, remove and dispose of garbage and/or trash, as defined in this article, from the
premises of others with their consent. (1998 Code, sec. 71.037(c))
Sec. 13.02.124 Permit fee; expiration of permit
(a) For each commercial hauler's permit, a minimum permit fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year for
each vehicle based upon an assessment of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each thousand pounds of gross weight per
vehicle as evidenced by a valid weight ticket.
(b) All permits shall be issued for one (1) year and may be renewed upon meeting all terms of this division
and payment of the specified annual permit fee.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(d))
Sec. 13.02.125 Application for permit; requirements for issuance
Applications for permits shall be filed with the city secretary, stating the name and address of the applicant and
the type of permit applied for, and shall be issued upon meeting the following requirements:
(1) Before issuing an initial or renewal permit, the city secretary shall refer the application to the
superintendent of sanitation, who shall inspect the vehicle proposed to be used and shall certify to the
city secretary whether the vehicle complies with the requirements of this article, and the city
secretary shall issue or refuse the permit in accordance with such certification.
(2) No person shall hold a permit or do any act for which such permit is required without having in
effect a policy of public liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state
in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for death or injury of any one (1)
person in one (1) accident, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for death or injury to more
than one (1) person in any one (1) accident, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property
damage, and furnishing proof of said insurance to the city secretary.
(3) The applicant shall pay the applicable permit fee.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 318/420
(4) Applicants for commercial hauler permits shall, upon request, furnish a current financial
statement.
(5) The applicant shall provide the city secretary with a list of customer accounts and shall keep
said list current each month by delivering to the city secretary said list no later than the tenth day of
each month.
(6) The applicant shall present the city secretary with a signed contract, valid for the full term of
the permit issued, for the disposal, at a state licensed solid waste landfill, of all solid wastes collected
under the provisions of said permit.
(7) The applicant shall present the city secretary with a special municipal transporter route permit
or a municipal transporter route permit issued by the state commission on environmental quality, if
applicable.
(8) The applicant shall present the city secretary with a bond in the amount of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), payable to the city. Said bond is required and shall be forfeited should the permittee fail
to service customers in a satisfactory manner or fail to meet other permit requirements for any cause
as provided in this division.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(e))
Sec. 13.02.126 Identification of vehicles
The city secretary shall assign an identifying number to each vehicle operated under a commercial hauler's
permit. All such vehicles used in the performance of the permittee's business shall have the company name and
city permit number displayed on the right-hand and left-hand doors of said vehicles. Letters and numbers shall
be at least three (3) inches and shall be either black on white or white on black. (1998 Code, sec. 71.037(f))
Sec. 13.02.127 Vehicle equipment and covering
Every permitted vehicle shall be fully enclosed or shall be enclosed at the sides and equipped with a tarpaulin
and methods of fastening the same so as reasonably to avoid spilling garbage or waste, disseminating odors, and
attracting insects. Such vehicle shall be kept closed or covered at all times when in use, except as may be
necessary for loading and unloading. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or allow his employee to
operate, any solid waste collection vehicle not complying with this section or to operate such vehicle without
having the tarpaulin in place and fastened as herein required. (1998 Code, sec. 71.037(g))
Sec. 13.02.128 Disposal of waste
No person shall dispose of any garbage or trash removed under a commercial hauler's permit except by carrying
it to a state licensed solid waste landfill. If said solid waste landfill shall be the city's solid waste landfill, then
said permit holder shall unload it at such place and in such manner as may be designated by the foreman or other
city employee in charge of the solid waste landfill, or by unloading it at such other place and in such manner as
may be directed by the superintendent of sanitation. No person shall unload any garbage or trash at the solid
waste landfill at any other time except as posted. Should the permittee dispose of said solid waste at any
unauthorized location, the permit may be revoked, bond forfeited, and all deposits retained. The permittee shall
maintain records for at least one year to document that waste was taken to an authorized solid waste facility.
Upon request, the permittee shall to furnish the city with adequate documentation regarding the destination of all
waste collected, including billing documents, to prove the proper disposal procedure is being followed. (1998
Code, sec. 71.037(h))
Sec. 13.02.129 Duties of drivers and permittee
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 319/420
(a) The driver of any vehicle licensed hereunder shall immediately gather up and place in his vehicle any
garbage, trash, or other wastes which may be spilled from such vehicle in transit or spilled from the vehicle
while loading.
(b) No permit issued to any junk or salvage dealer of the city shall authorize any person to whom a permit is
issued to remove any such waste material from any container or receptacle, or in any manner interfere with such
container or receptacle.
(c) Should the permittee fail to service customers in a satisfactory manner or fail to meet other permit
requirements for any cause, the city may revoke the permit, cause forfeiture of bond, retain all deposits and use
the proceeds to defray city collection service expense to service the permittee's customers.
(d) In the event that an applicant for a permit desires to handle waste declared to be hazardous, infectious,
toxic, or harmful by federal or state law, then, in addition to the stated requirements, the applicant shall dispose
of all waste in a legal and proper manner and at a proper location for the type of harmful waste being handled by
the applicant.
(e) The permittee shall follow all requirements of subchapter C of the Municipal Solid Waste Management
Regulations as published and amended by the state commission on environmental quality.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(i))
Sec. 13.02.130 Revocation of permit
(a) For serious or repeated violation of any of the requirements of the preceding section, a permit thereunder
may be revoked by the sanitation superintendent after an opportunity for a hearing has been provided.
(b) After five (5) days' written notice, stating the reasons for which the permit is subject to revocation, and an
opportunity to be heard by the council, any permit may be revoked or suspended at any time by the
superintendent of sanitation for violation of any provision of this article, or for failure to carry out any lawful
agreement for the removal of garbage or trash. The licensee may appeal to the council from the decision of the
superintendent of sanitation.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(j))
Sec. 13.02.131 Inspection of vehicles
All vehicles carrying garbage or trash may be inspected by the division of sanitation at any time to determine
whether they are properly equipped and kept covered and in a clean and sanitary condition. (1998 Code, sec.
71.037(k))
Sec. 13.02.132 Inspection of work performance
It is hereby made the duty of the superintendent of sanitation to make inspection trips at regular intervals to
determine whether or not garbage and trash are being properly collected, removed, and disposed of as required
by the provisions of this article, this code or any other applicable health regulations, and in the event it is found
that this article or other regulation is being violated, appropriate and timely action shall be taken to insure full
compliance with such provisions. (1998 Code, sec. 71.037(l))
Sec. 13.02.133 Limitations
A permit authorized by this division will not be a franchise, nor will it provide any exclusive area or class of
service, nor will the permit holder be authorized to make collections from single-family residences. (1998 Code,
sec. 71.037(m))
Sec. 13.02.134 Exceptions
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 320/420
The provisions of this article requiring a permit for the collection and hauling of waste products shall not apply
to the following:
(1) Persons collecting waste oils and transporting them for proper disposal or recycling.
(2) Persons collecting used or scrap tires and transporting them for proper disposal or recycling.
(3) Persons collecting hazardous materials from locations within the city and transporting them
outside the city for proper disposal or recycling.
(4) Persons collecting and transporting building wastes from a single specific construction site
within the city limits and transporting them for proper disposal or recycling.
(5) Persons collecting agricultural wastes containing cotton seeds and/or burrs and transporting
them to a site outside the city.
(6) Persons collecting consumer products and materials intended for recycling, such as bottles,
newspapers, bundled cardboard, and other paper products and transporting them to a site for storage
and/or processing.
(7) Persons collecting medical wastes for proper disposal.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.037(n))
Secs. 13.02.135–13.02.170 Reserved
Division 5. Landfill Regulations
Sec. 13.02.171 Compliance
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, dump, unload or leave any garbage, rubbish, refuse or other
waste matter at the city solid waste landfill, except as provided in this article. (1998 Code, sec. 71.051)
Sec. 13.02.172 Payment of fees
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, dump, unload or leave any refuse at the city solid waste landfill
without the payment of prescribed fees and surcharges. (1998 Code, sec. 71.052)
Sec. 13.02.173 Transporter's certificate regarding nonallowable wastes
It shall be unlawful for any transporter of solid wastes, as defined in this article, to dump any refuse at the city
solid waste landfill without the presentation of a certificate that the transporter or hauler has so arranged his
routes to eliminate nonallowable wastes from the loads he transports to said landfill. The certificate shall also
state that the transporter will remove any nonallowable wastes dumped by him immediately after their discharge,
or that, at the option of the facility operator, he will pay any applicable surcharges to have the disposal facility
operator accomplish the required immediate removal for him. (1998 Code, sec. 71.053)
Sec. 13.02.174 Supervision of disposal; inspection of waste
(a) All garbage, refuse matter, or permitted waste material of any kind taken to the city solid waste landfill
shall be placed and deposited upon the solid waste landfill under the direction of, and shall be inspected by, an
authorized person under the sanitation department. Authorized landfill employees are not required to accept any
solid waste which they determine will cause problems in maintaining full and continuous compliance with this
article and any applicable federal or state statutes or regulations.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 321/420
(b) The unloading of wastes in unauthorized areas is prohibited. Any waste deposited in an unauthorized area
shall be removed by the generator or transporter of the waste and disposed of properly.
(c) The unloading of prohibited wastes shall not be allowed. Any prohibited waste shall be returned promptly
to the transporter or generator of the waste.
(d) A working face monitor shall inspect each load and shall have the authority and responsibility to reject
unauthorized loads, have unauthorized material removed by the transporter and/or assess appropriate surcharges
and have the unauthorized material removed by on-site personnel.
(e) Screening of deposited waste materials may be conducted by landfill personnel as required by state
regulations. It shall be unlawful for any person transporting wastes to the landfill to evade said screening.
(f) Disposal of large, heavy, or bulky items which cannot be incorporated in the regular spreading,
compaction, and covering operations shall be in special collection areas for recycling.
(g) It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with an authorized landfill employee in the discharge of his
duty.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.054)
Sec. 13.02.175 Persons allowed on landfill
Only employees of the city, city officials, city officers directing operations of the sanitation department and
private persons delivering garbage or other permitted solid waste materials to the city solid waste landfill are
allowed on the landfill. All other persons are prohibited therefrom. It shall be unlawful for any person to remain
on the landfill when ordered to leave by an authorized city employee engaged in the lawful enforcement of any
of the provisions of state law, state regulations or this article. (1998 Code, sec. 71.055)
Sec. 13.02.176 Acceptance of waste
The disposal of any and all wastes in the solid waste landfill shall be at the discretion of the city and the city
shall not be responsible for the acceptance of any wastes into said landfill for any reason whatsoever if the
acceptance is deemed to not be in the city's interest by the sanitation superintendent, or if it is determined that
acceptance will cause problems in maintaining full and continuous compliance with this article and/or any
applicable federal or state statutes or regulations. (1998 Code, sec. 71.056)
Sec. 13.02.177 Materials spilled along the route to landfill
(a) Transporters or drivers of vehicles transporting waste to the landfill shall not permit waste to blow or spill
from the vehicle transporting such wastes.
(b) Persons allowing wastes to be spilled along and within the right-of-way of any public access road serving
the landfill, or any city street or alley, shall be responsible for the cleanup of all such waste materials spilled
along said right-of-way. Assessments or additional fees may be charged for cleanup activities conducted by city
employees.
(c) Access to the landfill may be denied to any person allowing wastes to be spilled along and within the rightof-
way of any public access road serving the landfill, or any city street or alley, and said person may be required
to secure future loads as a condition for continued access to the landfill.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.057)
Sec. 13.02.178 Charges for disposal of waste

available disposal.
(c) Contaminated soils. Contaminated soils originating within the city limits and meeting standards set forth in
this article may be disposed of, if approved by the city manager, at the rate of twenty dollars ($20.00) per ton.
(d) City residents. Residents of the city subject to regular residential sanitation collection charges may dump
approved residential wastes at the landfill at no charge, provided that they exhibit a paid-up sanitation service
receipt not more than one month old upon entering the landfill.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.058)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 323/420
(e) Each adult resident of the city, who is not then delinquent in the payment of such resident's regular
residential sanitation collection charges, may deposit not to exceed one ton per month, per residential property
address for which residential sanitation collection charges are made, of approved residential waste (not including
tires) at the landfill, at no charge, provided that such resident presents a valid photo identification showing the
residents address upon entering the landfill. Each adult resident of the county residing outside the city may
deposit not to exceed one ton per month of approved residential waste (not including tires) at the landfill at no
charge provided there is then in effect a landfill access agreement between the city and the county and provided
such residents present a valid photo identification showing the residents address upon entering the landfill. The
waste must be generated on property owned or rented by the resident and must be delivered to the landfill by the
resident. Approved residential waste includes those waste that would generally be categorized as type IV and
recyclable waste. (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
(f) County residents. Residents of Dawson County, subject to approval by an agreement between the city
council and the county commissioners court, may dispose of approved residential wastes at the landfill at no
charge, provided that they exhibit proof of residence in the county upon entering the landfill. Commercial and
agricultural wastes shall be charged at the regular rates, except as may be provided in said agreement.
(g) Governmental bodies or private firms. The city manager is authorized to enter into contract with any other
governmental body or agency or private firm for use of the sanitary landfill at rates to be negotiated, provided
that said rates shall not be lower than those charged to residents of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.058)
Sec. 13.02.179 Wastes requiring special handling
All waste requiring special handling by federal, state, or local regulation, if accepted, shall be charged for on a
basis of actual costs incurred by special handling. Said costs shall include all administrative, labor, equipment,
engineering, and property costs associated with accepting said wastes. (1998 Code, sec. 71.059)
Sec. 13.02.180 Burial of dead animals
A small animal carcass may be buried in the city solid waste landfill under the supervision of a designated
employee of the city, but all such animals shall be buried at a depth of not less than three (3) feet from the
surface of the earth to any part of the body of such carcass. A reasonable charge shall be collected for labor,
equipment and land use. The burial of large animal carcasses is prohibited. (1998 Code, sec. 71.060)
Sec. 13.02.181 Disposal of petroleum product contaminated soils
(a) No person shall dispose of any petroleum product contaminated soils or associated materials at the sanitary
landfill or place any of such products, soil, or other materials in a mechanized collection container without the
express permission of the sanitation superintendent.
(b) Only specified petroleum product contaminated soil wastes originating from property located within the
city limits may be deposited in the landfill. Any such wastes shall meet the requirements or standards for
disposal as promulgated by the state commission on environmental quality and shall be tested and certified as
meeting said requirements or standards by a certified laboratory. Only wastes tested and reported in an analysis
conducted for said soils shall be deposited in the landfill.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.061)
Sec. 13.02.182 Disposal of certain materials prohibited
No person shall dispose of any material or type of waste listed below, either in solution or solid form, at the city
solid waste landfill, or within the city limits, or within 5000 feet of its boundaries, to wit:

https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 324/420
(1) Any waste listed as a hazardous waste in 40 Code of Federal Regulations part 261, subparts C
and D, to include any volatile organic compounds (VOCs) for which required analytical procedures
provided in Environmental Protection Agency Report SW-846, Test Methods for Evaluating Solid
Waste, Third Edition, November, 1986, as revised December, 1987, include Method 8260, and 15
metals for which SW-846 provides either Method 6010 or a method from the 7000 series of methods.
(2) Any waste determined to be hazardous pursuant to section 335.504 of the Industrial Solid
Waste and Municipal Hazardous Waste Regulations promulgated by the state commission on
environmental quality.
(3) Any noxious or malodorous substance which, either singularly or by interaction with other
substances, is capable of causing objectionable odors or hazard to life.
(4) Any radioactive wastes (liquid or solid) greater than allowable releases specified by current
United States Bureau of Standards handbooks dealing with the handling and release of radioactivity,
and no transient concentration higher than 100 microcuries per liter shall be permitted.
(5) Any friable or regulated nonfriable asbestos waste. (Regulated asbestos-containing material as
defined in 40 CFR 61, as amended, includes friable asbestos material; category I nonfriable ACM
that has become friable; category I nonfriable ACM that will be or has been subjected to sanding,
grinding, cutting, or abrading; or category II nonfriable ACM that has a high probability of becoming
or has become crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder by the forces expected to act on the
material in the course of demolition or renovation operations.)
(6) Hazardous waste. Any solid waste identified or listed as a hazardous waste by the administrator
of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as
amended by the Resource and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq., as amended.
(7) Infectious waste. Waste containing pathogens or biologically active material which because of
its type, concentration, and quantity is capable of transmitting disease to persons exposed to the
waste.
(8) Liquid waste. Any waste material that is determined to contain “free liquids” as defined by
EPA Method 9095 (Paint Filter Test), as described in Test Methods for Evaluating Solid Wastes,
Physical/Chemical Methods (EPA Publication Number SW-846), including liquid septage and solid
material pumped from a septic tank, cesspool, or similar sewage treatment system. Containers
containing liquid waste shall not be accepted for disposal unless:
(A) The container is a small container similar in size to that normally found in household
waste;
(B) The container is designated to hold liquids for use other than storage;
(C) The waste is household waste.
(9) PCB waste. Those PCBs and PCB items that are subject to the disposal requirements of 40
CFR 761. Substances that are regulated by 40 CFR 761 include, but are not limited to, PCB articles,
PCB article containers, PCB containers, PCB-contaminated electrical equipment, PCB equipment,
PCB transformers, recycled PCBs, capacitors, microwave ovens, electronic equipment, and light
ballasts and fixtures.
(10) Special waste. Any solid waste or combination of solid wastes that because of its quantity,
concentration, physical or chemical characteristics or biological properties requires special handling
and disposal to protect human health or the environment. If improperly handled, transported, stored,

Sec. 13.02.183 Industrial solid wastes
(a) Industrial solid wastes originating within the city limits, or within areas of the county covered by a landfill
services contract or agreement, may be accepted only under the following conditions:
(1) Class 1 industrial solid wastes are prohibited, except with prior written approval of the state
commission on environmental quality and a written contract approved by the city manager, provided
the acceptance of such waste does not interfere with site operation.
(2) Class 2 industrial solid wastes, except special wastes, may be accepted provided that the
acceptance of such waste does not interfere with site operation.
(3) Class 3 industrial solid waste may be accepted, provided the acceptance of such waste does not
interfere with the operation of the landfill.
(b) Any industrial waste for which there is insufficient information, either by process knowledge or analytical
data, shall automatically be classified as a class 1 industrial waste and shall not be disposed of in the landfill.
(c) Empty containers shall be classified according to the materials held in the container and any treatment
applied to the empty container. A container which has held a hazardous substance, a hazardous waste, or a class
1 waste is automatically classified as a class 1 waste. However, any such container may be classified as a class 2
waste if it has been emptied and cleaned as described in this section. A container which has held class 2 wastes
is classified as a class 2 waste.
(d) Paper, cardboard, food wastes, glass, aluminum foil, plastics, styrofoam and other types of food packaging
and general office trash is designated as “plant refuse” and classified as class 2 waste. Plant waste shall not
include oils, lubricants, oil filters, contaminated soils, sludges, wastewaters, or any other waste which would be
subject to the class 1 waste criteria.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 327/420
(1998 Code, sec. 71.063)
Sec. 13.02.184 Construction and demolition wastes
(a) Only construction and demolition wastes originating from property located within the city limits shall be
allowed to be deposited in the landfill, unless said disposal is allowed by a contract or agreement.
(b) Transporters or drivers of vehicles transporting construction and demolition waste to the landfill shall not
permit waste to blow or spill from the vehicle transporting such wastes.
(c) All construction and demolition wastes taken to the city solid waste landfill shall be placed and deposited
at the solid waste landfill under the direction of and shall be inspected by authorized landfill employees. Said
employees are not required to accept any construction and demolition wastes which they determine will cause
operational problems.
(d) The unloading of construction and demolition wastes in unauthorized areas is prohibited. Any construction
and demolition wastes deposited in an unauthorized area shall be removed and disposed of properly by the
person transporting said wastes.
(e) No construction or demolition wastes mixed or commingled with any other type of waste shall be accepted
at the landfill.
(f) Disposal of large, heavy, or bulky construction and demolition wastes which cannot be incorporated in the
regular spreading, compaction, and covering operations may be prohibited. The disposal of large and/or heavy
rocks, pieces of concrete or any other heavy material is prohibited. Landfill employees shall require that said
materials be broken into smaller pieces before disposal.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.064)
Sec. 13.02.185 Trees, brush and yard wastes
(a) Transporters or drivers of vehicles transporting trees, brush and yard wastes to the landfill shall not permit
waste to blow or spill from the vehicle transporting such wastes.
(b) All trees, brush and yard wastes taken to the city solid waste landfill shall be placed and deposited upon
the solid waste landfill under the direction of and shall be inspected by authorized landfill employees. Said
employees are not required to accept any trees, brush and yard wastes which they determine will cause
operational problems.
(c) The unloading of trees, brush and yard wastes in unauthorized areas is prohibited. Any trees, brush and
yard wastes deposited in an unauthorized area shall be removed and disposed of properly by the person
transporting said wastes. Trees, brush and yard wastes shall be deposited in an area designated for recycling of
said materials.
(d) No trees, brush or yard wastes mixed or commingled with any other type of waste shall be accepted at the
landfill.
(e) All trees and tree stumps taken to the landfill shall be trimmed free of branches and cut into lengths not to
exceed ten inches (10") in diameter and four feet (4') in length, and the weight of such lengths shall not exceed
sixty (60) pounds.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.065)
Sec. 13.02.186 Agricultural wastes
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 328/420
(a) Agricultural wastes are classified as industrial solid wastes and shall be disposed of according to the
provisions of this article providing for the disposal of industrial wastes. Only class 2 and class 3 industrial
wastes may be accepted, provided that the acceptance of said wastes does not interfere with site operation.
(b) Any agricultural waste which because of its concentration or physical or chemical characteristics is toxic,
corrosive, flammable, or a strong sensitizer or irritant, [or] a generator of sudden pressure by decomposition,
heat, or other means and may pose a substantial present or potential danger to human health or the environment
when improperly processed, stored, transported, or otherwise managed, or otherwise classified as a hazardous
waste or class 1 industrial waste, shall not be disposed of in the landfill.
(c) Empty containers shall be classified according to the materials held in the container and any treatment
applied to the empty container. A container which has held a hazardous substance, a hazardous waste, or a class
1 waste is automatically classified as a class 1 waste. However, any such container may be classified as a class 2
waste if it has been emptied and cleaned as described in this section. A container which has held class 2 wastes
is classified as a class 2 waste.
(1) Empty containers which have been used for pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, or rodenticides
may be disposed of at the landfill provided that:
(A) The containers are triple-rinsed prior to receipt at the landfill (triple rinse: to rinse a
container three times using a volume of solvent equal to ten percent of the volume of the
container or liner for each rinse);
(B) The containers are rendered unusable prior to or upon receipt at the landfill;
(C) The containers are covered at the end of the same working day they are received.
(2) Those containers for which triple-rinsing is not feasible or practical, such as paper bags or
cardboard containers, may be disposed of if:
(A) The generator of the wastes is a conditionally exempt small quantity generator;
(B) The amount of wastes does not exceed 220 pounds per month per generator; and
(C) The containers are covered at the end of the same working day they are received with at
least three feet of normal solid waste.
(d) Treated or coated seeds, burrs or hulls are automatically classified as a class 1 waste and shall not be
disposed of in the landfill.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.066)
Sec. 13.02.187 Wastes containing asbestos
(a) Wastes containing nonregulated asbestos-containing materials (non-RACM) may be accepted for disposal
at the landfill provided the wastes are placed on the active working face and covered at the end of the working
day. The following non-RACM may be accepted at the landfill upon inspection and approval by the sanitation
superintendent or an authorized landfill employee:
(1) Category I nonfriable asbestos, including:
(A) Gaskets;
(B) Packing;
(C) Resilient floor covering;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 329/420
(D) Asphalt roofing products; and
(2) Category II nonfriable asbestos, including:
(A) Transite asbestos shingles;
(B) Transite asbestos pipe; and
(C) Any nonfriable asbestos material not defined as category I that, when dry, cannot be
crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder by hand pressure.
(b) The following wastes containing regulated asbestos-containing materials (RACM), as defined in 40
Federal Regulations (CFR) part 61, may not be accepted for disposal at the landfill:
(1) All friable asbestos products that, when dry, can be crushed to a powder by hand pressure, and
shall include:
(A) All blown-in insulation;
(B) Some pipe wrapping;
(C) Some ceiling tiles; and
(2) Any asbestos-containing material from outside the boundaries of the state.
(c) The sanitation superintendent or any landfill employee is authorized to reject for disposal in the landfill
any asbestos-containing material that has a high probability of becoming or has become crumbled, pulverized, or
reduced to powder in the course of demolition or renovation operations; or which may become crumbled,
pulverized, or reduced to powder in the course of disposal or landfill operations. It shall be unlawful for any
person to fail to remove any such materials rejected for disposal from the landfill when ordered to do so by any
authorized city employee. It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any said materials so rejected within
the city limits, or within 5000 feet of its boundaries.
(d) It shall be unlawful to dispose of any material containing non-RACM in the landfill or to place or allow to
be placed any material containing non-RACM on any surface or roadway which is subject to vehicular traffic or
disposed of by any other means by which the material could be crumbled into a friable state.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.067)
Sec. 13.02.188 Wastes from health care related facilities
(a) Microbiological waste, blood, blood products, body fluids, laboratory specimens of blood and tissue, and
animal bedding from health care related facilities which have been treated on-site in accordance with the
provisions of 25 TAC 136(a) (section 1.136(a)) may be disposed of in the landfill as routine municipal solid
waste provided any markings which identify the waste as a special waste from health care related facilities are
covered with a label which identifies the waste as treated medical waste.
(b) Carcasses and body parts of animals designated as a special waste from health care related facilities,
recognizable human body parts, tissues, fetuses, organs and the products of human abortions, spontaneous or
induced, shall not be disposed of in the landfill.
(c) Sharps which have been treated by the following an approved methods may be disposed of in the landfill:
(1) Broken glassware and pipettes may be placed in puncture-resistant packaging;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 330/420
(2) Hypodermic needles, syringes with attached needles, scalpel blades, and/or razors shall be
placed in containers designed for sharps and encapsulated by addition of an agent to the container
which will solidify and encase the contents of the container with a solid matrix; and
(3) Sharps which have been treated by an approved method which incorporates grinding and/or
shredding in the process may be disposed of as routine municipal solid waste if the sharps have been
made unrecognizable and significantly reduced in ability to cause puncture wounds.
(d) Other regulated medical waste which has not been mixed or commingled with special wastes from health
care related facilities and which is not contained within recognizable biohazard bags may be discarded with
routine municipal solid waste provided a label has been affixed to the container which states that the waste
within the container is not a special waste from health care related facilities.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.068)
Sec. 13.02.189 Ownership of contents
All solid waste and other material deposited in the solid waste landfill is the property of the city, and it shall be
unlawful for any person to separate and collect, carry off or dispose of same, except under the direction of the
superintendent of sanitation. (1998 Code, sec. 71.069)
Secs. 13.02.190–13.02.220 Reserved
Division 6. Recycling and Resource Recovery
Sec. 13.02.221 Ownership of waste deposited in solid waste management system
All solid wastes and other materials lawfully deposited or otherwise introduced into the solid waste management
system of the city, including any dumpster or other collection point, become the property of the city, and it shall
be unlawful for any person to scavenge, salvage, separate and collect, carry off or dispose of same, except under
the direction of the superintendent of sanitation. (1998 Code, sec. 71.091)
Sec. 13.02.222 Salvaging of recyclable materials
(a) No person shall engage in the act of salvaging recyclable materials from the solid waste management
system of the city without a contractual agreement signed by the city manager.
(1) In order to safeguard the health, general welfare, and physical property of the people and to
protect the environment by encouraging the reduction in solid waste generation and the proper
management of solid waste, the city manager may contract with any number of persons for the
salvaging of recyclable materials for a period not to exceed one year.
(2) Said contract shall hold the city harmless from any act of the party obtaining said contract.
(3) Said contract shall provide for a payment to the city in an amount of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00), except that the city manager may waive said payment for certain nonprofit organizations.
Said payment shall be in relation to the amount of materials expected to be salvaged minus the cost
that may have been incurred by the city in the collection and disposal of said materials.
(4) If the city manager determines that it is in the best interest of the city to contract with a
nonprofit organization for the salvaging of certain materials, the city manager may authorize payment
to subsidize said salvaging activities.
(b) Salvaging shall not interfere with prompt sanitary disposal of solid waste or create a public health
nuisance.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 331/420
(c) All salvaged materials shall be removed from the collection site or sanitary landfill site at such intervals as
necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of the material at the site.
(d) Class I and special wastes, as defined by the municipal solid waste regulations promulgated by the state
commission on environmental quality, shall not be salvaged.
(e) Pesticide, fungicide, rodenticide, and herbicide containers shall not be salvaged.
(f) Scavenging is not allowed.
(g) The following salvaging methods are allowed:
(1) Collection from the sanitary landfill by means of pre-disposal separation of salvageable
materials.
(2) Collection of materials at the source of initial disposal when said materials have been separated
from other materials to be disposed of by regular means.
(h) The following salvaging methods are not allowed:
(1) Collection from the sanitary landfill by means of removing materials from the working face of
the landfill or at any other secondary storage point containing materials for disposal in the working
face.
(2) Collection of materials from dumpsters or any other collection point containing garbage or
refuse mixed with said materials.
(1998 Code, sec. 71.092)
ARTICLE 13.03 WATER AND WASTEWATER SERVICE*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.03.001 Purpose; scope
This article covers all aspects of water, wastewater and utilities administration and regulation under the authority
of the city and is enacted to implement the stated purpose of protecting the health, safety and welfare of the
people of the city. (1998 Code, sec. 72.001)
Sec. 13.03.002 Applicability of article
The provisions of this article shall apply to all territory within the corporate limits of the city and to any and all
territory subsequently annexed into said corporate limits and to the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city as
specified, and shall apply to any individual, corporation, organization, government, governmental subdivision or
agency, business trust, partnership, association, or other legal entity, including all federal installations involved
in any aspect of the provision of drinking water and wastewater services within the city limits. (1998 Code, sec.
72.002)
Sec. 13.03.003 Applicability of state law
The provisions of chapter 402 of the Local Government Code, granting home-rule cities the power to operate
utility systems and to adopt rules and regulations relating to utility services; Health and Safety Code, section
341.002, prescribing the duties of the department of state health services relating to the regulation and control of
public drinking water systems, and the Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems as promulgated by the
state department of health shall apply and the city shall exercise all authority granted under said statutes; and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 332/420
when it appears that a violation of said statutes or any rule, regulation, permit, license, or other order of an
appropriate state agency granted in said statutes occurs or is occurring within the jurisdiction or extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the city, or is causing or will cause injury to or an adverse effect on the health, welfare or physical
property of the city or its inhabitants, then the city may cause a civil suit to be instituted in district court through
its own attorney for the injunctive relief or civil penalties, or both, as authorized in said statutes, against the
person who committed, is committing, or is threatening to commit the violation. (1998 Code, sec. 72.003)
Sec. 13.03.004 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following words and terms have the meanings ascribed to them by this
section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. In addition, other technical terms used shall have their
meanings or definitions listed in the latest edition of “Glossary, Water and Wastewater Control Engineering,”
prepared by a joint editorial board representing the American Public Health Association, the American Society
of Civil Engineers, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Foundation.
Apartment. A room or suite of rooms arranged, designed or occupied by a family, and shall include, but not be
limited to, a subordinate dwelling occupied as a garage apartment or a servant's quarters.
Apartment house. A building or portion thereof, or buildings, arranged, designed or occupied by three (3) or
more families.
Boarding house. A building or portion thereof, other than a hotel, where lodging and meals for five (5) or more
persons are served for compensation.
BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand). The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of
organic matter under a standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C),
expressed in parts per million by weight.
Building drain. That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from
soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer,
beginning three (3) feet outside the inner face of the building wall.
Building sewer. The extension from the public drain to the public wastewater system or other place of disposal.
City manager. The city manager or his authorized deputy, agent, or representative.
Commercial service. Water and wastewater services rendered to stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and
other non-manufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial activities.
Contamination. The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in water
which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water.
Cross-connection. A physical connection between a public water system and either another supply of unknown
or questionable quality, any source which may contain contaminating or polluting substances, or any source of
water treated to a lesser degree than in the treatment process.
Customer. A person legally connected to, consuming, and paying for service from the water supply or using the
wastewater or sewer system of the city.
Drinking water. All water distributed by the water system for the purpose of human consumption or which may
be used in the preparation of foods or beverages or for the cleaning of any utensil or article used in the course of
preparation or consumption of food or beverages for human beings, including all water supplied for human
consumption by any institution catering to the public.
Family. One (1) or more individuals living as a single housekeeping unit.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 333/420
Garbage. Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage
and sale of produce.
Health hazard. Any conditions, devices or practices in the water supply system and/or its operation which may
create, or may create, [sic] a danger to the public health and well-being of the water customer.
Hotel. The space in a building designed for occupancy as a more or less temporary abiding place of individuals
who are lodged with or without meals, in which there are more than twelve (12) sleeping rooms, and in which,
as a rule, the rooms are occupied singly for hire, and provision is not usually made for cooking in any individual
apartment.
Industrial wastes. The liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage.
Motel. The area, including a building or portion thereof, or buildings, where families, transients or tourists are
accommodated, and shall include, but not exclusively, a trailer camp.
Natural outlet. Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater.
One-family residence. A detached building having accommodations for and occupied by one (1) family.
Person. An individual, corporation, organization, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business
trust, partnership, association, or any other legal entity.
pH. The logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution.
Premises. A tract of land with the buildings thereon, or a building or part of a building with its grounds or other
appurtenances.
Properly shredded garbage. The wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been
shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in
public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension.
Public sewer. A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public
authority.
Public utility. Any person engaged in regularly supplying the public within the city with some commodity or
service which is of special consequence and need, such as electricity, gas, transportation, and telephone service.
Rooming house. A building or portion thereof, other than a hotel, where five (5) or more persons are lodged for
compensation.
Sanitary sewer. A sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and groundwaters are not
intentionally admitted.
Sewage. Means the same as “wastewater.”
Sewage treatment plant. Means the same as “wastewater treatment plant.”
Sewage works. All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage.
Sewer. A pipe or conduit designed to collect and transport wastewater.
Sewer service. Means the same as “wastewater service.”
Storm sewer or storm drain. A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage
and polluted industrial wastes.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 334/420
Superintendent. The superintendent of water and wastewater of the city or his authorized deputy, agent, or
representative.
Suspended solids. Solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids,
and which are removable by laboratory filtering.
Two-family residence. A detached building having separate accommodations for and occupied as a dwelling by
two (2) families.
Wastewater. Domestic or industrial waste carried in the drains of the sanitary sewer. The liquid and water-carried
industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions,
together which may be present whether treated or untreated, [sic] which is contributed into or permitted to enter
the wastewater treatment plant, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present.
Wastewater service. The collection, treatment, and disposal of domestic or industrial waste from the premises of
a person legally connected to, consuming, and paying for such service.
Wastewater service meter. A device intended to measure the amount of wastewater flowing through a
wastewater line for the purpose of determining the amount of wastewater used by a customer for billing
purposes.
Wastewater system. All property owned and controlled by the city, including its wastewater treatment plant,
mains and system and the organization used by the city in treating the wastewater generated by the inhabitants of
the city and vicinity, shall constitute and be known as the city wastewater system.
Water and wastewater department. Either the water and wastewater department of the city or the duly authorized
agents of said department.
Water and wastewater superintendent. Either the water and wastewater superintendent, his superiors, or his duly
authorized agents.
Watercourse. A channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently.
Water service. The delivery of water to the premises of a person legally connected to and paying for such
service.
Water service connection. A single-family residential unit or each commercial or industrial establishment to
which drinking water is supplied from the system.
Water service meter. A device intended to measure the amount of water flowing through a water line for the
purpose of determining the amount of water used by a customer for billing purposes.
Water superintendent. Means the same as “water and wastewater superintendent.”
Water system. All property owned and controlled by the city, including its plant, water supply, mains and system
and the organization used by the city in furnishing an adequate supply of water to the inhabitants of the city and
vicinity, shall constitute and be known as the city water system.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.011)
Sec. 13.03.005 Penalty
Any person, firm or individual who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this article or
who shall fail to perform any act which this article imposes a duty to perform shall be guilty of a misdemeanor,
and upon conviction shall be fined in a sum not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one thousand
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 335/420
dollars ($1000.00), and each and every day a violation exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.008)
Sec. 13.03.006 Assent to provisions by consumers
All of the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be incorporated in every contract between the water and
wastewater department and its consumers, and each consumer shall be charged with knowledge of the provisions
of this article and, by applying and accepting water from the water and wastewater department, to have assented
to the provisions hereof. (1998 Code, sec. 72.004)
Sec. 13.03.007 Efforts to obtain voluntary compliance
Nothing in this article shall prevent the city or its agents from making efforts to obtain voluntary compliance
through warning, conference or any other appropriate means. (1998 Code, sec. 72.009)
Sec. 13.03.008 Access to premises
The water and wastewater superintendent and employees of the water and wastewater department shall have
access at all reasonable hours to all premises supplied with water for the purpose of seeing that the terms of this
article applicable to water and wastewater usage are being observed, and refusal by any consumer shall result in
refusal of water supply from the city water system until such permission is granted. (1998 Code, sec. 72.005)
Sec. 13.03.009 Damaging or tampering with water or wastewater system
It shall be unlawful for any person, individually or in association with others, to willfully break, injure or tamper
with any part of the water or wastewater system of the city for any purpose whatsoever, or in any other manner
maliciously to interfere with or prevent the running and operation of such system and the water supply therein.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.006)
State law reference–Criminal mischief by tampering with public communications, public water, gas, or power supply, V.T.C.A., Penal
Code, sec. 28.03.
Sec. 13.03.010 Extensions
(a) Extensions inside city limits.
(1) All property inside the city limits as of February 15, 1959, will be entitled to water and sewer
extension of one hundred feet (100') per connection. The provision shall not prohibit the city from
extending water and wastewater service into areas and specific locations where water and wastewater
service would best serve the public welfare.
(2) The customer shall be responsible for furnishing and laying the necessary customer water
service pipe from the meter location to the place of consumption and shall keep the customer service
line in good repair. For new water service taps, the customer shall be required to install a customerowned
cut-off valve on the customer's side of the meter or connection. The customer shall be
responsible for furnishing and laying the necessary wastewater customer service line from the main
to the point of service, including installation of the service tap.
(b) Extensions outside city limits.
(1) It shall be unlawful to make any connection of water and wastewater services to any residence,
house, building or premises outside the corporate limits of the city, except as provided in subsection
(c) below.
(2) This section shall not affect or change any agreement or contract for providing water or
wastewater services entered into by the city on or before the effective date of this section.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 336/420
(3) No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement
or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby water or wastewater services
may be accepted by the city subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern at rates set by the
city council.
(4) For meters outside the city limits for those who are connected directly to the Canadian River
Municipal Water Authority pipeline, users of city water shall pay one hundred fifty percent (150%) of
the established rate paid for similar customers inside the city limits.
(c) Permitted connections outside city limits.
(1) Connections of water and wastewater services may be made to a residence, house, building or
premises outside the corporate limits of the city, provided:
(A) The property to which the connection of water and wastewater service is to be made is
not contiguous to the corporate limits of the city;
(B) The owner of the property to which the connection of water and wastewater services is to
be made agrees to voluntarily annex the property into the city when and if the requirements of
annexation are met and the conditions for annexation exist; and
(C) The city, in its sole discretion, shall determine whether it is in the best interest of the city
that such connection of water and wastewater services be made.
(2) If a connection of water and wastewater services is made outside the corporate limits of the city
under this subsection, all of the provisions of subsection (a)(2) of this section shall apply to such
connection, and the rates to be paid to the city for such water and wastewater services shall be the
same as those established from time to time for other customers of water and wastewater services
outside the corporate limits of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.007)
Sec. 13.03.011 Exemptions
Any person may apply to the city council for an exemption or partial exemption to the provisions of this article,
and an exemption may be granted, after a public hearing and affirmative vote of the city council, if it is found
that:
(1) The violation occurring or proposed to occur does not constitute a danger to public health or
safety;
(2) The violation occurring or proposed to occur will not be for more than ninety (90) days;
(3) Compliance with the provision from which exemption is sought would produce serious
hardship without equal benefits to the public;
(4) If the exemption is granted, it would not constitute a violation of any other city ordinance or
federal or state law or regulation; and
(5) The violation occurring or proposed to occur does not involve a violation of the plumbing code
of the city.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.010)
Secs. 13.03.012–13.03.050 Reserved
