Division 2. Water Service*
Sec. 13.03.051 Generally
(a) All water service and water service connections shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this
article, the plumbing code of the city, and the Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems as promulgated
by the department of state health services.
(b) All residences, commercial businesses and all other entities located within the city limits are required to
use the city water and sewer facilities.
(c) There shall be no free service or use of the facilities permitted by anyone or any entity or business located
within or without the city limits.
(d) This article shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of the law.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.021)
Sec. 13.03.052 Meters
(a) All water furnished by the water and wastewater department to its customers shall be measured by meters,
which shall be installed by the city on the premises of each customer. The size, type and right to own and control
all water service meters installed or used shall be determined by the water department.
(b) The water service meters installed for water customers shall remain the property of the city.
(c) The city may require certain commercial and industrial users to purchase, install and maintain specialized
water service meters if it is deemed in the best interests of the city by the water and wastewater superintendent.
(d) The city may require persons requiring temporary service for construction purposes to furnish, install and
maintain water service meters if it is deemed in the best interests of the city by the water and wastewater
superintendent.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.022)
Sec. 13.03.053 Unlawful use of water or water facilities
(a) Any person who intentionally by any means or device prevents water from passing through any meter
belonging to the water and wastewater department or used in conjunction with the supply of water to any
consumer by the water department to register the amount of water passing through meters, or intentionally
prevents a meter from duly registering the quantity of water supplied, or in any way interferes with its proper
action or just registration or without the consent in writing of the water and wastewater superintendent
intentionally diverts any water from any pipe of the city waterworks, or otherwise intentionally uses, or causes to
be used, without the consent of the water and wastewater department, any water produced or distributed by the
water and wastewater department with intent to defraud the city water system, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(b) The presence at any time of any device or pipes resulting in the diversion of water or preventing of its free
passage and registration by the meter or diverting the meter as above defined or resulting in the prevention of
water reaching the meter, or preventing the just registration of the meter of the taking of any water, except
through a meter as above set forth, shall constitute prima facie evidence of knowledge on the part of the person
owning or having custody and control of the room, building, place or premises where such device or pipe is of
the existence thereof and knowledge of such existence to the person who would be benefited by the failure of the
water to be properly metered, and shall further constitute prima facie evidence of intention on the part of such
person to defraud the city water system.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 338/420
(c) It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from the city water system without an application or
permission, or to turn on the city water for use on his premises after the same has been, for any reason, cut off,
except only in case of repairs, or before the same has been turned on by the city without having first secured
permission from the water and wastewater department to turn on the water at such place. If any person breaks or
damages a curb valve on his premises while turning water off or on, that person shall be liable for damages as
determined by the water and wastewater department.
(d) Any person, property owner or occupant, who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any sum not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00). Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense,
and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
(e) In addition to the remedies provided for above, any person, property owner or occupant, who shall violate
the provisions of this section shall also be responsible for payment for the estimated amount of water taken in
violation of same, from the date of last reading of the water service meter on said person's place or premises, and
shall furthermore be responsible for the payment for any and all damages caused to the water and wastewater
system in the conduct of such acts. In the event the water service meter has been removed by said person or
persons or has been broken or damaged, then said person or persons shall be charged for the estimated amount of
water used during the period of time said meter was not registering the amount of water plus the cost of
repairing the meter, and water meter repair charges shall be determined by the water and wastewater
superintendent. No reconnection to the water and wastewater system shall be made until all monetary claims by
the city water system have been resolved or provision for resolution of such claims has been made to the
satisfaction of the director of finance.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.023)
Sec. 13.03.054 Taking water from hydrant
It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with any fire hydrant for the purpose of taking water therefrom,
except:
(1) By members of the fire department engaged in the suppression of fires or for training purposes;
(2) By employees of city departments engaged in city business who have made prior arrangements
with the water and wastewater superintendent for the delivery of said water; and
(3) By persons who have contracted with the director of finance for the bulk purchase of metered
or unmetered water for construction or other commercial or industrial purposes, and have made prior
arrangements with the water and wastewater superintendent for the delivery of said water.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.024)
Sec. 13.03.055 Repair or replacement of service pipes; relocation of meter
(a) The water and wastewater department reserves the right to make all repairs and replacements of service
lines or pipes from the main line to the water service meter, and it shall be unlawful for any other person to
repair or replace or attempt to repair or replace any such lines or pipes.
(b) The water and wastewater department reserves the right to relocate any meter if it is required because of
the relocation of any mains, connections, or extensions of the water and wastewater system, and may relocate
the meter at the most convenient location on the customer's service line.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.025)
Sec. 13.03.056 Temporary disconnection of water supply
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 339/420
The right is reserved by the water and wastewater department to temporarily disconnect and to reconnect
without notice the water supply to all customers for the purpose of making repairs, connections, extensions and
cleaning of mains, machinery, reservoirs or any part of the city water system. (1998 Code, sec. 72.026)
Sec. 13.03.057 Furnishing water to other persons
No consumer shall supply water to other persons or suffer them to take water, except for use on the premises,
without the permission of the water and wastewater department. Provided, however, water service may be
supplied to multifamily dwellings as set forth in this article. (1998 Code, sec. 72.027)
Sec. 13.03.058 Cross-connections
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to:
(1) Make or have made any cross-connection between piping receiving water from the city water
system and piping receiving water from any other source or storage, including private wells or
otherwise;
(2) Install, or permit the installation of, any plumbing fixture, device or other type of construction
which will provide a cross-connection between the city water system and a drainage system, soil or
waste pipe so as to permit or make possible the backflow of sewage or waste into the water supply
system;
(3) Install or permit inflow, so as to make a cross-connection, from the city water system to a
swimming pool or other storage of water to a point below overflow level.
(b) The existence of a cross-connection is hereby declared a nuisance and an immediate threat to the health,
welfare, and safety to the residents of the city, and the removal of any cross-connection is a matter of public
emergency.
(1) It shall be the duty of the water and wastewater superintendent to immediately and without
further notice disconnect the service connecting such piping with the city water system.
(2) After termination of water services, said services may be reconnected to the customer provided
that the customer obtains a plumbing permit and has the plumbing corrected so as to comply with the
provisions of this section. After the plumbing inspector has approved the plumbing and ascertained
that there is no longer a cross-connection, the water and wastewater department shall reconnect the
premises to the water system upon payment of a reconnection service charge.
(c) Any person desiring to use water from any other source in addition to the city water system may do so in
accordance with a method approved by the plumbing code of the city and section 337.206(g) of the Rules and
Regulations for Public Water Systems as promulgated by the department of state health services regulating
backflow and siphonage, and after inspection and approval by the plumbing inspector and water and wastewater
superintendent.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.028)
State law reference–Backflow prevention for water closet plumbing fixtures or other equipment, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code, sec.
1301.501.
Sec. 13.03.059 Prohibited acts
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a duly authorized employee of the city, to commit, assist in
committing or allow any of the following things or acts in the city:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 340/420
(1) To disturb, break, injure or tamper with, remove or relocate any water meter, water meter box,
or water meter dial; or attempt to manipulate any water meter in the city in any manner so as to affect
its registration; or in any other manner maliciously to interfere with or prevent the running and
operation of such system and the water supply therein;
(2) To open or close any gate valves or shutoffs thereof or to open the covers of same without the
permission of the water and wastewater superintendent;
(3) To cover over or conceal from view any water valve box, service or meter box with dirt, paving
material or any other substance after it has been set for service by the city;
(4) To retain possession of or refuse to deliver a water service meter or other appliance loaned to
that person by the water and wastewater department for the purposes of furnishing water through
same; and
(5) To go upon or ascend the stairway or steps on any elevated water storage tank or standpipe of
the water system, except by permission of the water and wastewater superintendent.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.029)
Sec. 13.03.060 Private water supply
That water well contractors shall be required to secure a permit from the plumbing inspector of the city prior to
construction and installation of a water well on any private property in the city; providing for a permit fee of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for the issuance of said permit. (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
Secs. 13.03.061–13.03.100 Reserved
Division 3. Wastewater Service*
Sec. 13.03.101 Unlawful disposal of wastewater
It shall be unlawful for any person owning, living on or renting any property abutting or adjoining any street or
alley in which wastewater system pipes have been laid, except in the event such sewer pipe is not constructed in
a manner suitable for taking care of such wastewater or substance, to throw or allow to be thrown or deposited
on the surface of the ground or in any hole, cesspool or vault or in or under the surface of the ground, except for
the proper and necessary manuring of the soil, any water which has been used for domestic purposes, or any
liquid or solid filth, feces or urine. (1998 Code, sec. 72.041)
Sec. 13.03.102 Connection of sources of surface or drain water to sanitary sewer
It shall be unlawful for any person to make or have made any connection with the wastewater system of the city
that will permit any surface or drain water from the ground or from the roofs of any building or other structure to
drain into such wastewater system directly or indirectly; provided, however, that cellars may be connected with
such wastewater system when made in accordance with the regulations, plans and specifications of the city
inspector and under his supervision. (1998 Code, sec. 72.042)
Sec. 13.03.103 Injuring system; prohibited substances
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, break or remove any portion of a manhole, lamp hole, flush tank or
any part of the wastewater system or throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited in any wastewater
opening or receptacle connected with the wastewater system any garbage, offal, dead animal, or things
whatsoever except feces, urine and the necessary toilet paper and liquid or liquefied house waste. (1998 Code,
sec. 72.043)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 341/420
Sec. 13.03.104 Unlawful use of facilities
(a) Whoever intentionally, by any means or device, connects to the city wastewater system, or allows
wastewater to enter the city wastewater system, to avoid payment of wastewater charges shall be in violation of
this article and shall be fined for such violation as set out in this article. The existence of an unlawfully installed
wastewater tap shall constitute prima facie evidence of knowledge on the part of the person owning or having
custody and control of the room, building, place or premises where such device is located of such illegally
installed wastewater tap.
(b) Any person illegally using wastewater system facilities shall be billed for all wastewater system charges
which were evaded from the time the customer first connected to the wastewater system. The charge estimate
shall be made by the water and wastewater superintendent and shall be based on the established rate at the time
the violation was discovered.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.044)
Sec. 13.03.105 Meters
(a) The city may require certain residential, commercial and industrial users to purchase, install and maintain
specialized wastewater service meters if it is deemed in the best interests of the city by the water and wastewater
superintendent.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a duly authorized employee of the city, to break, injure or
tamper with any wastewater meter, wastewater meter box, or wastewater meter dial, or attempt to manipulate
any wastewater meter in the city in any manner so as to affect its registration, or in any other manner to interfere
with or prevent the running and operation of such system.
(c) It shall be unlawful for any person to retain possession of or refuse to deliver a wastewater service meter
or other appliance loaned to that person by the water and wastewater department.
(d) The customer at whose instance and request the service has been supplied shall be primarily liable to the
city for any and all damage that may occur to said meter and protective cover box. In addition to any other
remedy the city may have to collect damages thereto, it may add such sums to the regular bill for water
consumption and, on failure to pay said amount when due, the city may discontinue the water service in the
same manner as provided for in cases where the water bill has not yet been paid.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.045)
Sec. 13.03.106 Damaging or tampering with wastewater works
No person shall willfully or negligently break, damage, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure,
appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the municipal wastewater works. Any person violating this
provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. (1998 Code, sec. 72.046)
Secs. 13.03.107–13.03.150 Reserved
Division 4. Discharge of Harmful Wastes*
Sec. 13.03.151 Purpose
This division sets forth uniform requirements for direct and indirect contributors into the wastewater collection
and treatment system of the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws
required by the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR, part 403). (1998
Code, sec. 72.061)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 342/420
Sec. 13.03.152 Water and wastewater superintendent
The city manager shall appoint a water and wastewater superintendent, and such assistants as the city manager
may determine to be necessary, and it shall be the duty of the superintendent to see that certain provisions of this
division as pertaining to the use of the public wastewater system are carried out, to determine if the wastewater
collected by the wastewater collection system is treatable, and to supervise the treatment of the sewage. (1998
Code, sec. 72.062)
Sec. 13.03.153 Right of entry
The city manager and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification
shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling, and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this division. (1998 Code, sec. 72.063)
Sec. 13.03.154 Violations; penalty
(a) Any person found to be violating any provision of this division shall be served by the city with written
notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The
offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. If the offender
continues the violation after the expiration of the time stated, the city manager may prohibit the further use of
the wastewater system by the offender and may remove or close the offender's building wastewater and water
connections.
(b) Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one thousand
dollars ($1000.00) for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(c) Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense,
loss, or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.077)
Sec. 13.03.155 Legal action
If any person discharges sewage, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater system contrary to
the provisions of this division or federal or state laws or regulations, the city may commence an action for
appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in an appropriate court. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the
city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, and all other expenses of litigation against the person
found to have violated this division or the rules, regulations, and permits issued hereunder. (1998 Code, sec.
72.078)
Sec. 13.03.156 Remediation charges
If any person discharges wastewater, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater system contrary
to the provisions of this division or federal or state laws or regulations, the city may charge to and recover
reasonable expenses for remediation of the effects of said violation from the person found to have violated this
division or the rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. (1998 Code, sec. 72.079)
Sec. 13.03.157 Suspension of service
(a) The water and wastewater superintendent may suspend wastewater service when, in the opinion of said
superintendent, such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may
present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or to the environment, cause
interference to the wastewater treatment plant, or otherwise cause the city to violate any condition of its
wastewater treatment plant operating permit.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 343/420
(b) Any person notified of a suspension of the wastewater service shall immediately stop or eliminate the
condition or halt any further discharge into the wastewater collection system as specified by the water and
wastewater superintendent. In the event of a failure of the person to comply voluntarily with the suspension
order, the superintendent may take such steps as deemed necessary, including the immediate severance of the
wastewater or sewer connection, to prevent damage to the wastewater treatment plant or endangerment to any
persons. The city may reinstate wastewater service upon proof of the elimination of said discharge.
(c) The water and wastewater superintendent may require a written statement from the customer causing the
harmful discharge, describing the causes of said discharge and the measures taken to prevent any further
occurrences.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.064(a)–(d))
Sec. 13.03.158 Making false statement or certification; tampering with monitoring device
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false statement, representation or certification in any
statement or document required pursuant to this division, or to falsify, tamper with, or knowingly render
inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this division. (1998 Code, sec. 72.064(e))
Sec. 13.03.159 Discharge of stormwater, surface water, etc., to wastewater collection system
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, or
subsurface drainage waters to the wastewater collection system. (1998 Code, sec. 72.065)
Sec. 13.03.160 Discharge of polluted water into natural outlet
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge into any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the
jurisdiction of the city, any sanitary sewage, industrial waste or other polluted waters, except where suitable
treatment has been provided in accordance with the appropriate discharge regulations as promulgated by the
state commission on environmental quality. (1998 Code, sec. 72.066)
Sec. 13.03.161 Prohibited wastes generally; maximum limits
(a) In cases where, in the opinion of the superintendent, the character of wastewater or other liquid or solid
wastes from any manufacturer or industrial plant, building or other premises is such that it will damage the
system or cannot be treated satisfactorily in the system, the city manager shall have the right to require such user
to dispose of such waste otherwise, and prevent it from entering the system.
(b) Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the wastewater or
drainage system of the city, directly or indirectly, any of the following described matters, water or wastes:
(1) Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit
(150°F).
(2) Any water or waste which may contain more than one hundred (100) parts per million by
weight of fat, oil or grease.
(3) Any hydrocarbons such as gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, motor oil or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas.
(4) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
(5) Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, clothing, feathers, tar,
plastics, plastic bags, razors, wood, paunch manure, or other solid or viscous substances capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with proper operation of the sewage
works.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 344/420
(6) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 10.0 or having any other
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of
the sewage works.
(7) Any water or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance such as plating or heat treating
wastes in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, to constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater
treatment plant.
(8) Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual
attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the wastewater treatment plant.
(9) Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance.
(10) Any cyanide greater than 1.0 parts per million, as CN.
(11) Any hexavalent chromium greater than 1.0 [parts] per million.
(12) Any trivalent chromium greater than 10 parts per million.
(13) Any copper greater than 1.0 parts per million.
(14) Any nickel greater than 1.0 parts per million.
(15) Any cadmium greater than 1.0 parts per million.
(16) Any zinc greater than 1.0 parts per million.
(17) Any phenols greater than 12 parts per million.
(18) Any iron greater than 5 parts per million.
(19) Any tin greater than 1.0 parts per million.
(20) Any radioactive wastes greater than allowable releases as specified by current United States
Bureau of Standards handbooks dealing with the handling and release of radioactivity.
(21) Any other waste which may be designated as a special or prohibited waste by the state
commission on environmental quality, the department of state health services, the federal
Environmental Protection Agency or any other federal, state, or local agency having jurisdiction to
declare certain materials as hazardous or injurious to man or the environment and not allowed
elsewhere herein.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.067)
Sec. 13.03.162 Discharge of waste materials from poultry killing and processing plants, abattoirs and
slaughterhouses
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to permit or allow the discharge of blood, feathers,
entrails, heads, feet, stomach contents and other solid wastes resulting from the killing or processing of poultry
or other animals into the wastewater system of the city.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate a poultry killing and/or processing plant
or to operate an abattoir or slaughterhouse within the corporate limits of the city from which waste materials
from its operation are discharged into the wastewater system of the city, except that such waste materials may be
discharged into the wastewater system of the city if such waste materials are first passed through a separator or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 345/420
indirect waste receptor, which shall effectively retain all blood, feathers, entrails, heads, feet, stomach contents,
and other solid wastes resulting from the killing or processing of poultry or other animals prior to the discharge
of liquid waste into the wastewater system and if, in addition to said separator or indirect waste receptor, said
waste materials are then passed through a fixed grate which must be bolted or securely fastened in place prior to
the discharge of any waste materials into the wastewater system of the city. All screens over drain troughs shall
be constructed of wire, not smaller than eighteen (18) gauge with eight (8) mesh to the inch, and all drain outlets
shall be covered with plates bolted or securely fastened in place.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.068)
Sec. 13.03.163 Discharge of toxic or poisonous substances
(a) Where the operation of a person, firm or corporation entails the discharge of water or wastes containing
toxic or poisonous substances, a written statement on a standard form provided by the city manager, setting forth
the nature of the operation contemplated or presently carried on, shall be filed with the city manager. The
statement shall contain the amount of water which will be used and its source, the proposed point of discharge of
acid wastes into the wastewater system of the city, the estimated amount to be discharged, and a fair statement
setting forth the expected bacterial, physical, chemical, and other known characteristics of said wastes.
(b) Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such statement, it shall be the duty of the city manager to make an
order stating such minimum restrictions as in the judgment of the superintendent may be necessary to guard
adequately against unlawful uses of the city's wastewater works.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.069)
Sec. 13.03.164 Discharge of septic tank wastes
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge, empty or otherwise introduce the wastes from any septic tank,
cesspool, or chemical toilet or any similar receptacle for waste storage into the wastewater or sewer system of
the city, except that ordinary domestic wastes from small portable restrooms, campers, travel trailers or small
portable toilets intended for personal use may be disposed of at sites suitable or designated for the disposal of
same. (1998 Code, sec. 72.070)
Sec. 13.03.165 Interceptors
(a) Blood, grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided for the proper handling of liquid wastes
containing blood and grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, and other harmful
ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All
interceptors shall be of a type and capacity as approved by the plumbing code and shall be located as to be
readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
(b) Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in
continuously efficient operation at all times.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.071)
Sec. 13.03.166 Approval of admission of certain wastes; preliminary treatment facility requirements
(a) The admission into the public wastewater system of any waters or wastes having any of the following
characteristics shall be subject to the review and approval of the water and wastewater superintendent:
(1) A five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 250 parts per million by weight;
(2) Containing more than 250 parts per million by weight of suspended solids;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 346/420
(3) Containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in section 13.03.161
of this division; or
(4) Having an average daily flow greater than five percent (5%) of the average daily wastewater
flow of the city.
(b) When necessary in the opinion of the water and wastewater superintendent, the owner shall provide, at his
expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to:
(1) Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 250 parts per million and the suspended solids to
250 parts per million by weight;
(2) Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for
in section 13.03.161 of this division;
(3) Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes; or
(4) Meet any other requirements as specified by any applicable state or federal laws or regulations.
(c) Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment
facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent, and no construction of such facilities shall be
commenced until said approvals are obtained in writing.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.072)
Sec. 13.03.167 Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities
Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained
continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. (1998 Code, sec. 72.073)
Sec. 13.03.168 Control manholes
When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property served by a building wastewater line carrying
industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building wastewater lines to facilitate
observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and
safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole
shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at
all times. (1998 Code, sec. 72.074)
Sec. 13.03.169 Measurements, tests and analyses
All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in
this division shall be determined in accordance with Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and
Sewage as prescribed by the state commission on environmental quality, and shall be determined at the control
manhole provided for in section 13.03.168 of this division or upon suitable samples taken at said control
manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be
the nearest downstream manhole in the public wastewater system to the point at which the building wastewater
line is connected. (1998 Code, sec. 72.075)
Sec. 13.03.170 Special agreements for receipt of industrial wastes
No statement contained in this division shall be construed as preventing any agreement or arrangement between
the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted
by the city for treatment, subject to payment of a surcharge based on capital and operating cost. Such charge
shall be subject to change by the city council when capital and/or operating costs fluctuate. (1998 Code, sec.
72.076)

Secs. 13.03.171–13.03.210 Reserved
Division 5. Rates and Charges
Sec. 13.03.211 Establishment
The service rates and charges for water and wastewater services shall be fixed by the city council, except as
provided elsewhere in this article. (1998 Code, sec. 72.091)
Sec. 13.03.212 Authority of city manager
The city manager shall have the authority to decide any question which may arise and which is not fully covered
by any of the provisions of this article and shall have the right to fix and determine any water rate not provided
for in this article, and said decision in such cases shall be final, subject to modification by official action of the
city council. (1998 Code, sec. 72.092)
Sec. 13.03.213 Connection to water and wastewater system
(a) Any person desiring to have premises under such person's control connected with the water and
wastewater system of the city shall make application for those services to the director of finance on a form to be
provided by the director. The application shall contain and constitute a contract on the part of the applicant to
pay the city for the use and benefit of the water and wastewater department for all charges for those services
provided by the city to that person or premises, and to abide by any regulations of the city relating to those
services as those regulations exist and may be amended.
(b) The water and wastewater superintendent may set certain policies for the time, manner, and method of
connection to the water and wastewater system as may be deemed necessary for the orderly and efficient use of
the department's resources.
(c) All methods of connection to the water and wastewater system shall be in compliance with all applicable
plumbing codes as may be in effect at the time of connection, and the water and wastewater superintendent may
require that remedial measures be taken to bring any connection into conformity with existing codes, if said
action is necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of any person.
(d) The water and wastewater department may decline to serve an applicant which fails to be in compliance or
for the following reasons:
(1) If the applicant's installation or equipment is known to be inadequate or of such a character that
satisfactory service cannot be given;
(2) If the applicant is indebted to the city for the same kind of service as that applied for;
(3) For refusal to make a security deposit if the applicant is required to make a deposit under this
article.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.093)
Sec. 13.03.214 Discontinuance of service
(a) Notice. Any consumer desiring to discontinue the use of water shall give notice to the water department on
or before the date on which the service is to be discontinued and shall be liable for the use of water until such
notice is given and said service is disconnected. (1998 Code, sec. 72.094)
(b) Disconnection fees. The fee for disconnection of water service shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) but where
there has been an actual disconnection of service by removal of any metering device or disconnection of lines,
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 348/420
there shall be charged and collected a disconnection charge of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for
disconnecting of water and one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) for disconnecting the sewer, except as
provided elsewhere in this section. (Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
(c) Exemptions from disconnection fee.
(1) Eligibility. The residential accounts of qualified persons shall be exempt from the provisions of
this section providing for the assessment of a disconnection fee. Persons may qualify by presenting to
the director of finance proof of eligibility based upon at least one of the following criteria:
(A) Age sixty-five or older.
(B) Age sixty or older and recipient of social security or other old-age or survivor benefits.
(C) Any person, married or unmarried, including those living alone, who is under a disability
for purposes of payment of disability insurance benefits under federal old-age, survivors' and
disability insurance or its successor.
In addition to the hereinabove mentioned criteria, the person making application for said
exemption must be the principal source of income for the household at which the account
in question is located. The account shall not be eligible for said exemption if the person
applying for the exemption is a temporary resident, boarder, or family member living with
owners or renters of the property who would not otherwise be eligible.
(2) Determination. The director of finance shall review all submitted proof and shall determine
eligibility for such exemption. The determination of the director of finance may be appealed to the
city manager, and upon a review of all submitted proof and a hearing of the applicant's grievance, the
city manager shall issue a determination, which shall be final.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.094)
Sec. 13.03.215 Liability for unpaid charges
(a) In cases of landlord/tenant relationships, the director of finance may require an additional deposit charged
against premises for which a tenant has left an unpaid balance, if the owner of the premises chooses not to be
liable for the unpaid balance.
(b) In cases where the premises have been disconnected from water or wastewater services under the authority
provided in section 13.03.218 of this code, the owner of the premises shall be liable for any charges for
reconnection of services.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.095)
Sec. 13.03.216 Water rates and charges
(a) Rate schedule.
(1) The minimum rate for water, which shall be charged all customers, except as otherwise
provided, shall be $32.25 per month effective October 1, 2016. (Ordinance O-18-16, sec. 5, adopted
8/30/16)
(2) Next two thousand gallons (each 1,000) shall be $3.90.
(3) Each 1,000 gallons above three thousand shall be $3.25.
(Ordinance O-12-11, sec. 4, adopted 9/13/11)

(c) Minimum rates for multifamily units. In calculating the minimum rate to be charged apartment houses,

percent (85%) of the rates established elsewhere in this division provided the customer applies with the
finance director for this rate and provides information satisfactory to the finance director with regard to the
vacancy rate during the past year for units on that customer's account.
(e) Customers outside city limits. For meters outside the city limits, users of city water shall pay two hundred
twenty-five percent (225%) of the established rate for similar customers inside the city limits.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.096)

Sec. 13.03.217 Wastewater service rates and charges
(a) Minimum rate. The minimum rate for wastewater service, which shall be charged all customers, except as
otherwise provided, shall be: (1) residential: $23.75; and (2) commercial: $30.00; per month effective October 1,
2014. (Ordinance O-18-14, sec. 4, adopted 9/9/14)
(b) The city, through its water and wastewater department, shall charge and collect, and every customer shall
pay, for wastewater service furnished to the customer, whether or not the city meter is the only source of billing
of water used by the user, the amount calculated by application of the following rates for all billing cycles on or
after October 1, 2009:
Amount of Wastewater Rate
Residential (based on water consumption):
First 7,000 gallons (minimum) $23.75
Commercial (based on water consumption):
First 10,000 gallons (minimum) $30.00

100,001 gallons to 101,000 $92.50

(c) Users providing own water. Where the user provides all or part of his own water, and it is disposed of
through the city wastewater disposal system, the water not metered on the city water system shall be metered the
same as if the water was procured from the city with the same rates for installation and rules concerning the
water meters as if the water was purchased from the city, with the exception that no charge is made for the water.

(d) Minimum rate for multifamily units. In calculating the minimum rate to be charged apartment houses,

(e) Service outside city limits. For service outside the city limits, users of city wastewater service shall pay
two hundred twenty-five percent (225%) of the established rate for similar customers inside the city limits.
(f) Nonprofit multifamily units. Nonprofit multifamily residential units will be charged according to
commercial wastewater rates.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.097)
Sec. 13.03.218 Authority to disconnect service
The city shall retain the right to disconnect water and wastewater service in the following circumstances:
(1) Upon request of the user;
(2) Upon termination of service;
(3) Upon failure of the user to properly meter non-city water;
(4) Where a known dangerous condition related to the type of service provided exists, for as long
as the condition exists;
(5) Where service is connected without authority by a person who has not made application for
service;
(6) Where service has been reconnected without authority following termination of service for
nonpayment; or
(7) In instances of tampering with the water and wastewater department's meter or equipment,
bypassing the same, or other instances of diversion as defined in this article.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.098)
Sec. 13.03.219 Payment; late charge
The rates and charges fixed and prescribed in this article shall be due and payable in the office of the director of
finance on or before the tenth (10th) day after billing. In the event that such rates and charges are not received
within 10 days from such due date, the director of finance shall assess and collect a penalty of ten percent (10%)
of the amount so due and payable. (1998 Code, sec. 72.099)
Sec. 13.03.220 Disconnection of service for nonpayment; collection of unpaid charges
(a) Disconnection for nonpayment. In the event that any user or customer of the water and wastewater systems
does not pay the rates and charges within thirty (30) days from the date originally billed, the director of finance
shall cause the water and/or wastewater service to be disconnected until such rates and charges are paid,
including any penalty assessed for late payment.
(b) Past due debts. In the event that any user or customer of the water and wastewater systems does not pay
the rates and charges and the service is discontinued for nonpayment, the debt shall be considered past due.
Within thirty (30) days from the date of discontinuance of service, the director of finance shall deduct an amount
equal to the debtor's security deposit, if any, and shall institute a civil suit to secure payment of a sum in the
amount of any remaining debt plus any interest and legal costs incurred in obtaining a judgment against the
debtor in a court of proper jurisdiction.

(1998 Code, sec. 72.100)
Sec. 13.03.221 Resumption of service after disconnection
Upon payment of the amount past due and delinquent, any penalty, any judgment and court costs incurred in the
collection of a past due account, and a security deposit as required, water and wastewater service may be
resumed. (1998 Code, sec. 72.101)
Sec. 13.03.222 Returned check charge
A charge not to exceed thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be collected when a customer's check is returned by the bank
unpaid because of insufficient funds or any other reason. April 1, 2005.
Sec. 13.03.223 Charge for temporary turn-off and turn-on
A charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be collected for each turn-off and each turn-on requested by a customer
and made by the city for any reason. October 1, 2009.
Sec. 13.03.224 Charge for out-of-cycle meter reading
A charge of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be collected for each time a customer request and the city makes an out-ofcycle
meter reading. However, if the meter is read for a customer as a recheck on the regular reading and the
reading was found to be in error, there will be no charge.
(Ordinance O-03-11, sec. 2, adopted 3/15/11)
Sec. 13.03.225 Estimation of usage upon failure of water meter to register correctly
(a) Should any water meter fail to register correctly the amount of water used by a consumer since the
previous reading, the water and wastewater department shall estimate the consumption based on previous usage.
(b) Any such estimation of previous usage may be based on an average of the three previous months, or upon
the same month in the previous year, or the water and wastewater superintendent may submit an estimate of
usage to the director of finance if it is determined that consumption of an amount of water in excess of either of
these methods of estimation has occurred.
(c) The method of estimation to be used for any such consumption shall be determined by the director of
finance. The determination of the director of finance may be appealed to the city manager, and upon a review all
submitted evidence of usage and a hearing of the applicant's grievance, the city manager shall issue a
determination, which shall be final.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.105)
Sec. 13.03.226 Responsibility for leakage
(a) All property owners, their agents and tenants shall be held responsible as consumers for loss of water due
to leakage in pipe or plumbing inside the discharge side of the meter or on the property, and if this water is not
paid for according to the rates then in effect, when it becomes due, the water service shall be cut off and not
turned on again until all claims are paid or adjusted to the satisfaction of the water and wastewater department.
(b) In the event of any change in tenant or consumers in rented property, and there exist, at the time,
arrearages for past leakage, the landlord and property owner shall be held accountable for payment for this
leakage before service will be extended and water furnished to the second tenant, unless said landlord and owner
can provide either evidence of repair from a plumber licensed to work in the city or certification from the
plumbing inspector that the leak was repaired in accordance with city plumbing codes.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 353/420
(1998 Code, sec. 72.106)
Sec. 13.03.227 Billing adjustments
(a) Customers experiencing water leaks and high bills.
(1) Any church and/or residential city water customer who experiences a water leak and abnormal
water bill is eligible for an adjustment on the customer's water bill if the following conditions are
met:
(A) The customer experienced a water leak and can provide either evidence of repair from a
plumber licensed to work in the city or certification from the plumbing inspector that the leak
was repaired by the resident homeowner in accordance with city plumbing codes;
(B) The water consumption increased at least fifty percent (50%) over the prior month or
comparable month in the previous year;
(C) The customer has not had an adjustment to a bill in the past twelve (12) months.
(2) If these conditions are met, the director of finance is authorized to make an adjustment on the
customer's account in the following manner:
(A) The average consumption shall be based on the monthly water consumption during the
two (2) past months and the same three (3) month period of the prior year, if the customer
received city service during that period of time. Only water service shall be affected by any
adjustment, not wastewater or sanitation services. The difference between the average
consumption and consumption during the billing period in which the leak occurred shall be the
amount of leakage.
(B) If the above conditions are met, the director of finance is authorized to make an
adjustment on the customer's account by deducting the cost for one-half (1/2) of the leakage
amount as described above. The customer may also be authorized to pay the current amount
(based on average consumption and wastewater and sanitation charges) and one-third of
remaining cost of the leakage amount at the time of the adjustment and continue to pay the
current bill and another one-third (1/3) of the leakage amount each month until fully paid
without the addition of a penalty for late payment.
(3) If incomplete billing records exist to compute the consumption defined herein, the finance
director and the water superintendent may make appropriate estimates to allow the completion of the
adjustment.
(b) Customers with incorrect meter readings.
(1) A residential city water customer who experiences an abnormal water bill due to an incorrect
meter reading is eligible for an adjustment on the customer's water bill if the water and wastewater
superintendent determines that:
(A) The customer's high bill was due to an incorrect meter reading during previous months;
and
(B) The current reading is determined to be correct for the amount of water actually used.
(2) The director of finance is authorized to:
(A) Waive the payment of any:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 354/420
(i) Late charge penalty; or
(ii) Fee for re-reading the customer's meter; and
(B) Allow the customer up to six (6) months to pay the balance without interest or penalty.
(1998 Code, sec. 72.107)

ARTICLE 13.04 WATER SUPPLY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT*
Division 1. Generally
Secs. 13.04.001–13.04.030 Reserved
Division 2. Drought Contingency Plan
Part I. In General
Sec. 13.04.031 Policy; purpose and intent; scope
(a) Declaration of policy. In order to conserve the available water supply and protect the integrity of water
supply facilities, with particular regard for domestic water use, sanitation, and fire protection, and to protect and
preserve public health, welfare, and safety and minimize the adverse impacts of water supply shortage or other
water supply emergency conditions, the city hereby adopts the following regulations and restrictions on the
delivery and consumption of water.
(b) Purpose and intent. Water uses regulated or prohibited under this water supply emergency management
article are considered to be nonessential and continuation of such uses during times of water shortage or other
emergency water supply condition are deemed to constitute a waste of water which subjects the offender(s) to
penalties as defined in section 13.04.091 of this article.
(c) Drought contingency plan. This article shall serve as the drought contingency plan as required under the
provisions of section 11.1272 of the Water Code of the state.
(d) Public involvement. Opportunity for the public to provide input into the preparation of the plan was
provided by the city by means of public hearing prior to the meeting.
(e) Public education. The city will periodically provide the public with information about the plan, including
information about the conditions under which each stage of the plan is to be initiated or terminated and the
drought response measures to be implemented in each stage. The information will be provided by means of press
release or utility bill inserts.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 357/420
(f) Coordination with regional water planning groups. The service area of the city is located within the Llano
Estacado Planning Group (region “O”) and Canadian River Municipal Water Authority. The city secretary is
hereby authorized and directed to provide a copy of the plan to same.
Sec. 13.04.032 Authority of mayor and city manager
(a) Officers designated. The following officer of the city shall have the authority to initiate or terminate
drought or other water supply emergency response measures as described in this article:
(1) The mayor, acting under authority granted as emergency management director in section
1.05.006(a) of this code; or
(2) The city manager acting under the authority granted as emergency management coordinator in
section 1.05.006(b).
(b) Implementation authorized. These officers are hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable
provisions of this article upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect public health,
safety and welfare.
Sec. 13.04.033 Applicability
The provisions of this article shall apply to all persons, customers, and property utilizing water provided by the
city. The terms “person” and “customer” as used in this article includes individuals, corporations, partnerships,
associations, and all other legal entities.
Sec. 13.04.034 Definitions
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply:
Aesthetic water use. Water use for ornamental or decorative purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and
water gardens.
Commercial and institutional water use. Water use which is integral to the operations of commercial and
nonprofit establishments and governmental entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants,
and office buildings.
Conservation. Those practices, techniques, and technologies that reduce the consumption of water, reduce the
loss or waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of water so
that a supply is conserved and made available for future or alternative uses.
Customer. Any person, company, or organization using water supplied by the city.
Domestic water use. Water use for personal needs or for household or sanitary purposes such as drinking,
bathing, heating, cooking, sanitation, or for cleaning a residence, business, industry, or institution.
Even-numbered address. Street addresses, box number or rural postal route numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8 and
locations without addresses.
Industrial water use. The use of water in processes designed to convert materials of lower value into forms
having greater usability and value.
Landscape irrigation use. Water used for the irrigation and maintenance of landscaped areas, whether publicly
or privately owned, including residential and commercial lawns, gardens, golf courses, parks, and rights-of-way
and medians.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 358/420
Nonessential water use. Water uses that are not essential nor required of the protection of public, health, safety,
and welfare, including:
(1) Irrigation of landscape areas, including parks, athletic fields, and golf courses, except otherwise
provided under this plan;
(2) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other vehicle;
(3) Use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, or
other hard-surfaced areas;
(4) Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for purposes other than immediate fire
protection;
(5) Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or accumulate in any gutter or street;
(6) Use of water to fill, refill, or add to any indoor or outdoor swimming pools or Jacuzzi-type
pools;
(7) Use of water in a fountain or pond for aesthetic or scenic purposes except where necessary to
support aquatic life;
(8) Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a reasonable period after having been given notice
directing the repair of such leak(s); and
(9) Use of water from hydrants for construction purposes or any other purposes other than
firefighting.
Odd-numbered address. Street addresses, box number, or rural postal route numbers ending in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9.
Secs. 13.04.035–13.04.060 Reserved
Part II. Drought and Emergency Contingency Stages and Procedures
Sec. 13.04.061 Water emergency contingency stage implementation
(a) Responsibility. The director of utilities or his/her designee, shall monitor water supply and/or demand
stage of this article. Public notification of the initiation or termination of drought response stages shall be by
means of publication conditions on a daily basis and shall determine when conditions warrant initiation or
termination of each in the official newspaper of the city, local radio and through the cable television local
organization channel.
(b) Triggering criteria. The triggering criteria described below are based on analysis of the vulnerability of the
water source under drought of record conditions and any identifiable limitations of production and/or delivery
systems.
(1) Stage 1 - Mild water shortage conditions.
(A) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be requested to comply with the
requirements and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses provided in section 13.04.034
when the water supply available is less than eighty percent (80%) of flow capabilities, or when
the director of utilities determines that a “mild shortage condition” exists.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 359/420
(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 1 may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed
as triggering events have ceased to exist as determined by the director of utilities.
(2) Stage 2 - Moderate water shortage conditions.
(A) Goal. Achieve a twenty-five percent (25%) reduction in daily water demand.
(B) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements
and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses provided in section 13.04.034 when the
water supply available is less than seventy-five percent (75%) of flow capabilities, or when the
director of utilities determines that a “moderate water condition” exists based on: [sic]
(C) Water use restrictions. Under threat of penalty for violation, the following water use
restrictions shall apply to all persons:
(i) Irrigation of landscape areas with hose-end sprinklers or automatic irrigation system
shall be limited to even-numbered days for customers with a street address ending in an
even number (0, 2, 4, 6, 8), and odd-numbered days for water customers with a street
address ending in an odd number (1, 3, 5, 7 or 9). Irrigation of landscape areas is limited
to the hours of 12:00 midnight until 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00
midnight. However, irrigation of landscaped areas is permitted at anytime if it is by means
of hand-held hose, a faucet filled bucket or watering can of five (5) gallons or less, or drip
irrigation system.
(ii) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other
vehicle shall be done with a hand-held bucket or a hand-held hose equipped with a
positive shutoff nozzle for quick rinses. Vehicle washing may be done at any tine on the
immediate premises of a commercial carwash or commercial service station. Further, such
washing may be exempted from these regulations if the health, safety, and welfare of the
public is contingent upon frequent vehicle cleansing, such as garbage trucks and vehicles
used to transport food and perishables.
(iii) Use of water to fill, refill, or add to any indoor or outdoor swimming pools, wading
pools, or Jacuzzi-type pools is prohibited except on designated watering days between the
hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight.
(iv) Operation of any ornamental fountain or pond for aesthetic or scenic purposes is
prohibited except where necessary to support aquatic life or where such fountains or
ponds are equipped with a recirculation system.
(v) Use of water from hydrants shall be limited to firefighting, related activities, or
other activities necessary to maintain public health, safety, and welfare, except that use of
water from designated fire hydrants for construction purposes may be allowed under
special permit from the city.
(vi) The following uses of water are defined as nonessential and are prohibited:
a. Wash down of any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts,
or other hard-surfaced areas;
b. Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for purposes other than
immediate fire protection;
c. Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or accumulate in any gutter or street;
and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 360/420
d. Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a reasonable period after having
been given notice directing the repair of such leak(s).
(D) Requirements for termination. Stage 2 may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed
as triggering events have ceased to exist as determined by the director of utilities upon
termination of stage 2, stage 1 becomes operative.
(3) Stage 3 - Severe water shortage conditions.
(A) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements
and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses provided in section 13.04.034 when the
director of utilities determines that a “severe water crisis condition” exists based on:
(i) An analysis of water supply availability under drought of record conditions may
indicate that there is an immediate risk of water supply shortage;
(ii) That there exists severe facility capacity limitations; or
(iii) Emergency conditions such as supply source contamination exists.
(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 3 may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed
as triggering events have ceased to exist as determined by the director of utilities upon
termination of stage 3, stage 2 becomes operative.
(4) Stage 4 - Critical water shortage conditions.
(A) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements
and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses for stage 4 of this plan when the water supply
is less than 50% of flow capabilities or when the director of utilities determines that a critical
water condition exists.
(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 4 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the
conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist or as determined by the director of
utilities.
(5) Stage 5 - Emergency water shortage conditions.
(A) Requirement for initiation. Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements
and restrictions for stage 5 of this plan when the director of utilities or his/her designee,
determines that a water supply emergency exists based on:
(i) Major water line breaks, or pump or system failures occur, which cause
unprecedented loss of capability to provide water service; or
(ii) Natural or manmade contamination of the water supply source(s).
(B) Requirements for termination. Stage 5 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the
conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist or as determined by the director of
utilities.
(6) Stage 6 - Water allocation.
(A) Requirements for initiation. Customers shall be required to comply with the water
allocation plan prescribed in section 13.04.034 of this plan and comply with the requirements
and restrictions for stage 5 of the plan when: [sic]
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 361/420
(B) Water rationing. In the [event] that water shortage conditions threaten public health,
safety, and welfare, the director of utilities is hereby authorized to ration water according to the
following water allocation plan:
(i) Single-family residential customers.
a. The allocation to residential water customers residing in a single-family
dwelling shall be as follows:
Persons per Household Gallons per Month
1 or 2 6,000
3 or 4 7,000
5 or 6 8,000
7 or 8 9,000
9 or 10 10,000
11 or more 12,000
b. “Household” means the residential premises served by the customer's meter.
“Persons per household” includes only those persons currently physically residing at
the premises and expected to reside there for the entire billing period. It shall be
assumed that a particular customers household is comprised of two (2) persons
unless the customer notifies the city of a greater number of persons per household on
a form prescribed by the director of utilities. The director of utilities shall give
his/her best effort to see that such forms are mailed, otherwise provided, or made
available to every residential customer. If, however, a customer does not receive

c. When the number of persons per household increases so as to place the

writing within two (2) days. In prescribing the method for claiming more than two
(2) persons per household, the city secretary shall adopt methods to ensure the
accuracy of the claim. Any person who knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal
negligence falsely reports the number of persons in a household fails to timely notify
the city of a reduction in the number of persons in a household shall be fined not less
than $25.00. Residential water customers shall pay the following surcharge:

1. $10.00 for the first 1,000 gallons over allocation.

3. $75.00 for the third 1,000 gallons over allocation.
4. $100.00 for each additional 1,000 gallons over allocation.
Surcharges shall be cumulative.
(ii) Commercial customers.
a. A monthly water usage allocation shall be established by the director of
utilities, or his/her designee, for each nonresidential commercial customer other than
the industrial customer who uses water for processing purposes. The nonresidential
customer's allocation shall be approximately 75% of the customer's usage for
corresponding month's billing period for the previous 12 months. If the customer's
billing history is shorter than 12 months, the monthly average for the period for
which there is a record shall be used for any monthly period for which no history
exists. Provided, however, a customer, whose monthly usage is less than 1,000
gallons, shall be allocated 750 gallons.
b. The director of utilities shall give his/her best effort to see that notice of each
nonresidential customer's allocation is mailed to such customer. If, however, a
customer does not receive such notice, it shall be the customer's responsibility to
contact the city to determine the allocation. Upon request of the customer or at the
initiative of the director of utilities, the allocation may be reduced or increased if the
designated period does not accurately reflect the customer's normal water usage, one
nonresidential customer agrees to transfer part of its allocation to another
nonresidential customer, or other objective evidence demonstrates that the
designated allocation is inaccurate under present conditions. A customer may appeal
an allocation established hereunder to the mayor and city council. Nonresidential
commercial customers shall pay the following surcharges:
1. $20.00 per thousand gallons for first 1,000 gallons over allocation.
2. $50.00 per thousand gallons for second 1,000 gallons over allocation.
3. $150.00 per thousand gallons for third 1,000 gallons over allocation.
4. $200.00 per thousand gallons for each additional 1,000 gallons over
allocation.
The surcharges shall be cumulative.
(C) Requirement for termination. Water allocation may be rescinded when all of the
conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist or determined by the director of
utilities.
Sec. 13.04.062 Drought response stages
The director of utilities or his/her designee, shall monitor water supply and/or demand conditions on a daily
basis and, in accordance with the triggering criteria set forth in section 13.04.061 of this plan, shall determine
that a mild, moderate, severe, critical emergency or water shortage condition exists and shall implement the
following actions upon publication of notice in a newspaper of general circulation.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 363/420
(1) Stage 1 - Mild water shortage condition.
(A) Goal. Achieve a voluntary reduction in total water use.
(B) Supply management measures. Measures, if any, to be implemented to manage limited
water supplies and/or reduce water demand may include reduced or discontinued flushing of
water mains, activation and use of an alternative supply source(s); and use of reclaimed water
for nonpotable purposes.
(C) Voluntary water use restrictions.
(i) Water customers are requested to voluntarily limit the irrigation of landscaped areas
to Sundays and Thursdays for customers with a street address ending in an even number
(0, 2, 4, 6, or 8), and Saturdays and Wednesdays for water customers with a street address
ending in an odd number (1, 3, 5, 7 or 9), and to irrigate landscapes only between the
hours of midnight and 10:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. to midnight on designated watering days.
(ii) All operation of the city adhere to water use restrictions prescribed for stage 2.
(iii) Water customers are requested to practice water conservation and to minimize or
discontinue water use for nonessential purposes.
(2) Stage 2 - Moderate water shortage conditions.
(A) Goal. Achieve a 25% percent reduction in daily water demand, etc.
(B) Supply management measures. Measures, if any, to be implemented to manage limited
water supplies and/or reduce water demand may include reduced or discontinued flushing of
water mains, activation and use of an alternative supply source(s); reduced or discontinued
irrigation of public landscaped areas, and use of reclaimed water for nonpotable purposes.
(C) Water use restrictions for demand reduction. Under the threat of penalty for violation, the
following water use restrictions shall apply to all persons:
(i) Irrigation of landscape areas with hose-end sprinklers or automatic irrigation system
shall be limited to even-numbered days for customers with a street address ending in an
even number (0, 2, 4, 6, 8), and odd-numbered days for water customers with a street
address ending in an odd number (1, 3, 5, 7 or 9). Irrigation of landscape areas is limited
to the hours of 12:00 midnight until 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00
midnight. However, irrigation of landscaped areas is permitted at anytime if it is by means
of hand-held hose, a faucet filled bucket or watering can of five (5) gallons or less, or drip
irrigation system.
(ii) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other
vehicle is prohibited except on designated watering days between the hours of 12:00
midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. Such washing, when
allowed, shall be done with a hand-held bucket or a hand-held hose equipped with a
positive shutoff nozzle for quick rinses. Vehicle washing may be done at any time on the
immediate premises of a commercial carwash or commercial service station. Further, such
washing may be exempted from these regulations if the health, safety, and welfare of the
public is contingent upon frequent vehicle cleansing, such as garbage trucks and vehicles
used to transport food and perishables.
(iii) Use of water to fill, refill, or add to any indoor or outdoor swimming pools, wading
pools, or Jacuzzi-type pools is prohibited except on designated watering days between the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 364/420
hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight.
(iv) Operation of any ornamental fountain or pond for aesthetic or scenic purposes is
prohibited except where necessary to support aquatic life or where such fountains or
ponds are equipped with a recirculation system.
(v) Use of water from hydrants shall be limited to firefighting, related activities, or
other activities necessary to maintain public health, safety, and welfare, except that use of
water from designated fire hydrants for construction purposes may be allowed under
special permit from the city.
(vi) Use of water for the irrigation of golf course greens, tees, and fairways is
prohibited except on designated watering days between the hours 12:00 midnight and
10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight. However, if the golf course utilizes
a water source other than that provided by the city, the facility shall not be subject to these
regulations.
(vii) All restaurants are prohibited from serving water to patrons except upon request of
the patron.
(viii) The following uses of water are defined as nonessential and are prohibited:
a. Wash down of any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts,
or other hard-surfaced areas;
b. Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for purposes other than
immediate fire protection;
c. Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or accumulate in any gutter or street;
and
d. Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a reasonable period after having
been given notice directing the repair of such leak(s).
(3) Stage 3 - Severe water shortage conditions.
(A) Goal. Achieve a 35% percent reduction in daily water demand.
(B) Water use restrictions for demand reduction. All requirements of stage 2 shall remain in
effect during stage 3 except:
(i) Irrigation of landscaped areas shall be limited to designated watering days between
the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 8:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight
and shall be by means of hand-held hoses, hand-held buckets, drip irrigation or
permanently installed automatic sprinkler system only. The use of hose-end sprinklers is
prohibited at all times.
(ii) The watering of golf course tees is prohibited unless the golf course utilizes a water
source other than that provided by the city.
(iii) The use of water for construction purposes from designated fire hydrants under
special permit is to be discontinued.
(4) Stage 4 - Critical water shortage conditions.
(A) Goal. Achieve a 50% percent reduction in daily water demand.

(B) Water use restrictions for demand reduction. All requirements of stage 2 and 3 shall

(ii) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other

prohibited. Further, such vehicle washing at commercial carwashes and commercial
service stations shall occur only between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and

(iii) No application for new, additional, expanded, or increased-in-size water service

any kind shall be approved, and time limits for approval of such applications are hereby
suspended for such time as this drought response stage or a higher-numbered stage shall
be in effect.
(5) Stage 5 - Emergency water shortage conditions.
(A) Goal. Achieve a 75% percent reduction in daily water demand.
(B) Water use restrictions for demand reduction. All requirements of stage 2, 3 and 4 shall
remain in effect during stage 5 except:
(i) Irrigation of landscaped areas is absolutely prohibited.
(ii) Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other
vehicle is absolutely prohibited.

(ii) “Household” means the residential premises served by the customer's meter.
